webTitle: Blank Czechs leave Liverpool in the dark

fields.headline: Blank Czechs leave Liverpool in the dark
fields.standfirst: Uefa Cup
fields.trailText: Liverpool will step into the unknown at Anfield tonight despite having two Czech Republic internationals in their squad. When the second-round draw paired the Merseysiders with Slovan Liberec, Gerard Houllier looked a contented man as he approached Patrik Berger and Vladimir Smicer.
fields.body:
Liverpool will step into the unknown at Anfield tonight despite having two Czech Republic internationals in their squad. When the second-round draw paired the Merseysiders with Slovan Liberec, Gerard Houllier looked a contented man as he approached Patrik Berger and Vladimir Smicer.

The Czech mates would illuminate a blank canvas and Liberec's secrets would be laid bare. Or so Houllier thought. "I don't know much about them really," confessed Berger. "They are a small club from a small town in the north near the Polish border."

Smicer was equally unsure about the merits of a club in Europe for the first time. "I know that they are small but very ambitious," said Smicer. "They don't even have floodlights at their ground but are installing them just for the second leg. This will be the biggest game in their history by some distance."

Liverpool must overcome Liberec at Anfield without their most potent weapon, Michael Owen. The striker sat out Saturday's win over Leicester with the after-effects of concussion suffered at Derby. He now has a slight leg injury and may even miss Sunday's derby with Everton at Anfield.

 Chris Sutton will have a late fitness test on his left ankle before Celtic's second-round tie in Bordeaux tonight. The striker was injured in Celtic's 2-1 win over Dundee United on Saturday. Bordeaux will be without the Belgian Marc Wilmots and the Russian Alexei Smertin.

fields.headline: Mihajlovic apologises for racial abuse
fields.trailText: Sinisa Mihajlovic has apologised for racially abusing Patrick Vieira during last week's Champions League match between Lazio and Arsenal.
fields.body:
Sinisa Mihajlovic has apologised for racially abusing Patrick Vieira during last week's Champions League match between Lazio and Arsenal.

Mihajlovic was fined and suspended for two European games after calling the French midfielder a "black shit" and then subjecting him to a torrent of racial abuse throughout the game.

Speaking before Lazio's home match against Shakhtar Donetsk last night, the Yugoslav said on the public address system: "I know I made a mistake last Tuesday and I want to sincerely apologise to all those who felt rightly offended for the expression I used in a moment of particular tension on the field."

Mihajlovic also called on Lazio fans to cease racist chanting. "Please stop for ever the racist chants against players of colour," he said.

He went on to claim that his former colleagues from his time at Sampdoria - Ruud Gullit, Clarence Seedorf and Christian Karembeu - would confirm his good character. "I want to deny the racist label that has been applied to me," he said

fields.headline: Straw's 'Orwell' curbs on sex videos
fields.trailText: Film industry watchdogs last night warned the home secretary, Jack Straw, that his plans for a fresh clampdown on R18 sexually explicit videos will give the police "Orwellian" powers to enter private homes to check whether parents have hidden such videos from their children.
fields.body:
Film industry watchdogs last night warned the home secretary, Jack Straw, that his plans for a fresh clampdown on R18 sexually explicit videos will give the police "Orwellian" powers to enter private homes to check whether parents have hidden such videos from their children.

The British Board of Film Classification also attacked his plans to abolish the independent watchdog which last year passed them for sale in adult-only sex shops and appoint a new watchdog body in its place. The BBFC defended the video appeals committee, saying its appointment process should be kept separate from Whitehall.

Mr Straw proposed the new controls on R18 videos after a high court ruling backed the video appeals committee's decision to legalise their sale. He claimed that the new controls were needed because there was evidence that paedophiles "sometimes used this sort of material to 'groom' children for sexual abuse."

But the BBFC, whose president is Andreas Whittam Smith, now says that such paedophiles also use a range of legitimate sex education videos and that the R18 category specifically bans any material involving children in a sexual context.

"The UK still probably has the strictest guidelines of any European or western nation," said the BBFC statement. "There was also no evidence that in countries where pornography was more accessible, children had more problems as a result."

The film standards watchdog however does want to see a legal requirement for all R18 videos to be labelled with a clear warning of the dangers of exposing children to their contents.

The video standards council was also deeply critical of Mr Straw's proposal to create a new criminal offence of failing to take reasonable care to prevent a child from watching an R18 video.

fields.headline: Sturm damage for divided Rangers
fields.standfirst: Sturm Graz 2 Yuran 19 Prilasnig 90 Rangers 0
fields.trailText: Rangers must now go to the wire in Group D. With great resolve Sturm Graz have stormed to the top of the section and, with Monaco also seeing off Galatasaray, Rangers must now beat the French champions in two weeks to be sure of reaching the second phase. A point will do for Dick Advocaat's side only if Sturm win in Istanbul.
fields.byline: Graham Spiers at the Arnold Schwarzenegger Stadium
fields.body:
Rangers must now go to the wire in Group D. With great resolve Sturm Graz have stormed to the top of the section and, with Monaco also seeing off Galatasaray, Rangers must now beat the French champions in two weeks to be sure of reaching the second phase. A point will do for Dick Advocaat's side only if Sturm win in Istanbul.

If this is anything to go by, Ibrox in a fortnight will be a shocking strain on Glaswegian nervous systems. Rangers are in dire straits and last night ended with defeat compounded by the sending-off of Arthur Numan after the defender's second caution in the final minutes.

Even then Gilbert Prilasnig found time in the last seconds to shoot home with a low drive to add to Sergei Yuran's earlier goal and complete the Austrian victory.

Rangers faced a minor storm here, much of it whipped up by themselves. As they came off the back of one win in five games, the spirit around Ibrox already seemed fragile.

The sight of the team captain Lorenzo Amoruso and Advocaat angrily bawling at each other hardly improved matters. Neither did Sturm being allowed to skip into a 19th-minute lead.

Many of the salvoes were stressful for Rangers. Bert Konterman was booked, putting him, like Numan, out of the Monaco game. Most of Rangers' efforts also failed to perturb Josef Schicklgruber in goal.

Advocaat and Amoruso have famously been at odds but the captain's refusal to heed the manager's instructions with Rangers in disarray seemed one conceit too far. Rangers quickly changed their shape from a defensive trio to an orthodox back four but by then damage had been inflicted. Yuran's stealth saw to that.

By the time Prilasnig's long pass had found Hannes Reinmayr on the right, the Rangers defence was wilting. Reinmayr's swift lob released Yuran in the area and the rest he made simple. Such was Rangers' defensive confusion that Barry Ferguson, a midfielder, frantically attempted to make the saving tackle. Yuran skipped around him and the goalkeeper Jesper Christiansen to prod home from eight yards.

Rangers desperately needed incision from their cultured Dutchman Giovanni van Bronckhorst but, having been out injured for three weeks, he lasted only 55 minutes here.

His low 20-yard effort in the first half - saved by Schicklgruber - had been one of Rangers' highlights in a dispiriting opening period and his loss was a further blow to their morale. Sturm, meanwhile, continued to ferret their way towards Christiansen's goal.

The young Danish goalkeeper, plucked urgently from Odense by Rangers last week, watched as Yuran and Tomislav Kocijan tore towards him.

In the 48th minute Yuran blasted a venomous shot too high. Moments later Kocijan slithered behind the Rangers defence to drive just to the right of Christiansen's upright. Rangers found all this too fraught by far.

Sturm Graz ( 3-5-2): Schicklgruber; Neukirchner, Popovic, Koros; Mamedov (Feldhofer, 84min), Schupp, Reinmayr (Minavand, h-t), Fleurquin, Prilasnig; Yuran, Kocijan.

Rangers : (3-5-2): Christiansen; Amoruso, Porrini (Negri, 76), Konterman; Kanchelskis, Ferguson, Tugay, Van Bronckhorst (McCann, 55), Numan; Wallace (Dodds, 71), De Boer.

Referee : A Lopez (Spain).

fields.headline: Cruising Arsenal secure top spot
fields.standfirst: Arsenal 4 Parlour 5 Lauren 7 Dixon 35 Kanu 52 Sparta Prague 2 Labant 41pen Rosicky 90
fields.trailText: The only disappointment for Arsenal's fans last night was that their side only scored four times. Two up inside seven minutes, Arsène Wenger's players slipped into cruise control and produced only bursts of brilliance to make sure of top spot in Group B.
fields.body:
The only disappointment for Arsenal's fans last night was that their side only scored four times. Two up inside seven minutes, Arsène Wenger's players slipped into cruise control and produced only bursts of brilliance to make sure of top spot in Group B.

Goals by Ray Parlour, Lauren and Lee Dixon put Arsenal in control and although Sparta Prague pulled one back, Nwankwo Kanu added a fourth early in the second half. Sparta's spirit deserved the impressive injury-time goal added by Tomas Rosicky but they never looked likely to prevent Arsenal continuing their 100% record here this season.

Arsenal knew that whatever happened they could look forward to playing in the second group stage, having qualified last week with that 1-1 draw at Lazio. But Wenger's team were aware that victory would guarantee top spot and ensure they could draw only one other group winner in the next round. The £200,000 offered by Uefa for a win must also have interested Wenger as he saves up for decent binoculars and a good lawyer in case his appeal against a 12-match touchline ban fails.

Not that Sparta, beaten 1-0 by a piece of Silvinho magic in Prague, had promised to be pushovers. And they must have fancied their chances when they saw Arsenal's defence.

With five centre-halves unavailable, Wenger deployed Oleg Luzhny and Nelson Vivas at the heart of a back four composed entirely of full-backs. Barely had Sparta had a chance to test any weaknesses, though, than they were two goals down. It seemed their back line was made of made of players with bad backs, never mind full-backs.

Arsenal's first arrived in the fifth minute, Patrick Vieira passing square into the path of Parlour, who struck the ball sweetly past Tomas Postulka from 25 yards.

Then, two minutes later, came the second. Robert Pires was the architect, bursting past Libor Sionko on the left flank and cutting back a cross which Lauren swept into the corner. Had Thierry Henry found the back rather than the side of the net when Jiri Novotny made a hash of a back-pass Arsenal would have been three up inside 10 minutes. And, not surprisingly, they drifted for a while.

It needed a fine save from David Seaman to tip a Vladimir Labant free-kick on to the underside of the bar, and Arsenal frequently looked a combination of complacent and confused at the back as Sparta refused to throw in the towel.

Not long after Sionko and Michal Hornak had headed chances wide, though, Arsenal scored a third. Postulka failed to hold Henry's free-kick and the captain Dixon slammed in the loose ball from a couple of yards.

Unfortunately for Arsenal, Seaman had clearly watched that incident too closely. Shortly afterwards he let a Rosicky free-kick slip from his grasp and brought down Marek Kincl as the ball ran loose. To the delight of Sparta's 93 fans Labant scored from the penalty spot.

Perhaps to keep them on their toes, Arsenal switched from blue shirts to yellow at the interval, though the official explanation was that the two teams looked too similar to the fourth official.

Whatever, the change did not confuse Wenger's players. Six minutes into the second half Henry burst into the box down the left and although his cross was blocked by Postulka, Kanu showed off his wonderful balance to wrongfoot a defender and clip in the loose ball.

Still Sparta refused to give up. Seaman atoned for his earlier error by saving well from Sionko and Dixon headed off the line from the resulting corner. But it mattered little as Arsenal looked forward to more testing European ties.

The Lazio defender Sinisa Mihajlovic last night apologised for the abuse he directed at Arsenal's Patrick Vieira in last week's Champions League match. Speaking before last night's home match against Shakhtar Donetsk, the Yu goslav said on the public address system: "I know I made a mistake last Tuesday and I want to sincerely apologise to all those who felt rightly offended for the expression I used in a moment of particular tension on the field." Mihajlovic also called on Lazio fans to cease racist chanting.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Vivas, Luzhny, Silvinho (Cole, h-t); Lauren, Parlour, Vieira, Pires (Bergkamp, 64min); Kanu, Henry (Wiltord, 71).

Sparta Prague (3-5-2): Postulka; Hornak, J Novotny, Bolf; Sionko (Papousek, 85), Jarosik, Rosicky, Hasek, Labant; Kincl, Jun (Mynar, h-t).

Referee: A Hamer (Luxembourg).

webTitle: Rovers profit immediately from Hughes investment

fields.headline: Rovers profit immediately from Hughes investment
fields.standfirst: First Division
fields.trailText: Blackburn Rovers 3 Hughes 26 31, Ostenstad 36 Tranmere Rovers 2 Koumas 30, Taylor 90
fields.body:
Blackburn Rovers 3 Hughes 26 31, Ostenstad 36 Tranmere Rovers 2 Koumas 30, Taylor 90

Mark Hughes, making his Football League debut a week short of his 37th birthday, produced the kind of performance that suggests he will prove to be that most rare of Blackburn commodities in recent seasons - a good investment.

A free transfer signing on Tuesday, the Wales manager has arrived on an 18-month contract and for a considerable salary. But if his signing raised eyebrows after a return of one goal in 18 Premiership games for Everton, they should have been lowered by a robust performance that featured two excellent finishes as well as a 78th-minute booking for persistent foul play.

That Tranmere threatened to steal the limelight from a player who appeared to be entering the autumn of his career when he left Manchester United more than half a decade ago gives a real indication of how much Hughes' experience will be required by Graeme Souness' side.

The Blackburn manager said: "We feel we've not had enough physical presence up front and Mark Hughes is raw, honest aggression, maybe the best there's been in this country the last 10 to 12 years.

"I would have loved to have worked with him when he was a younger man but I'm still glad to have him here at the tender age of, whatever he is."

Hughes 26th-minute opening goal owed much to the industry of Garry Flitcroft. Chasing down a lost cause, he kept a loose ball in play for the winger Damien Johnson, whose first-time cross was swept in matter of factly by Hughes from six yards.

The second goal underlined how much a player of Hughes' vast experience can dominate in this division; he rose effortlessly above Steve Yates to head in Stig Bjornebye's deep cross after 31 minutes.

It was just as well that Hughes was turning the game into his personal finishing regimen because Tranmere were happily setting about demonstrating why Blackburn have a long way to go before they can take a play-off place for granted.

After half an hour they had equalised through Jason Koumas, an eight-yard finish as he ran in unmarked to meet a Richard Hinds' cross from the right. And had Wayne Allison not cleared the bar by the height of a small Lancashire peak minutes after Hughes' second, Blackburn's resolve would have been really tested.

Instead Egil Ostenstad shared the limelight by claiming the game's fourth goal, heading in David Dunn's cross.

There were moments at both ends in the second half, Tranmere's best coming from Koumas, Blackburn's inevitably from Hughes, before the substitute Scott Taylor gave the scoreline a more realistic appearance with a header from Stuart Barlow's cross.

Blackburn Rovers (4-4-2): Filan; Curtis, Berg, Short, Bjornebye; Johnson (McAteer, 76min), Dunn, Flitcroft, Hignett; Ostenstad (Carsley ,53), Hughes.

Tranmere Rovers (5-4-1): Murphy; Hinds, Hazell, Hill, Yates (Challinor, 65), Roberts; Barlow, Hamilton,Flynn, Koumas; Allison (Taylor, 68).

Referee: W Jordan (Tring)

webTitle: Marcelo blows City's weekend blues away

fields.headline: Marcelo blows City's weekend blues away
fields.trailText: Birmingham City 1 Marcelo 90 Gillingham 0
fields.body:
Birmingham City 1 Marcelo 90 Gillingham 0

Trevor Francis proved a master of the timely substitution once more last night. City had huffed and puffed unimaginatively against a resilient Gillingham side who, with goalkeeper Vince Bartram in defiant mood, held out until the Brazilian striker Marcelo, the third of three strikers introduced by the Birmingham manager, struck with a headed goal from a late corner.

Smarting from their failure to defeat Sheffield Wednesday on Sunday, City wasted little time in attempting to atone. But despite almost constant occupation of Gillingham territory during the first period, by the end of it they were no closer to making amends for defeat at Hillsborough.

Bartram was never in danger of being overworked because City, Stan Lazaridis excepted, lacked the wit to break down the five-man defensive wall in front of him. City did not make life easy for themselves. One striker, Dele Adebola, had trouble remaining on his feet while the other, Peter Ndlovu, over-elaborated.

Bartram was finally given an anxious moment 10 minutes before the interval when Adebola at last remained upright. webTitle: Todd set to fill Smith's boots at Derby

fields.headline: Todd set to fill Smith's boots at Derby
fields.trailText: Jim Smith is ready to call time on a managerial career spanning almost 30 years, paving the way for Colin Todd to take over at the Premiership's bottom club Derby County.
fields.body:
Jim Smith is ready to call time on a managerial career spanning almost 30 years, paving the way for Colin Todd to take over at the Premiership's bottom club Derby County.

Swindon Town, who hired Todd on a four-year contract five months ago, rejected Derby's initial approach as well as Todd's resignation proffered after Tuesday's 2-0 home defeat by Millwall. Talks are now ongoing about a compensation package.

Derby issued a statement last night. "After discussing personal terms, Colin Todd has agreed to join as Jim Smith's assistant manager. There is a matter of compensation which Colin and his adviser will be discussing with Swindon and matters cannot be finalised until then."

Smith, 60 last week, is expected to become general manager at the end of the season but the likelihood is that the former Derby defender, who played for Smith at Oxford and Birmingham, will be handed control of first-team affairs within weeks.

"I have been managing football clubs for a long, long time but ideally I know how I would like it to finish," said Smith. "I would like to be able to groom my successor - someone everyone here is agreed upon."

Mark Bosnich has had another acrimonious row with Sir Alex Ferguson. After being ostracised since the summer signing of Fabien Barthez, the deposed goalkeeper incurred his manager's wrath again when he apparently arrived late for the flight to Brussels for Tuesday's Champions League game at Anderlecht.

Bosnich claimed he had problems with his car but Ferguson refused to accept his version of events and dropped him from the bench in favour of Raimond van der Gouw.

Michael Bridges, who scored 22 goals for Leeds last season but has been on the bench for most of this, needs an ankle operation and will be out for at least four months.

Middlesbrough have been informed that the Milan midfielder Zvonimir Boban will be staying in Serie A this season and have turned their attention to Dino Baggio. The Boro manager Bryan Robson held talks with Parma last week and is understood to be preparing a £5m bid for the 29-year-old.

Baggio, who featured at USA 94 and France 98, has been told he can leave and almost joined Lazio in exchange for Nestor Sensini last month.

"There is no chance that Boban will leave," said Adriano Galliani, Milan's vice-president. "His help will be crucial for the rest of the season, given that we're active on all fronts. For him to leave I have to sign and I refuse to do so."

Crystal Palace, who suffered their sixth successive league defeat on Tuesday, have transfer-listed Clinton Morrison, Hayden Mullins, Jamie Smith and Julian Gray. "There are people at this club who are not showing the right commitment or attitude and I won't put up with it any longer," said Alan Smith, Palace's manager. "There is only so much you can do with players whose attitudes leave a lot to be desired."

Watford have signed Stephen Armstrong from Vastra Frolunda to the end of the season. The 24-year-old, scorer of three goals in his 16 Swedish first division games, was born in Birkenhead but spent his childhood in South Africa.

webTitle: FSA warns firms on leaks to investors and media

fields.headline: FSA warns firms on leaks to investors and media
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The financial services authority, the City's watchdog, fired off a warning to major companies last night to stop leaking any information to bankers, investors or the media which could jolt their shares and erode the integrity of the stock market.
fields.body:
The financial services authority, the City's watchdog, fired off a warning to major companies last night to stop leaking any information to bankers, investors or the media which could jolt their shares and erode the integrity of the stock market.

Howard Davies, the FSA chairman, warned that the regulator would "actively pursue" cases of suspected "selective briefing" and issue updated guidelines on disseminating information next year.

The move comes just five months after the FSA took over the regulation of companies from the London Stock Exchange, and the regulator now intends to start consulting the industry on the most effective way of releasing announcements by companies.

"There is nothing more corrosive of market confidence than the feeling that some investors are deliberately excluded from an inner circle of privileged counterparties," Mr Davies said.

From next year the FSA will have the power to fine companies it believes are engaging in such practices in addition to its current ability to issue private or public censures of breaches of the rules.

Yesterday's reminder was caused by the introduction of new rules in the US and follows a number of instances where potentially price-sensitive information has leaked ahead of wider publication - such as the takeover of Compass by Granada to enable the creation of Granada Media.

Mr Davies said the "timely flow of accurate information" was crucial and had become increasingly so because of the large number of smaller investors who are now active in the markets.

Rules prohibiting selective briefing have been in place in the City since 1966, although those in use at present have been operating since 1993 and require firms to issue statements to the LSE about news which could move their shares. When the LSE is closed they must inform news agencies and at least two newspapers.

"In some cases we may be looking at sloppy or careless practices rather than deliberately selective briefings," Mr Davies said. "But sloppy practices can be just as damaging to market integrity."

Mr Davies said "company representives" should refuse to answer questions which could elicit price-sensitive information, and keep records of private briefings. Companies are increasingly recording conversations with analysts.

fields.headline: Same old tune on the Magic Flute
fields.standfirst:
Magic Flute
Richmond Theatre
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Magic Flute
Richmond Theatre
Rating: **
fields.body:
English Touring Opera's new production of The Magic Flute contains no outstanding vocal or dramatic performance; still less does it tell us anything radically new about one of Mozart's most problematic masterpieces. Yet the production is grounded in a solid musical and theatrical vision. Underpinning the performance is Martin Fitzpatrick's deft and purposeful conducting of the 26-piece orchestra. He draws real warmth from the players, especially in Pamina's second act aria, but it is his astute pacing over the course of both acts that is most convincing.

Fitzpatrick carefully characterises each of the dramatic contrasts that drive the opera: from Sarastro's sunlit certainty to the Queen of the Night's darkly glittering realm, and from Papageno's carefree wit to Tamino's heartfelt longing.

Daniel Slater's direction is alert to the ambiguities of the drama. Instead of glossing over the sometimes overt misogyny of Sarastro's creed, he emphasises the libretto's uncomfortable connotations. When one of Sarastro's priests warns Tamino against women's lies, there is a palpable sense of the nastiness behind a facade of supposed wisdom. The dramatic effect is to disrupt the perception of Sarastro representing pure good, any more than the Queen of the Night represents pure evil. Slater even manages to subvert the ending of the opera: the final image of this production is of a grieving Pamina, separated from Tamino, lamenting the death of her mother, the Queen of the Night.

Of the singers, Anna-Clare Monk's Pamina and Dean Robinson's Sarastro are most versatile in combining stage and vocal presence. But even though Richard Burkhard's Papageno grows in personality as the opera progresses, he never masters the blend of humour and pathos the role requires.

It is a bonus to have a Tamino who can play the flute, as the character is supposed to charm the wild animals with it. But although Eugene Ginty's musical multitasking is remarkable, it is his vocal performance that ultimately lets him down: his first aria lacks any suppleness of phrasing, and he becomes more forced throughout the opera. Laura Meloy's coloratura sees her through the famously stratospheric heights of her two arias. Uneven as the cast may be, they are carried by the momentum of overall good musical and dramatic sense.

 At Marlowe Theatre, Canterbury (01227 787787), until Saturday, then touring to Weston-Super-Mare, Bath, Wolverhampton, Wycombe, York and Buxton.

fields.headline: Theatre review:  Intimate Male
fields.trailText: For the past few years John Keates and his company Fecund have been fictionalising their growing-up in a series of off-the-wall multimedia theatre pieces.
fields.body:
Intimate Male BAC, London **

For the past few years John Keates and his company Fecund have been fictionalising their growing-up in a series of off-the-wall multimedia theatre pieces. Keates is now 30, and Intimate Male allows us into his thoughts via a series of poems - some brilliant, some cringe-worthy - and plenty of video scenes featuring Keates in embarrassing wigs.

The evening has a certain clumsiness of tone. At some points it seems like a Steve Coogan spoof; at others, it is lyrical, deadly serious and well observed. But too many of Keates's men are no more than stereotypes, and there is a shallow, middle-class quality to the angst. In a sense this is a piece about someone who has yet to forge a real identity - who hasn't quite got over the fact he was part of the E generation.

As has become customary with Fecund, technology and live action are equal partners, and the whole piece, with its laidback, club-like ambience and Keates's musings on the nature of theatre, is as much about performance and the absurdities of dramatic convention as it is about becoming a man.

I found a lot in this 90-minute show self-indulgent and boring, and it doesn't tell you anything new about being male. But every time I was about to lose interest, the show would veer off in a new direction, form would smash up against form, and I'd suddenly be intrigued again. That is no mean feat, and there's nothing here that a more rigorous directorial eye could not cure.

webTitle: Help me to change my shift

fields.headline: Help me to change my shift
fields.trailText: I work nights as a security guard in a private factory. I have been doing this for 17 years now. It is beginning to take its toll and I want to get out.
fields.body:
The problem

I work night shift on security in a private factory, I have been doing this for 17 years now. It is beginning to takes it toll and I want to get out.

I volunteered to do the job when I was working on the shop floor. My health has been suffering for a couple of years now, and no one appreciates the extra work that has come with the job. I have been overlooked three times for promotion.

Could you please advice me on the best way to get out of my present job and go back on the shop floor. I have mentioned this to my line manager and he says that he is not prepared to release me.

The solution

I wonder why he won't "release" you? Is it because you are so indispensable in security? Or because he doesn't think you are up to shop floor work? Either way, what he probably does not realise is that he has a legal obligation towards you as a night worker. For a start, your employer should provide you with a free medical check and, if medical advice suggests that the nights are taking a toll on your health, your employer is obliged, where possible, to switch you to another shift. In your case, it would seem that a switch to shop work would certainly be possible, given your experience and qualifications.

I suggest that you contact your union or local ACAS (number in the phone book) to confirm your rights. Then you could compose a letter to your line manager, (perhaps copied to his boss) in which you gently but assertively explain that you would like to come off the night shift as the 17 years working nights has taken a toll on your health. Remind him that night work does has this effect - this is why employers are obliged to provide medical checks and to switch employee's shifts where possible if medical advice recommends it. Explain that in your case it should be possible to switch shifts and state that you are more than happy to have a medical check if confirmation of the toll on your health is required.

I imagine that such a letter will soon see your boss finding a way to "release" you!

 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: Austere, silent and nameless - Whiteread's concrete tribute to victims of nazism
fields.standfirst: Closed books and stilled lives
fields.trailText: Finally, five-and-a-half years after Rachel Whiteread’s design for a Holocaust memorial in Vienna was approved, the sculpture was unveiled.
fields.body:
Finally, five-and-a-half years after Rachel Whiteread's design for a Holocaust memorial in Vienna was approved, the sculpture was unveiled.

As much as it is a sculpture Whiteread's memorial is a closed, windowless single storey building. It sits on a low plinth at one end of Judenplatz. The walls are covered from top to bottom in row upon row of books. But it is as though they have been turned to face the wall.

One sees the edges of the book covers, the closed pages. They are like the books one holds in one's hand, about to be opened. Like the rest of the building the books are made of concrete, which in the autumn sunshine looked as pale as the stones which paved the newly pedestrianised square.

A pair of doors at one end of the building are sealed shut. The metaphor, surely, is one of finality.

The concrete looks fresh, although small imperfections in the surface make some of the books look used, the edges of the pages discoloured or speckled with age.

Whiteread had to use a slightly less porous concrete than planned. She wanted the rain to get in and frost to age the sculpture, giving it what she called a somewhat sorry appearance.

At a distance you can barely see the books, and the building appears to be made of a series of slabs. The top edge of the structure is cut off at an angle. Although it echoes the roofs of the baroque buildings which line the square, it looks like a bunker.

Whiteread's memorial asserts itself against its surroundings. It is an interruption in the square. It stops you short.

How can any public sculpture address the enormity of the Holocaust? Expressionist figurative sculpture risks the humiliation of its tormented mannerisms. Whiteread's nameless library is austere to the point of brutality, yet seen up close its details have a familiarity and approachability which invites a step towards it.

At this point one looks down and reads the names of the death camps, and the dedication to the Jewish Austrian dead.

This monument resists the affectations of style. Echoing the military bunkers of the second world war it achieves a kind of stylelessness, and timelessness.

How can one read a closed book? What does a perpetually closed building signify? Whiteread will not be drawn into discussions about the memorial's symbolism although books inevitably speak of the histories and stories of their time. Conceived almost six years ago the Holocaust Memorial cannot be considered a new work by the artist and she is not, she has said, in the memorial business. Yet the Vienna memorial will undoubtedly enhance her international reputation as an artist of great seriousness, rigour and sensitivity.

Across the Judenplatz the statue of Gottfraim Lessing gesticulates. Whiteread's building does not invite a dialogue with the statue nor with the buildings on the square nor with the remains of the 15th century synagogue, beautifully displayed in it's own subterranean vault beneath the square.

The memorial's uncomfortable unapologetic presence has a certain grandeur. It is a reminder enough of its meanings. The building's emphatic muteness and silence is the appropriate response to the enormity of its subject.

It will not disappear into forgetfulness or the every day. It is a place where memories happen.

Whiteread's building does not invite a dialogue with the statue nor with the buildings on the square nor with the remains of the 15th century synagogue, beautifully displayed in it's own subterranean vault beneath the square. The memorial's uncomfortable unapologetic presence has a certain grandeur. It is a reminder enough of its meanings. The building's emphatic muteness and silence is the appropriate response to the enormity of its subject. It will not disappear into forgetfulness or the every day. It is a place where memories happen.

fields.headline: Rita, Sue.../A State Affair
fields.standfirst:
Everyman, Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Everyman, Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Theatre becomes urgent, relevant and absolutely crucial in this double bill of plays. Both are set on Bradford's Buttershaw estate, one of Britain's deprived housing schemes, wracked over the past 40 years by unemployment, poverty and cheap heroin.

In Buttershaw you find what right-wing sociologist Charles Murray calls "the underclass"; in reality, struggling single mums trying to bring up their kids decently on no money, no hope and in the absence of men who have become redundant in every sense. As Mum says in Rita, Sue and Bob Too, written in 1982 by the then 21-year-old Andrea Dunbar: "Anyway, all men are no good. They want shooting for all the trouble they cause." There was something prophetic in those words.

Rita, Sue and Bob Too was the second of three plays that Dunbar wrote before a fatal brain haemorrhage at 29. This grim little comedy about two 15-year-old girls' affair with the same married man, was one from the heart. She only wrote about what she knew. Max Stafford Clark, then director of the Royal Court, commissioned the play and now revives it and pairs it with a new work, A State Affair by Robin Soans. Soans's play is a piece of verbatim theatre created via interviews with people who live in Buttershaw today.

If, for all its mouthy, larky high spirits, Rita Sue and Bob Too has a hard-boiled desperate edge, A State Affair is like falling down a deep, dark well. It depicts a war zone where the front line consists of people struggling with understated heroism to hold their lives together and deal with the consequences of addiction, child abuse, domestic violence and lack of hope.

On its own, either play would have impact. Together, they cannot be ignored. One springs from the other. That was then and this is now. A State Affair ends poignantly with Dunbar's own daughter, Lorraine, a former drug addict, being given voice: "If my mum wrote the play now, Rita and Sue would be smackheads on crack as well... and working the red light districts, sleeping with everybody and anybody for money."

Max Stafford Clark's production is matter of fact, unobtrusive and best of all, honest. So are the performances. It never lets you forget that, in reality, there are people on the Buttershaw estate who are living this piece of theatre every day.

 Until November 4. Box office: 0151-709 4776. Then tours to Oxford, Colchester, Plymouth, Eastbourne, London, Bradford and Manchester.

fields.headline: DTI starts best buy drive
fields.standfirst:
Utilities and banks come next in Byers' campaign to give consumers better deal

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Department of Trade and Industry is poised to launch a "consumer friendly" drive to make it easier for people to switch between utility companies and banks.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry is poised to launch a "consumer friendly" drive to make it easier for people to switch between utility companies and banks.

The wide-ranging initative could see league tables for the "best buys" in different consumer markets which might name the cheapest supplier, for instance, in the gas market.

Ministers are also expected to issue new guidelines to industries which would make it easier for customers to swap from one service provider to another.

The move is expected to affect a wide range of businesses - from the provision of electricity, gas and telephone lines into millions of homes as well as access to bank accounts and insurance policies.

The DTI decided to act after detailed research showed that while consumers say they are prepared to take their business elsewhere, they often end up deciding it would be simpler to stay with their existing provider. The research was conducted on the instruction of Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and intended to give the first real insight into what motivates consumers to switch their supplier and what deters them.

The research has tried to touch on a wide range of consumer habits and comes at time when gas and electricity suppliers are scrambling to persuade consumers to allow just one provider of these major utilities into their home.

In the financial sector, it follows the controversial Cruickshank inquiry into competition among the banks and a decision by the industry to make it easier for customers to move their current accounts, a market dominated by the "big four" - NatWest, Lloyds TSB, Barclays and HSBC.

From next year the major banks have agreed to automate details of direct debits from current accounts and exchange the information with each other. The move is seen as an attempt to counter claims that such difficulties have deterred customers from moving.

Statisticians in the financial industry claim that people are more likely to divorce than move their current account, although the major banking groups stress that they do not behave in a way which deliberately makes it difficult for customers to leave them.

City sources were last night concerned that the DTI intended to embark on a "naming and shaming" exercise to try to pin the blame on certain companies for making it difficult for customers to move.

The DTI is expected to try to persuade suppliers that the research contains data crucial to their business which will make it easier for them to take customers away from rivals.

Sources say the research has involved a detailed analysis of each industry. So, for instance, in financial services, the analysis has scrutinised consumers' attitudes towards moving not only their current account but also their mortgage and insurance policy. The research findings could be released as soon as next week.

fields.headline: Danilo Perez
fields.standfirst:
Ronnie Scott's, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Ronnie Scott's, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Danilo Perez, the Panamanian pianist, sounds like a character out of the Dr Seuss children's books. And it's true, he does seem a big kid at heart. "This is like walking into a dream," he beamed, opening his first ever set at Ronnie Scott's, a cute little hat perched on his head.

He had scaled down the party from the 18-strong combo of Motherland, his latest album, to the Motherland Project: the pure voice of Luciana Souza, Donny McCaslin on the saxophone, flute and clarinet, Adam Cruz on drums and the bassist Essiet Essiet.

Perez is used to supplying support to the stars but here he got a chance to show his mettle as a leader on stage and did so generously.

It was a night of infectious enthusiasm which began with a tamborito vibe introduced, disarmingly, by Perez playing a solo harmelodica (one of those blow-pianos).

Souza entered the tune on triangle and Perez wove in snatches of that old school assembly chestnut God is Love. Once the groove was launched, he went back to the piano in search of gaps in the rhythm, establishing a push-pull pattern against Cruz with a combination of montunos, arpeggio and unison melody that grounded the set and sustained a kaleidoscope of tempo changes.

His musicians had a relaxed, though not casual, approach which lent an unfinished, wistful quality to their sound. Souza, for example, mirrored McCaslin in several places but used her voice onomatopoeically, coming and going, haunting the tune rather than singing it. In other places she was commanding, her Middle Eastern tonality reminiscent of a call to prayer.

Perez meanwhile jumped back and forth between piano, Gershwinesque harmelodica and the odd clap, diverting applause into percussive subtlety with a brio that brought a smile to our faces.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: Phoenix
fields.standfirst:
Dingwalls, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Dingwalls, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Phoenix know what they like and while following in Prince's diminutive footsteps is not only unwise but uncredible, Thomas Mars isn't going to let anything stop him. Singer, chief show-off and heart and soul of Phoenix, Mars is yelping and falsettoing all over the place, standing on the drum riser with one hand gripping his microphone, the other thrown skyward, flying in the face of fashion.

But then his easy vocals, by turns full of Californian sunshine and as soulful as Stevie Wonder, already surprise, because Mars, along with the rest of Phoenix, is French. And while the French are now known for their laidback dance wizardry alongside their fine wines, it's rare to find a bunch of musicians who can evoke the Minneapolis genius at his finest one second and the Eagles the next. But whatever the genre, you can be sure it dates from the decade that taste forgot - the 1980s.

United, the band's debut album, is made up of ultra-cool homages to bands you would never admit to loving; it should be an ironic joke, a nod back to the last century with a grin on its face. That the Van Halen riffs and Chicago melodies at this concert add up to such exciting yet heartwarming songs that are always achingly hip is proof of Phoenix's power.

Tearing into School's Rules, Phoenix's guitars rock, while the bass is so heavy it hurts. But they don't look like metalheads. With their grown-out pudding bowl haircuts, shirts and ties, they look like a bunch of sixth-formers, storming the stage straight from the school gates.

Mars, with the gait of a young Mick Jagger and the twitchiness of an Iggy Pop, is unable to contain himself, and shakes his head madly. His singing is sublime; whether raging on the Supergrass-like Party Time or tender on Honeymoon, it's the glue that holds the band's diverse styles together.

And then there's the funk. Tonight there's a keyboard player whose voice recalls early rap. Mars commands us to clap as If I Ever Feel Better begins; with its Owner of a Lonely Heart bassline, the party atmosphere grows. But while their own material shines, a cover of Prince's Forever in My Life allows Phoenix to rise above their contemporaries.

As Mars sings a cappella, in a straight rendition of a classic, sung with awe, we all sing along, blissfully engaged in a moment of mutual affection.

fields.headline: Birmingham Rep's Hindu epic
fields.standfirst:
Ramayana
Birmingham Rep
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Ramayana
Birmingham Rep
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Epics are everywhere. No sooner have I recovered from Denver's 12-hour Tantalus than I am confronted by this new version of the legendary Sanskrit saga. Far from being a show for specialists it turns out, in Peter Oswald's adaptation and Indhu Rubasingham's production, to be a witty and inventive piece of popular theatre that clearly delighted a large, multiracial audience.

Coming fresh to the story, what instantly struck me was its blend of the spiritual and the secular. Rama, an earthly incarnation of the Hindu god Vishnu, gives up his regal claims and goes into voluntary exile for 14 years with his bride, Sita, and his brother Lakshman. But Sita is abducted from their forest home by the 10-headed demon Ravana. The bulk of the story concerns a quest by the two princes to recover Sita, with the aid of an army of monkey people, from her captivity in the island kingdom of Lanka.

On one level it is an adventure story, but the basic themes are universal: sacrifice, fidelity, sexual and fraternal love, the conflict of good and evil. And what is impressive about Oswald's version is the way it captures both the story's Hindu origins and its cross-cultural appeal. When, for instance, the recovered Sita offers to submit to death by fire to prove her sexual constancy we are in a world that many people may find alien. But Rama's final argument that victory over his enemies lies in mercy and that even lost souls shall return to heaven taps into the charity and forgiveness that lies at the heart of all religion.

If the narrative leaps lightly over east-west barriers so, too, does Rubasingham's production, which is characterised by its merry eclecticism.

Her designer, Ultz, uses silken saffron canopies to note princely grandeur and free-wheeling office stools to convey the demons' war council. And the whole show is a mixture of what Peter Brook called holy and rough theatre. Dangling ropes become trees, a temptress sports Madonna-style cone breasts, a bridge is built out of drinks crates and in the interval the leaping actor-monkeys invade the auditorium and filch our worldly toys including, I was particularly pleased to see, someone's mobile phone.

In an age of parsimony it is also astonishing to see 21 actors and two musicians on stage. From a vast company, I would single out Gerald Kyd as a stately, turquoise Rama, Andrew French as the rapacious Ravana, Miltos Yerolemou as a hairy, Pan-like simian and Charlotte Bicknell, who has a remarkable capacity to stay in character while dangling upside down from a rope. Erratic lighting aside, this is a totally charming show that gives us access to an Indian classic and combines uplifting spiritual odyssey with old-fashioned magic that comes straight out of provincial panto.

 Until November 11. Box office: 0121-236 4455.

fields.headline: Toddler tantrums at the Lilian Baylis
fields.standfirst:
Sasha Pepelyaev
Lilian Baylis Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Sasha Pepelyaev
Lilian Baylis Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Any small dance company growing up in St Petersburg must want to kick hard against the monolithic influence of the Kirov Ballet, which has dominated that city's dance culture for over 200 years - and Sasha Pepelyaev's Kinetic Theatre certainly do a lot of kicking. In the double bill that they've been presenting in London this week (their second visit since they formed in 1994), the group's five dancers frequently behave like truculent toddlers - lying on the floor and screaming, refusing stubbornly to move and disrupting phrases of grown-up dance with furiously ungracious moves.

This mix of serious and subversive, athletic and absurd is obviously part of Pepelyaev's quest to invent new choreographic strategies within the predominantly classical Russian scene. So while his company members are all, visibly, ballet-trained, their vocabulary features traces of American post-modernism and expressionist new European dance. It also plays with a style of surreal clowning familiar to UK audiences from Slava's Snow Show (Slava was, in fact, in the audience on opening night).

In the first piece, Not There, the clowning is mostly embodied in the surly, trampish figure of Pepelyaev himself, who either rants commands at the four other dancers, or rumbles a hoarse running commentary to his own slapstick moves. The dancers respond in bursts of compliantly graceful choreography or in fits of obsessive housework - wiping the chairs lined up in a corner of the stage. Sometimes they resist altogether, smooth, gentle faces distorted by howls and whimpers.

While this alternation between anarchy and precision sparks some pleasing discordances (I liked the painted backdrop of an audience whose cardboard hands break into clockwork applause like a flock of birds), there is no focus to its lunacy. Pepelyaev gives us no clues about the fantasy world he thinks his dancers are inhabiting.

However, the score's musical collage of Italian opera, Latin dance music and Spanish smooch cues steps that deftly parody those genres. These we understand, and the performers prove as likable as comedians as they are as dancers. But overall, the evening leaves us with the sense of a company so locked into their private jokes and preoccupations that they have stopped noticing whether anyone else is listening.

webTitle: HIV father wins human rights asylum case

fields.headline: HIV father wins human rights asylum case
fields.standfirst:
Special report: human rights in the UK

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: An HIV victim from Colombia, jailed for causing grievous bodily harm and possessing drugs, yesterday won the right under the Human Rights Act to stay in Britain pending the outcome of his ex-partner's application for asylum.
fields.body:
An HIV victim from Colombia, jailed for causing grievous bodily harm and possessing drugs, yesterday won the right under the Human Rights Act to stay in Britain pending the outcome of his ex-partner's application for asylum.

A high court judge ruled that to deport the father of three, who has been refused asylum himself, while his children remained in Britain, would create a serious risk of breaching his right to respect for family life under article 8 of the European convention on human rights.

The case is among the first of an expected barrage of challenges under the convention, now incorporated into domestic law by the Human Rights Act.

The man, named only as R, sought judicial review of a Home Office decision last summer to send him back to Colombia following his release from prison after serving 18-months for grievous bodily harm and a concurrent eight weeks for drink-driving and possession of drugs.

He has suffered a number of Aids-related illnesses since being diagnosed as HIV positive in 1995 and is undergoing treatment at a London hospital.

Mr Justice Gage said the home secretary was entitled to take into account criminal convictions when deciding whether to allow asylum seekers to enter or remain in Britain. Buthe must take into account convention rights and not act in a way which was "disproportionate". To remove R because of his criminal convictions "would seem to me disproportionate".

R, in his thirties, had been in Britain for more than seven years and his youngest child was born here. He was still in close contact with his children.

The mother of his children, from whom he is separated, launched her own claim for asylum three years ago.

The couple, who were not married, arrived in Britain together in April 1993.

The immigration authorities had expressed concern that the family could "string out" their stay in the UK by making sequential applications for asylum, but the judge made it clear proper regard had to be paid to convention rights.

He said of the ex-partner's asylum claim: "It seems to me that if she were given permission to remain in this country there is a serious risk that to remove him would be a breach of his rights under article 8 of the convention."

However, her application remained outstanding and the probability was that she and the children would not be allowed to stay. In that case there would be no convention breach in R's case, said the judge.

He dismissed R's application for judicial review on condition the Home Office undertook not to enforce R's deportation until his ex-partner's application was determined.

The Refugee Legal Centre had unsuccessfully applied to the immigration authorities for R to be allowed exceptional leave to remain in the country because of his HIV.

The judge rejected R's claim that he would face death within a matter of months if he was sent back to Colombia because he would not be able to obtain effective treatment for HIV in his home country.

His counsel, James Gillespie, had argued that his right to life would be threatened and that deportation would involve inhumane and degrading treatment, contrary to articles 2 and 3 of the convention.

The judge ruled there would be no violation of those rights because there was evidence he would be able to obtain proper treatment in Colombia.

A high court judge ruled that to deport the father of three, who has been refused asylum himself, while his children remained in Britain, would create a serious risk of breaching his right to respect for family life under article 8 of the European convention on human rights. The case is among the first of an expected barrage of challenges under the convention, now incorporated into domestic law by the Human Rights Act. The man, named only as R, sought judicial review of a Home Office decision last summer to send him back to Colombia following his release from prison after serving 18-months for grievous bodily harm and a concurrent eight weeks for drink-driving and possession of drugs. He has suffered a number of Aids-related illnesses since being diagnosed as HIV positive in 1995 and is undergoing treatment at a London hospital. Mr Justice Gage said the home secretary was entitled to take into account criminal convictions when deciding whether to allow asylum seekers to enter or remain in Britain. Buthe must take into account convention rights and not act in a way which was "disproportionate". To remove R because of his criminal convictions "would seem to me disproportionate". R, in his thirties, had been in Britain for more than seven years and his youngest child was born here. He was still in close contact with his children. The mother of his children, from whom he is separated, launched her own claim for asylum three years ago. The couple, who were not married, arrived in Britain together in April 1993. The immigration authorities had expressed concern that the family could "string out" their stay in the UK by making sequential applications for asylum, but the judge made it clear proper regard had to be paid to convention rights. He said of the ex-partner's asylum claim: "It seems to me that if she were given permission to remain in this country there is a serious risk that to remove him would be a breach of his rights under article 8 of the convention." However, her application remained outstanding and the probability was that she and the children would not be allowed to stay. In that case there would be no convention breach in R's case, said the judge. He dismissed R's application for judicial review on condition the Home Office undertook not to enforce R's deportation until his ex-partner's application was determined. The Refugee Legal Centre had unsuccessfully applied to the immigration authorities for R to be allowed exceptional leave to remain in the country because of his HIV. The judge rejected R's claim that he would face death within a matter of months if he was sent back to Colombia because he would not be able to obtain effective treatment for HIV in his home country. His counsel, James Gillespie, had argued that his right to life would be threatened and that deportation would involve inhumane and degrading treatment, contrary to articles 2 and 3 of the convention. The judge ruled there would be no violation of those rights because there was evidence he would be able to obtain proper treatment in Colombia.

fields.headline: This is personal
fields.standfirst: Her own experience of inequity set Maggie Smith, of Barnardo's, on her career
fields.trailText: Profile: Her own experience of inequity set Maggie Smith, of Barnardo's, on her career.
fields.body:
From her desk at the Essex headquarters of Barnardo's, Maggie Smith oversees a small army of 3,000 staff and 15,000 volunteers. Her role as children's services manager gives her the ear of government and a key role shaping support for Britain's poorest, most disadvantaged youngsters.

But when Smith looks back on a 30-year career, it is her first and smallest project that she describes as "probably the best thing I ever did". Newly estranged from her first husband, with no home, no furniture, and two small boys under five, she was one of a handful of lone parents in the West Yorkshire mill town of Keighley who, in 1972, founded a local Gingerbread group and the district's first modern childcare facility.

That centre, Kiddicare, is still going, with Smith, now 53, as life president. And it was the experience of setting it up that launched her on her crusading course, dedicated to child welfare and social justice. "It wasn't really a planned career," she says. "I got involved with Keighley Gingerbread in desperation."

Her first marriage ended abruptly and unhappily. She quit the family home in Bradford with her two sons and "began to read and understand about social policy for the first time in my life". Very soon, she was stung by the injustice of it all.

"If it wasn't for my parents, my children might have ended up in care," she recalls. "Remember Cathy Come Home? You had very few rights in those days. The police wouldn't intervene in cases of domestic violence - restraining injunctions didn't exist. You'd lose your furniture, absolutely everything you ever owned.

"I was catapulted into poverty and homelessness. My circumstances had suddenly got a whole lot worse - my marriage had ended and I was homeless - but the council wouldn't house me, their rule then was that they put a six months 'stay' on your points, to prevent lone parents trying to jump the housing queue. Their argument was that you might go back to the family home. So even if your points shot up, as mine did, there was a six month period before they would take it into account."

Smith was lucky: she could fall back on her parents, and their "respectable" working class home at Boston Spa, near Wetherby. But there was still the tut-tutting of elderly people in the queue at the post office while she stood in line waiting for her giro. "At that time, the media focused on lone parents wanting more benefits, when the actual picture was that we wanted help to work."

After landing a housing association tenancy in Bradford, she found her nurse training was next to useless. Shift working was out of the question with two children. Things changed when she got in touch with Gingerbread, the lone parent network.

"I contacted Gingerbread - I had seen someone talking about it on TV - and said: 'Where's my nearest group? I need help.' There were eight or 10 other lone parents, some in even worse states than me. There was a slow realisation that if we helped each other, we could actually survive much better, and try to lobby locally."

They lobbied loudly and in the end, in classic early-70s fashion, the unlikely group did it themselves. A social worker's tip-off led them to a Keighley mill nursery which was due to close. Mill nurseries had been a common feature in Lancashire and Yorkshire, but the companies were closing them rapidly to avoid the 1974 health and safety regulations.

"Five of us went in to see social services," Smith recalls. "We really didn't know what employing people - we eventually employed eight people - would be like. All we knew was we had nothing to lose. But we had some horrendous times."

As well as Smith, there were three other young mums, and Noel, a father of four, widowed when his wife died of a brain haemorrhage on their youngest baby's first birthday. He was the most politically aware of the group. "He would go to the library and get out government reports," says Smith. "We'd read bits of it and get even more angry - we became very bolshie. We learned our politics the hard way, when we came up against bureaucracy."

That learning process culminated in heated exchanges, and even threats of jail, when the childcare centre was adjudged to be operating without a registration certificate. Behind the acrimony, thinks Smith, was resentment on the part of the welfare establishment. "They were angry that this rank group of amateurs, lone parents on benefit, should take on something so complex," she says.

"I'm proud that Kiddicare is still flourishing. It's helped 20,000 lone parents in 25 years, and is still managed by the parents. I go back from time to time - I still think it's probably the best thing I ever did."

It was, however, just the beginning of a career fighting for children's rights. Smith was recruited to Gingerbread's staff, first in Keighley and then in London, and subsequently went into local government in Bradford and Manchester. After a couple of years in higher education, she joined Barnardo's in 1998.

What attracted her to the charity was its work with children and young people right on the margins - the ones that other agencies had given up on. "Barnardo's has a commitment to social justice for all children. It's the most inspiring work I've ever seen," she says.

webTitle: Amnesty hires Borkowski for anniversary bash

fields.headline: Amnesty hires Borkowski for anniversary bash
fields.trailText: 8am: Amnesty International has hired Borkowski PR to handle its 40th anniversary celebrations next year, the first time the human rights organisation has hired an outside agency for such a major task. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Amnesty International has hired Borkowski PR to handle its 40th anniversary celebrations next year, marking the first time the human rights organisation has hired an outside agency for such a major task.

Borkowski PR, whose clients range from Bacardi Breezer to Sir Cliff Richard, won the task after a competitive pitch.

It has previously created PR campaigns for the UN children's charity, Unicef, and for Jubilee 2000, the charity lobbying for the cancellation of third world debt.

Amnesty is keeping details of the celebrations under wraps until the beginning of next year, but is understood to be planning an ambitious line-up of events across the world.

Andy Hackman, fundraising manager for Amnesty, acknowledged that hiring Borkowski PR marked a departure from the organisation's usual practice of handling all its publicity in-house, but said that the scale of the operation had made it necessary to look outside.

He said: "We chose them because they came up with some very good ideas about how we can get our new message across. We want to use the celebrations to reconvey what Amnesty International is about. While our central message is still about freedom and justice, we also have to adapt to the changes that are going on in the world."

webTitle: Government drive to attract more ethnic minorities to nursing

fields.headline: Government drive to attract more ethnic minorities to nursing
fields.standfirst: The NHS should be more representative of the communities it serves.
fields.trailText: The government has announced a drive to attract more people from Asian and other ethnic minority backgrounds into the NHS and in particular into nursing, including setting recruitment targets in areas where they are under-represented.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
The government will today announce a drive to attract more people from Asian and other ethnic minority backgrounds into the NHS and in particular into nursing, including setting recruitment targets in areas where they are under-represented.

Health minister John Denham, announcing the strategy at the end of a summit on ethnic minorities working in the NHS, will say the health service needs to be representative of the communities it serves.

But there is also an urgent need for the government to find ways of tackling the acute shortages in nursing.

The government pledged to swell the numbers of nurses and midwives by 20,000 by 2004.

In the NHS as a whole, proportions of people from ethnic minorities are broadly in line with those in the general working population.

But there is particular under-representation of Asian people in nursing, the Department of Health says.

While they make up 4% of the general working population, in nursing they are only 1.4%. Only 1.6% of students from nursing degree courses are from Asian backgrounds.

The Royal College of Nursing believes there is a problem of institutionalised racism. Bradford University has looked at the reasons why Asian students are under-represented on healthcare courses and found some cultural issues, such as women's reluctance to nurse men and men regarding nursing as a woman's job.

There is also a negative attitude from parents who consider the pay and status of nurses as too low.

Mr Denham will say today that he is "determined to tackle whatever obstacles there are which prevent Asian staff from joining the NHS or reaching their full career potential within it."

The package of measures to be announced by the government include requiring all NHS organisations to set targets for the recruitment of staff from Asian, black and other minority ethnic backgrounds in areas where they are currently under-represented.

But people from ethnic minorities also need to be attracted onto educational courses that can prepare them for a job in the NHS.

Mr Denham will announce that he has agreed with the Committee of Vice Chancellors and Principals on a number of measures to ensure that dis crimination does not prevent people from taking healthcare degrees.

The higher education sector will work with government to identify any barriers to black and ethnic minority students gaining places on courses, monitor the situation and find solutions to any problems that are uncovered.

The government has already set targets for senior NHS management. By 2004 at least 7% of executive directors must be from Asian, black or other ethnic minority backgrounds.

webTitle: Inquiry into Israel's use of UK arms

fields.headline: Inquiry into Israel's use of UK arms
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The government is to investigate whether British equipment has been used in Israeli helicopter attacks on Palestinians, official sources said last night.
fields.body:
The government is to investigate whether British equipment has been used in Israeli helicopter attacks on Palestinians, official sources said last night.

The future of arms sales to Israel is also being considered, the sources said.

Amnesty International yesterday called on the government to suspend all exports of any components for US Apache helicopters until Israel showed they would not be used to breach human rights.

Whitehall last year licensed the sale of unidentified components to Israel for combat helicopters plus other equipment including "small arms ammunition", says the government's latest annual report on strategic export controls.

It is thought that Israel denied British equipment had been used although Whitehall admits it is hard to discover where such equipment ends up.

Amnesty, which has also called on Washington to halt arms sales to Israel, said Israeli forces had used US-supplied helicopter gunships "to violate the human rights of Palestinians in punitive attacks on civilians" and "where there was no imminent danger to life".

Lethal force can only be used if there is imminent danger to life and if force cannot be avoided to protect life, said Amnesty. It said Israel had made clear that missiles fired on October 12 were not used to protect lives but in response to the killing of two soldiers.

webTitle: Settlers' return feeds fire of Arab rage

fields.headline: Settlers' return feeds fire of Arab rage
fields.standfirst:
Exploiting the disarray of Israeli politicians, an incendiary land claim is reasserted

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The two caravans perched on a windswept desert peak lie two miles from the nearest living soul, but yesterday they stood squarely in the maelstrom that has savaged Israel and the Palestinians.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Mitzpeh Hagit, West Bank
fields.body:
The two caravans perched on a windswept desert peak lie two miles from the nearest living soul, but yesterday they stood squarely in the maelstrom that has savaged Israel and the Palestinians.

The return of Shimon and Chaya Ben Dor to this Jewish settlement - population eight adults and four children - promises to further stoke Palestinian rage, after a month of blood and mayhem that has seen more than 120 Arabs die.

The government evacuated the illegal outpost last year, but the Ben Dors said yesterday that their return to the caravans, guarded by three large, barking dogs and two armed sentries, had the full sanction of the prime minister, Ehud Barak - though among Israeli officials yesterday there was confusion about this.

Whether these settlers have Mr Barak's blessing or not, a Palestinian official warned that new additions to the 145 Jewish settlements in the West Bank could inflame feelings that are very hot already.

"This is an indication of the real intentions of the Barak government," Ziad Abu Zayyad said. "At such times of tension, of emotion, we need efforts to bring the parties to trust each other again and not such radical actions that pull the sides apart."

Later in the day, Palestinian cabinet ministers declared that Israel was trying to get "by force and attacks, what it cannot get through negotiations".

Mr Barak, meanwhile, was intensifying efforts to form an emergency government with the man most reviled by the Arab world, Israel's hawkish leader of the Likud party, Ariel Sharon.

For the Palestinians, Mr Barak's courting of their enemy, coupled with his harsh pronouncements against their leader, Yasser Arafat, and his declaration of a "time out" in the peace process, are clear signals that he is now in no mood to talk peace.

The sanctioning of the Ben Dors' Mitzpe Hagit settlement, which lies between Jericho and Jerusalem, is just further confirmation.

But Mr Sharon is proving resistant to the Barak blandishments. Yesterday, he repeated his demand for a large share of cabinet portfolios for his followers in the Likud, and a say over future peace negotiations.

His posture may well harden more, if he thinks this is needed to stave off a leadership challenge from the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu.

Yesterday, Mr Netanyahu told Israel Radio he believed the Likud should steer clear of a national unity government with Mr Barak's Labour party. Netanyahu loyalists in Likud have also tried to stop Mr Sharon from sealing the deal.

As this political standoff continued among the Israelis, clashes in the West Bank and Gaza yesterday were doused by the arrival of heavy winter rains, which kept demonstrators from the barricades. Even so, at least two Palestinians were killed in Gaza, and another man was shot dead in his home overnight in the West Bank town of Hebron.

Israel remains on edge after another night of gunfire on Gilo, built on occupied land on the southern edges of Jerusalem. "If the Palestinians will not stop firing, we will have to stop it, and it will require a massive operation," said Jerusalem's mayor, Ehud Olmert. "It will cost them dearly."

In such an atmosphere, the return of the Ben Dors to Mitzpeh Hagit is loaded with meaning. "It sends a very clear message to the Palestinians that we are claiming a part of the West Bank. It is the same message as unilateral separation: that the Palestinians better be prepared to make a peace that doesn't include large parts of the West Bank," said Jeff Halper, an Israeli peace activist.

That view suits the family just fine. Although Mrs Ben Dor says she wanted her four children to grow up in a pristine environment, and argues that in planting ficus and carob trees she is in communion with the desert, she admits her presence at Mitzpe Hagit is extremely political.

"We would not come and live here, if we did not believe this is Israel and should be part of Israel forever and ever."

The outposts are envisaged as a chain of settlements that would outflank Palestinian villages along the road from Arab East Jerusalem to the West Bank city of Ramallah, and would bolster existing isolated settlements, which Mr Barak was prepared to abandon at his Camp David negotiations with Mr Arafat last July. Last year, when Mr Barak came to power promising to make peace with the Palestinians, he declared 42 such settlements illegal. But in the months since then, Israeli bureaucrats have given the green light to nearly all of the settlements.

If Mr Sharon joins the government, the settlers can expand their ambitions even more. The Likud leader is a vigorous proponent of keeping large "security zones" in the Jordan valley, along with all settlements in the West Bank.

webTitle: Sinn Fein will be told to fly the flag

fields.headline: Sinn Fein will be told to fly the flag
fields.standfirst:
New regulation seen as gesture of support to Trimble
                                                  who faces hardline unionist calls to withdraw from
                                                  power-sharing executive
fields.trailText:
Sinn Fein ministers in Northern Ireland are to be forced to fly the
                                                  union flag over their departments, the government announced
                                                  yesterday in an attempt to shore up the position of David Trimble
                                                  ahead of a crunch meeting of the Ulster Unionist council on
                                                  Saturday.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein ministers in Northern Ireland are to be forced to fly the union flag over their departments, the government announced yesterday in an attempt to shore up the position of David Trimble ahead of a crunch meeting of the Ulster Unionist council on Saturday.

MPs will pass a regulation in the Commons this week which will ensure that the flag flies over the departments run by Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun on Remembrance Sunday next month and on the birthday of the Prince of Wales two days later.

Sinn Fein, which said that its ministers should not be forced to work in a British environment, angrily rejected the government announcement.

Alex Maskey, the party's chief whip, said that he would seek legal advice, adding: "Peter Mandelson has to get the message that nationalists are not second class citizens."

Government sources yesterday played down the timing of the announcement, saying that the issue needed to be resolved ahead of Remembrance Sunday. But there was little doubt that Mr Mandelson has offered an important concession to the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble ahead of Saturday's meeting of his party's ruling council.

Hardline unionists have called the meeting in an attempt to force Mr Trimble to withdraw from Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive in protest at what they claim is the slow progress on disarmament by the IRA.

There is speculation that Mr Trimble will hang on as first minister, but at the risk of damage to the peace process. It is understood that the UUP leader may appease his critics by setting a deadline for the IRA to begin the actual process of decommissioning, hardening his position. Hardline unionists have dismissed the international inspection of IRA arms as unsatisfactory.

Downing Street said that the announcement was not linked to Saturday's meeting. The prime minister's spokesman said that Mr Mandelson had used his powers because the Northern Ireland assembly had been unable to reach agreement on the flags issue.

"We recognise this won't satisfy any one side completely but we believe it's a practical solution which steers a course through a difficult problem," the spokesman said. Under the regulation, the union flag will have to fly at full mast over selected buildings on 17 days of the year. These include obscure celebrations such as the birthday of the Countess of Wessex.

The government last month cut the number of flag days in Northern Ireland by four, as a gesture to the nationalists, bringing the province into line with the rest of the United Kingdom. This means union flags no longer fly over official buildings on July 12, the day of Orange Order celebrations. Government sources tried to reassure republicans last night by saying that the flag would not fly over any individual departments.

Rathgael House in Bangor, which is one of the buildings named in the regulation, houses both Mr McGuinness's education department and the finance department run by the SDLP. Although the government said that it did not have Saturday's meeting in mind when it drew up the flags regulation, Mr Mandelson made clear yesterday that he was determined to ensure Mr Trimble survives. Speaking in the loyalist Shankill area of Belfast, Mr Mandelson said that Mr Trimble was "indispensable".
