webTitle: After 50 years as MP, Sir Edward sails into the sunset

fields.headline: After 50 years as MP, Sir Edward sails into the sunset
fields.trailText: The former Conservative prime minister Sir Edward Heath , who became          Father of the House of Commons, last night ended intense speculation          about his future and announced his retirement as an MP after more than 50          years at Westminster.
fields.body:
The former Conservative prime minister Sir Edward Heath , who became Father of the House of Commons, last night ended intense speculation about his future and announced his retirement as an MP after more than 50 years at Westminster.

His letter to party activists in Old Bexley and Sidcup prompted a flood of tributes to the politician who took a wary Britain into Europe in 1973 - hoping in vain that he had finally settled the country's post-imperial destiny.

Instead, the man who had drastically reformed trade union law suddenly fell from power over a miners' strike. Ousted by Margaret Thatcher in a Palace of Westminster coup in 1975, he resorted to one of the longest sulks in public life over his treatment by her.

As the former prime minister (1970-74) last night flew out of London to visit Japan and China - where he is held in very high regard as a friend - Tony Blair spoke of his "outstanding contribution" and political courage.

William Hague said he would be "greatly missed" while Michael Heseltine likened his European achievements to victory in the second world war.

But Lady Thatcher, whom Sir Edward regularly denounced for 25 years, made no immediate statement.

Though he aroused fierce loyalty among Europhile Tories like Mr Heseltine and Kenneth Clarke, Sir Edward was seen as a "traitor" and "virtually a socialist" by Thatcherite Tories.

To them Europe and economic pragmatism were his great crimes.

The decision by Sir Edward, 84, to step down at the coming general election - which had been widely predicted but never quite believed - came the day after he presided over a seven-hour process to elect Labour's Michael Martin as new Speaker of the Commons.

Like much else in his career, Sir Edward's handling of the election had provoked both praise and criticism, much of it from MPs on both sides, who argued that he should have used his authority to change the rules - and get the 12-candidate election over with in two quick ballots.

Last night he stressed that the timing of his decision had nothing to do with that controversy, but was tied to Conservative HQ's deadline of November 1 for older members to state their intentions for the coming election.

In 1997 the amateur yachtsman and musician - who conducted great orchestras - had a majority of 3,569 (6.9%) over Labour, which will now try to seize the seat.

Sir Edward's 50 years of unbroken service as an MP fell short of David Lloyd George's 54 years and that of his hero, Sir Winston Churchill, who served 62 years in all. Like Sir Edward, Churchill, who stayed an MP until he was 89, also rejected a peerage. In the 50s, Sir Edward had been one of Churchill's rising young stars.

Colleagues at Westminster had said that Sir Edward's constituency activists hoped he would quit, but did not want to hurt his feelings by asking. He was still busy locally and yesterday Barry Fowler, his Bexley secretary, called him a "national and international politician who never once forgot his constituents".

Beset by European problems of his own, Mr Blair struck a more ambiguous note.

"It was Sir Edward who took this country into the European community and he can be justly proud of that. Whether you agree with his views or not, no one is ever in any doubt what they are," he said.

webTitle: Enrolment of minorities on health courses to be studied

fields.headline: Enrolment of minorities on health courses to be studied
fields.trailText: University chiefs and NHS officials are launching a joint research project into the enrolment of students from ethnic minorities on medical, nursing, and healthcare degree courses. The project was announced by health minister John Denham during today's summit on the recruitment and retention of black and minority ethnic staff in the NHS.
fields.body:
University chiefs and NHS officials are launching a joint research project into the enrolment of students from ethnic minorities on medical, nursing, and healthcare degree courses. The project was announced by health minister John Denham during today's summit on the recruitment and retention of black and minority ethnic staff in the NHS.

The project, which will monitor the trends in the participation of ethnic minority students on degree courses, and assess the factors that affect their recruitment, will support the efforts of the NHS to diversify the ethnic make-up of its staff.

Figures show that whilst the number of Asian, black and minority ethnic staff in the NHS as a whole reflects the general population, Asian people are often under-represented in nursing. Only 1.4% of nursing staff are Asian, compared with 4% of Asian people in the general working population. Only 1.6% of students on nursing degree courses are from Asian backgrounds.

The project aims to increase the number and spread of black and minority ethnic students on healthcare courses, in particular, on nursing and scientific courses. The nature and length of the study are yet to be finalised.

webTitle: IRA to allow second arms inspection

fields.headline: IRA to allow second arms inspection
fields.trailText: The IRA tonight announced it would permit further inspection of its secret arms dumps.
fields.body:
The IRA tonight announced it would permit further inspection of its secret arms dumps.

New talks with General John de Chastelain's Independent International Commission on Decommissioning (IICD) will also get under way, but only if the Provisionals are satisfied it will advance the peace process.

The statement said: "Because the British Government has yet to honour its undertakings, we have not resumed discussions with the IICD. Neither have we broken off contact.

"These actions announced by us today represent clear and irrefutable evidence of the IRA's commitment to a just and equitable peace settlement. The significance of these decisions should not be underestimated or undervalued."

No date was given for the second inspection of the weapons caches, hidden throughout Ireland and thought to hold as many as 1,700 weapons and two tons of Semtex explosives.

Northern Ireland security minister Adam Ingram welcomed the announcement, saying he expected a second inspection to take place.

He said: "This is clearly a very helpful step forward... I am sure that those who genuinely want to move towards full decommissioning will take great heart from this. Our view is, if they say they are going to do something, they deliver."

The pledge came as prime minister Tony Blair prepared to hold fresh talks in Belfast tomorrow with first minister David Trimble, his deputy Seamus Mallon and Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams.

Mr Trimble, due to attend a critical meeting of the Ulster Unionist party's ruling council this Saturday, is likely to come under pressure to withdraw from the power-sharing executive unless the IRA begin emptying their dumps soon.

Despite their pledge, the IRA have given no indication of a handover, pointing responsibility instead at the British government. The statement said: "The IRA are doing our best to enhance the peace process. This is not our responsibility alone. Others also must play their part. The political responsibility for advancing the current situation and making progress rests with the two governments, especially the British government."

The first inspection by Cyril Ramaphosa and Martti Ahtisaari took place last June, a month after the restoration of the power-sharing executive.

The statement added: "In many ways this re-inspection is more important than the first inspection."

fields.headline: New Media Markets round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 20
fields.trailText: October 20: ONdigital is in talks with video-on-demand companies about launching a video-on-demand service.
fields.body:
ONdigital is in talks with video-on-demand companies including Future TV and Video Networks about launching a video-on-demand service.

Last week's clearance of the Time Warner/AOL and Vivendi/Canal Plus and Seagram mergers clears the way for content distribution across multiple platforms.

Telewest's chief executive, Adam Singer, has said that the current video-on-demand model, where revenues are split between the content provider and the operator, will not work. He warns that providers of "high-value, significant content" will look more favourably on video on demand if they are given a higher share of revenue.

ONdigital has added 100,000 subscribers, despite increased churn.

fields.trailText: October 26: Air Miles' managing director, Judith Thorne, has quit after just five months.
fields.body:
Air Miles's managing director, Judith Thorne, has quit after just five months, raising questions about British Airways' future management of the Air Miles brand.

Carlton Interactive's chief executive, Rupert Miles, is quitting the organisation for a senior role at Reuters, the news and information group.

Weetabix is calling a review of it £17m media planning and buying account. The work is currently split between New PHD, Banks Hoggins O'Shea and Western.

Interbrew has appointed Iain Napier, chief executive of Bass Brewers, to head its UK business.

Sainsbury's is set to spend £6m on the launch of Taste the Difference, its new premium food range, in a bid to reach sales of £200m in its first year.

Royal Mail is to proceed with its investment in the Postal Preference Service, signalling a move into the lifestyle data sector.

EasyGroup is poised to appoint Starcom Motive and MediaVest to handle a £6m media planning and buying account for its comparison shopping site, easy.com.

Prudential is launching an interactive TV service on Telewest in its first move into digital interactive television.

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 26.
fields.trailText: October 26: Ericsson is reviewing its £100m global consumer ad account. It is understood to be unhappy with the latest Young & Rubicam campaign.
fields.body:
Mobile phone company Ericsson is reviewing its £100m global consumer advertising account. The company is understood to be unhappy with the latest Young & Rubicam ad campaign, which included the company's long-time brand message, "Make yourself heard."

Cadbury Trebor Bassett is launching a range of high-street cafes with a chocolate theme. Cafe-Cadbury is being tested in Bath and, if successful, is expected to roll out across the UK.

The BBC has scrapped plans to restructure its marketing department according to target groups following the resignation of marketing chief Matthew Bannister. The corporation will revert to marketing teams for each TV channel and radio station.

Gillette is launching a women's version of its Mach 3 razor. The launch will be backed by a multimillion pound global marketing push.

Seagram is gearing up for a global ad campaign to reposition its Martell cognac brand by targeting young consumers. The campaign has been created by TBWA Worldwide.

Dolland & Aitchison has raided rival chain Vision Express for its new marketing chief. Des Taylor, marketing director at Vision Express, will take on the new post of commercial director.

Clickmusic.co.uk, the search engine that specialises in music sites, is launching a consumer magazine in a deal with Virgin Megastores. The magazine will be offered free in-store.

Pharmaceuticals company Pharmacia is understood to be reviewing its £28m international Nicorette account. The business is currently held by DDB Worldwide.

webTitle: Blair launches online learning scheme for adults

fields.headline: Blair launches online learning scheme for adults
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair and education secretary David Blunkett today launched learndirect, a new online initiative that aims to give adult education a 21st century internet boost.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair and education secretary David Blunkett today launched learndirect, a new online initiative that aims to give adult education a 21st century internet boost.

The scheme allows learners to choose from a range of over 400 courses, most of which are available over the internet, in a wide range of areas, such as business, technology and other basic skills. More than 700 centres are also opening.

The initiative is being run by the University for Industry (UfI), a public-private partnership that has been created to promote and innovate within lifelong learning in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The learndirect scheme "represents a revolution in learning," said Mr Blunkett, who was speaking at an event to mark the opening of a learndirect centre in Stratford, East London, today.

"By grasping the opportunities of new technology, it offers a unique way of reaching more people in new and exciting ways and engaging them in learning to boost their own employability," he explained.

Dr Anne Wright, chief executive of UfI, said: "Over 36,000 people have already tried online learning through learndirect as part of our national pilot. Nine out of ten say they would recommend it.

"This is hugely encouraging and demonstrates real enthusiasm for this revolutionary new way of learning."

Mr Blunkett also announced a further £10m of funding for Ufi to provide a fleet of branded learndirect vehicles - mobile learning centres - to bring learning to the doorsteps of small businesses, including those in rural areas.

webTitle: Ivory Coast's military dictator ousted in revolution

fields.headline: Ivory Coast's military dictator ousted in revolution
fields.trailText: The Ivory Coast's opposition leader, Laurent Gbagbo, today swept to power after a people's revolt ousted military ruler General Robert Guei.
fields.body:
The Ivory Coast's opposition leader, Laurent Gbagbo, today swept to power after a people's revolt ousted military ruler General Robert Guei.

Tens of thousands of people took the streets to protest after Gen Guei proclaimed himself the winner of Sunday's presidential election following his dissolution of the national electoral commission which organised the vote.

Several potential candidates, including former prime minister Alassane Ouattara, were barred from standing in the poll by the supreme court. Today Mr Ouattara's supporters marched through the Ivory Coast's capital, Abidjan, calling for a new election.

Gen Guei has fled Abidjan for Cotonou in nearby Benin, his former information minister, Henri Cesar Sama, said. Mr Sama was among the soldiers who turned against the dictator.

Mr Sama said that pro-Gbagbo soldiers were trying to convince the remaining junta forces to put down their arms. He said another senior junta member, Captain Saint Cyr Djikalou, had also defected.

The general came to power in a December coup, the first military takeover in Ivory Coast. Instability since has battered the economy and frightened the people. Gen Guei had promised that the elections would mark a return to civilian rule.

Violent clashes erupted yesterday after Mr Gbagbo called on his supporters to take to the streets. Opposition leaders claimed nine people were killed.

Before dawn today, mutinous soldiers were defeated by loyalist comrades in an Abidjan military base. Hours later, thousands of Mr Gbagbo's supporters swarmed through the streets of Abidjan, erecting barricades, lighting fires and screaming for Gen Guei's resignation.

Soldiers loyal to Gen Guei fired shots in the air as they attempted to disperse unarmed demonstrators gathering outside the dictator's residence, in an exclusive suburb of the capital.

But by midday, more members of the security forces had joined the ranks of the protesters. Demonstrators had overrun broadcast facilities for state radio and television, and thousands more were outside the broadcast offices in central Abidjan. At least two people were killed and four were injured in the clashes, witnesses said.

Mr Gbagbo was introduced as "president; in an address broadcast on state television and said he would be forming a cabinet shortly. He praised his supporters for opposing what he called Gen Guei's "electoral coup d'etat".

"I pay particular homage to those who died in the cause of this," he said. "We will give them a funeral befitting their courage," he said. The speech was recorded at his campaign headquarters, where it was played on loudspeakers to hundreds of cheering supporters standing outside.

The announcement triggered celebrations on the streets of Abidjan and of the western city of Gagnoa, a Gbagbo stronghold. Some protesters beat on drums while others sang and danced in the streets.

fields.bodyText: The Ivory Coast's opposition leader, Laurent Gbagbo, today swept to power after a people's revolt ousted military ruler General Robert Guei. Tens of thousands of people took the streets to protest after Gen Guei proclaimed himself the winner of Sunday's presidential election following his dissolution of the national electoral commission which organised the vote. Several potential candidates, including former prime minister Alassane Ouattara, were barred from standing in the poll by the supreme court. Today Mr Ouattara's supporters marched through the Ivory Coast's capital, Abidjan, calling for a new election. Gen Guei has fled Abidjan for Cotonou in nearby Benin, his former information minister, Henri Cesar Sama, said. Mr Sama was among the soldiers who turned against the dictator. Mr Sama said that pro-Gbagbo soldiers were trying to convince the remaining junta forces to put down their arms. He said another senior junta member, Captain Saint Cyr Djikalou, had also defected. The general came to power in a December coup, the first military takeover in Ivory Coast. Instability since has battered the economy and frightened the people. Gen Guei had promised that the elections would mark a return to civilian rule. Violent clashes erupted yesterday after Mr Gbagbo called on his supporters to take to the streets. Opposition leaders claimed nine people were killed. Before dawn today, mutinous soldiers were defeated by loyalist comrades in an Abidjan military base. Hours later, thousands of Mr Gbagbo's supporters swarmed through the streets of Abidjan, erecting barricades, lighting fires and screaming for Gen Guei's resignation. Soldiers loyal to Gen Guei fired shots in the air as they attempted to disperse unarmed demonstrators gathering outside the dictator's residence, in an exclusive suburb of the capital. But by midday, more members of the security forces had joined the ranks of the protesters. Demonstrators had overrun broadcast facilities for state radio and television, and thousands more were outside the broadcast offices in central Abidjan. At least two people were killed and four were injured in the clashes, witnesses said. Mr Gbagbo was introduced as "president; in an address broadcast on state television and said he would be forming a cabinet shortly. He praised his supporters for opposing what he called Gen Guei's "electoral coup d'etat". "I pay particular homage to those who died in the cause of this," he said. "We will give them a funeral befitting their courage," he said. The speech was recorded at his campaign headquarters, where it was played on loudspeakers to hundreds of cheering supporters standing outside. The announcement triggered celebrations on the streets of Abidjan and of the western city of Gagnoa, a Gbagbo stronghold. Some protesters beat on drums while others sang and danced in the streets. fields.headline: Marconi shortlists agencies for relaunch
fields.trailText: 12pm: Marconi has shortlisted eight London ad agencies as part of a drive to revamp its image. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Marconi has shortlisted eight London advertising agencies as part of an attempt to move away from its arms and defence company image.

J Walter Thompson, Bates UK, Leo Burnett, Saatchi & Saatchi, Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, D'Arcy, Grey and Bartle Bogle Hegarty have all been approached about the multi-million pound global relaunch.

It is understood Marconi is prepared to spend up to $50m ($36m) on a global push as it extends its worldwide reach. The company has previously limited itself to ads in the defence and technology trade press.

Marconi now wants to reach out to ordinary consumers to convey its new image as a general IT company.

The agencies were this week involved in first round presentations, and a decision on a final shortlist is expected shortly.

In 1997, the electronics giant agreed a £16bn deal to sell its defence electronics division to British Aerospace.

fields.headline: Protecting kids from chatroom chat-up
fields.standfirst: As one paedophile starts a prison sentence after finding a young victim on the internet, Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor looks at protecting children from chatroom dangers
fields.trailText: As one paedophile starts a prison sentence after finding a young victim on the internet, Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor looks at protecting children from chatroom dangers.
fields.body:
Plenty of unpleasant things lurk online. Bomb-making and bestiality are two of them. Paedophilia, however, is a different matter.

The drive to exorcise paedophiles from the internet has been just as remorseless as the News of the World's campaign to publish their whereabouts - and, to the casual observer, considerably more effective.

Most web hosting companies take down any child pornography they find and report the perpetrators to the home office and the Internet Watch Foundation.

British ISP Demon Internet doesn't tolerate paedophile newsgroups either, and will contact the police if they are found on Demon servers.

Move them on, officer. Fair enough. No one wants to be responsible for harbouring paedophile activity. But cracking down on any illegal vice - whether it is kerb crawling, drug trafficking or paedophilia - tends to mean the trade reappears elsewhere.

Patrick Green chose to use private chatrooms, rather than public websites, to introduce himself to a young girl in the guise of a 15-year-old boy. He then started to email her, enclosing naked photographs of himself.

Green was yesterday jailed for five years in the first such conviction of its kind.

No amount of web policing could have prevented Green from doing this, because the space he operated in was outside the public domain. Just as the law of indecent exposure can only apply in a public place, private chatrooms are beyond the ambit of police surveillance.

The new RIP Bill would certainly have made it easier for police to access his emails once they suspected something, but because Green was impersonating another teenager, scanning for words like "paedophile" would probably have been unsuccessful.

It's easy to report the dodgy-looking character hanging around outside a school to the police. It's even easier to tell the Internet Watch Foundation about a dubious site.

In the same way that children already know why they shouldn't accept sweets and lifts from strangers, perhaps we should tell them why emails can be dangerous, too.

Chatrooms are a kind of online playground. Anyone venturing outside them for a private meeting does so at their own risk.

webTitle: New favourite, old favourite, and always unpopular

fields.headline: New favourite, old favourite, and always unpopular
fields.trailText: ROY AND THE BOY
fields.body:
ROY AND THE BOY

Every night, Del Boy Crozier, David 'Rodney' Davies and old duffer Uncle Noel say their prayers. "Please let a suitable candidate for the vacant England job show himself to us," they chorus before bedding down in the back of Del's yellow three-wheeler, "and God bless Hooky Street." This morning, the chums' prayers were finally answered when a mush in Copenhagen - sports director Niels-Christian Holmstrom, to be exact - said he would not object if they wanted to talk to his manager Roy Hodgson.

"That's very nice," effused Hodgson on BBC Radio Four after hearing the cushty news. "It's an extremely sporting gesture on their part." But Hodgson - who enjoyed spectacular success as coach of Switzerland before winging it at Internazionale - didn't get where he is today without playing it cool. "It is very nice to be mentioned and I am honoured," he said, "but at the same time I am presuming nothing and I am not even presuming I am one of the candidates."

In a sly manoeuvre that would make even Boycie proud, Roy then played hard to get. "There are complications along the line and it would be a little bit facile to say I would jump at the chance," he shrugged. "I am under contract with a club here in Copenhagen who are not terribly anxious to get rid of me," he explained, knowing full well that even a total plonker would be able to do a deal to get him back from Denmark. Brother, he's their man

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

GOING UP IN THE WORLD

Earlier this month, England bade farewell to the twin towers of Wembley with a performance to match some of the stadium's greatest moments. And that includes Bros's sellout gig in 1989. But it wasn't only the past that was glorious. According to the Wembley National Stadium Limited (or WNSL, not in any way to be confused with the New Millennium Experience Company or NMEC), the future would be cool too, with a Nu Wembley to "surpass anything which has been done before". And how right they were. Because Nu Wembley is already set to become the most expensive stadium on earth.

According to reports in the London Evening Standard, the cost of building the wazzy new stadium is set be £326m. Meanwhile, the Stade de France in Paris and Olympic Stadium in Sydney each cost £260m. Some times you gets what you pays for, of course, and it could be that Nu Wembley, with 150 corporate boxes and more toilets than any other international stadia, will be worth it. It could, however, also mean WNSL (chairman, Ken Bates) has got its sums wrong and may have even more trouble than anticipated in finding financing for the new home of football.

The new figures are included in NMEC's - sorry - WNSL's own business plan, which arrived at City banks today. However, according to WNSL chief executive Bob Stubbs, there is nothing to worry about. "The business plan has to look at the worst-case scenario, but even if that arises, we are confident we will raise the money and meet our commitments." WNSL are said to be looking for something in the region of £400m to finish the project. This they hope to secure via loans from the City, which in turn will be repaid via proposed ten-year debentures on seats which would allow people who like both football and Celine Dion to live out their wildest dreams. Personally, however, the Fiver would be more likely to stump up for a new stand at Villa Park.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The weather in Glasgow is not nice and the standard of the league is no better than Austria. When you see such top names playing for Rangers, there can only be one reason money!" - Sturm Graz chairman Hannes Kartnig gives his visitors from Ibrox the warmest of welcomes.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

GINGER MINGER

There is no greater fan of football than Chris Evans. The former TV celebrity has always been into it, and likes it almost as much as he likes dressing up Asian families in fairy lights and getting them to dance on a barge in the Thames. Or cracking jokes about how, instead of milk, Indian people get a pint of curry delivered to their door in the morning. So it is only fitting that, after a supposedly confidential chat with ITV controller of sport Brian Barwick, Evans this morning leaked details of ITV's plans to replace Match of the Day.

As you may be aware, the BBC will lose the right to broadcast Saturday night Premiership highlights at the end of this season. Barry Venison, sorry, ITV will then pick up the rights and attempt to replace a national institution with something bright and breezy instead. And, according to Evans, that attempt will be called ATG (short for All The Goals rather than All The Goals From Saturday's Premiership Matches And Sometimes Sunday's Too, But Never Monday's) and will be shown at the rather early hour of 6pm.

Evans believes this is a fantastic idea and that the BBC (against whom he has no axe to grind whatever) will only "realise what they had" when it's gone. Presumably this is an ironic statement from football's number one fan, who will know as well as anyone how difficult it is to get home from the football by six on a Saturday afternoon. Or perhaps it's just a typically hilarious windup by the pasty multi-millionaire, with ITV insisting this afternoon that they "have not made a decision on the scheduling or the title of the programme". Who do you trust? The makers of Where The Heart Is or the inventor of Asian Lookalikes? It's a tough one, think about it if you need to.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Jesper Gronkjaer could still be on his way to Chelsea, after his agent refuted reports that the Danish winger had failed a fitness test. "It's absolutely rubbish to say that he has failed a medical," Vincenzo Morabito said.

Rangers are the latest club to be linked with Real Madrid outcast Steve McManaman. Dick Advocaat wants to take the England winger on loan until the end of the season.

Celtic defender Alan Stubbs could move to Newcastle in a player-plus-cash deal, which would see Stephen Glass move the other way.

Charlton are considering a £3m move for Liverpool right-back Rigobert Song.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Aston Villa have given up their pursuit of Celta Vigo striker Benni McCarthy after the Spanish club priced the South African at £13m.

Leicester manager Peter Taylor has announced that the future of Stan Collymore will be resolved "within the next few days".

Swindon have refused to accept manager Colin Todd's resignation and are considering how to react to an approach from Derby for his services. Todd offered his resignation last night after a 2-0 home defeat at the hands of Millwall, and Swindon today received a request from Jim Smith asking for permission to talk to the 51-year-old about becoming his deputy at Pride Park. Chief executive Peter Rowe explained: "We have refused his resignation and are discussing the situation with our team of lawyers."

Watford have signed former Tranmere trainee Stephen Armstrong from Swedish side Vastra Frolunda until the end of the season.

Dundee are set to sign Bologna's number-two goalkeeper Marco Roccati on loan. "I am hopeful of negotiating an option to buy Marco when the loan deal runs out at the end of the season," said player-manager Ivano Bonetti. "Only a couple of years ago, there was a £1.3million tag on his head which shows he has a good reputation."

Former Manchester United chairman James Gibson, who saved the club from bankruptcy 70 years ago, will be honoured tomorrow when a plaque is unveiled in his memory beside Old Trafford.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live (7.30pm) Arsenal in England in England, Rangers in Austria in Scotland.

The Big Match (11.30pm) If you live in Scotland, settle down for extended highlights of the match you've just watched.

Football Extra (3.05am) Not Big cup, so don't care.

ITV2: The Big Match - Live (7.30pm) The Rangers game. But what do you do if you're in Scotland and want to watch the Arse?

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (4.30am) It's late, so we understand if you want to rummage around in your pyjamas instead

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (7pm) but there's no excuse for such antics when this is on

Football Special (7.30pm) and certainly not when Jeff Stelling's smiling mug is on the box.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm) Tonight, Dave Clark tries to break the record for World's Squarest Jaw.

Sky Sports 3: Jimmy Hill's Last Word (11pm) The title is sadly not as literal as you may hope.

ONsport 1: Big Cup programme (at some point) Go with us on this one.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.30pm) Don't bother tuning in. Make your own commentary instead using the following words: view, stanchion, gantry, draught, wooden, seat, disgrace, rubbish, cold, pie, parking, difficult, had, to, walk, over, ten, yards, match, boring, also.

Midweek 6-0-6 (10pm) Opinions ooze from every pore. Not counting the ones bunged up with dirt.

webTitle: Dunlop Tyres reviews its ad account

fields.headline: Dunlop Tyres reviews account after 20 years
fields.trailText: 5pm: Dunlop is putting its multi-million pound ad account out to tender as it gears up for its first pan-European push, writes Jade Garrett .
fields.body:
Dunlop Tyres is reviewing its multi-million pound advertising account currently held by Abbott Mead Vickers as it gears up for its first pan-European advertising push.

AMV will re-pitch for the business alongside Springer & Jacoby and Dutch agency 180 in a move that could see the end of its 20-year relationship with the company.

Geraldine McGovern, marketing services manager at Dunlop, confirmed the move.

Geraldine McGovern, marketing services manager at Dunlop, confirmed the move.

fields.headline: Prisoner 'killed in race hate attack'
fields.standfirst:
Young Asian bludgeoned to death by cellmate who revered the killers of Stephen Lawrence, court told

Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Stephen Lawrence
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: A young Asian prisoner was bludgeoned to death with a table leg by a racist cellmate who revered the killers of Stephen Lawrence, just hours before he was due to be released, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A young Asian prisoner was bludgeoned to death with a table leg by a racist cellmate who revered the killers of Stephen Lawrence, just hours before he was due to be released, a court heard yesterday.

Zahid Mubarak, 19, from Walthamstow, east London, was beaten to death early on March 21 at Feltham young offenders institution, west London.

He was sharing a cell with Robert Stewart, 20, who pleads not guilty to his murder.

Stewart and Mr Mubarak, who had reached the end of a 90-day sentence of youth custody for dishonesty, had shared a cell for six weeks before the attack.

Stewart, who has the letters RIP tattooed on his forehead, was on remand having just completed a custodial sentence.

Mr Mubarak suffered massive head injuries after being hit at least seven times, Sir John Nutting QC, prosecuting, told the jury at Kingston crown court. He also received a fractured forearm and finger from attempting to fend off the blows. Mr Mubarak died as a result of his injuries one week later.

The jury heard that Stewart had written seven letters containing "the crudest and most flagrant" racist language on the day of the attack and had scratched racist graffiti on his cell walls. As he left the dock at the end of the day's hearing he aimed a V sign at Mr Mubarak's family.

Mr Nutting said: "Out of a mixture of motives - frustration at his continued incarceration, racial hatred of the man with whom he shared a cell, and probably envy at Zahid Mubarak's release - the defendant developed the intention to injure his cellmate on the evening before his release.

"While his cellmate was lying down, defenceless, asleep, he attacked, cowardly and brutally causing his death."

On the night of the attack a patrol officer checked on the pair's cell, number 38 on the Swallow wing, at around 9pm and spoke briefly to them. They appeared bored but otherwise peaceful, the court heard.

At around 3.20am a warning buzzer, set off by Stewart, rang in the night patrol room and a guard went to the cell. He opened the hatch in the door and saw Stewart standing by Mr Mubarak's bed holding a table leg snapped from the table in their cell. He pointed at Mr Mubarak's bed and said, "My cellmate's had an accident."

The bedclothes and wall round the bed were covered with blood and Mr Mubarak was slipping into unconsciousness.

Stewart was then taken to a segregation cell for two hours to await the police. After he had been taken from the cell a swastika was discovered scratched on the wall along with the words "Just killed me pad mate (cellmate)".

Stewart admitted the assault but when asked why he'd attacked Mr Mubarak he said: "I don't even know myself, it's hard to explain, I just felt like it."

Mr Nutting read from letters found in Stewart's cell dated the day before the attack and addressed to seven different people. These, said Mr Nutting, demonstrated the defendant's racist views.

"Me ship out (transfer) to the north west better come soon, see some old friends, white ones," he wrote in one. Another read: "Nice spell up the north west, watched some Granada TV, heard some real accents, saw some white people. Did you watch Romper Stomper the other day? Fat film. I wish dem (sic) blokes were in and dem what killed Stephen Lawrence. The niggers would soon shut up.

"I'm going to nail bomb the Asian community of Great Norbury. Its all about immigrants getting smuggled into here, Romanians, Pakis, niggers, Chinkies, taking over the country and using us to breed half castes.

Zahid Mubarak, 19, from Walthamstow, east London, was beaten to death early on March 21 at Feltham young offenders institution, west London. He was sharing a cell with Robert Stewart, 20, who pleads not guilty to his murder. Stewart and Mr Mubarak, who had reached the end of a 90-day sentence of youth custody for dishonesty, had shared a cell for six weeks before the attack. Stewart, who has the letters RIP tattooed on his forehead, was on remand having just completed a custodial sentence. Mr Mubarak suffered massive head injuries after being hit at least seven times, Sir John Nutting QC, prosecuting, told the jury at Kingston crown court. He also received a fractured forearm and finger from attempting to fend off the blows. Mr Mubarak died as a result of his injuries one week later. The jury heard that Stewart had written seven letters containing "the crudest and most flagrant" racist language on the day of the attack and had scratched racist graffiti on his cell walls. As he left the dock at the end of the day's hearing he aimed a V sign at Mr Mubarak's family. Mr Nutting said: "Out of a mixture of motives - frustration at his continued incarceration, racial hatred of the man with whom he shared a cell, and probably envy at Zahid Mubarak's release - the defendant developed the intention to injure his cellmate on the evening before his release. "While his cellmate was lying down, defenceless, asleep, he attacked, cowardly and brutally causing his death." On the night of the attack a patrol officer checked on the pair's cell, number 38 on the Swallow wing, at around 9pm and spoke briefly to them. fields.headline: Carlton sales arm bags £120m SMG business
fields.trailText: 5pm: Carlton's airtime sales arm has picked up the contract to handle Scottish Media Group's £120m-a-year TV ad business, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications has confirmed that its airtime sales arm has picked up the contract to handle Scottish Media Group's £120m-a-year TV advertising business.

Carlton Sales will take over the SMG contract, selling airtime for the company's Scottish and Grampian ITV subsidiaries, on January 1 next year, as part of a five year deal.

Carlton will be conducting negotiations for 2001 advertising campaigns.

Scottish and Grampian sales were previously handled by TSMS. The former United News & Media sales house is being merged with Granada Sales, following the £1.75m sale of United's ITV businesses to Granada Media.

In order to get the deal cleared by the Office of Fair Trading, Granada gave an undertaking to the competition regulator that it would free the smaller ITV franchises from their airtime sales contracts.

TSMS had handled the Scottish and Grampian accounts since 1994 and the existing deal was due to run until the end of 2002.

SMG managing director Donald Emslie said the company held "pretty thorough and extensive discussions" with both Carlton Sales and Granada Sales before awarding the sales contract to Carlton.

He added: "We went with Carlton because of the deal that they offered in commercial terms and the services they could provide." He also said the deal was "good news for ITV and advertisers, creating a balance in the marketplace between two equally strong sales houses".

SMG's total TV advertising revenues in the last full year reported, 1999, were just under £120m, with Scottish and Grampian accounting for 6.1% of ITV's net advertising revenue (NAR) in that year.

Carlton Sales now handles 46% of ITV NAR with the addition of the Scottish stations. The outfit has also recently added HTV - which Carlton bought from Granada yesterday - to a client list that already includes the Carlton, Central and Westcountry ITV franchises.

Carlton Sales managing director Steve Platt said: "Adding the Scottish stations to the Carlton stable gives us a stronger sell with a wider reach. HTV and the Scottish stations together bring another 9m people into the Carlton sell."

fields.headline: Blair defends petrol price rises
fields.trailText: The prime minister denied today that it had been a "mistake" to raise petrol duties in this year's budget, as he clashed with William Hague at the first prime minister's questions of the new session of parliament. The half-hour session was dominated by a battle over economic issues including the euro and tax, with each party leader accusing the other of presiding over a policy in disarray.
fields.body:
The prime minister denied today that it had been a "mistake" to raise petrol duties in this year's budget, as he clashed with William Hague at the first prime minister's questions of the new session of parliament. The half-hour session was dominated by a battle over economic issues including the euro and tax, with each party leader accusing the other of presiding over a policy in disarray.

Beyond the squabbling, Tony Blair also gave a strong hint that former Japanese prisoners of war could be in line for extra compensation. Mr Blair twice told MPs that he had a good deal of sympathy with the campaign mounted by the Royal British Legion for additional monies to be paid to POWs. He stressed that Britain owed the POWs a "debt of honour" and pledged that "it won't be very much longer" before a decision is made. "The suffering that they endured was appalling. The nation owes them a particular debt of honour for the sacrifice they've made and the memories they have had to live with, literally, for the rest of their lives," the prime minister said.

On petrol, William Hague challenged Mr Blair to admit that tax increases in the last budget had been an error. "As first lord of the treasury you've given us the most expensive petrol in Europe and brought the country to a standstill," he said. "Will he now admit it was a mistake to increase petrol duties?"

The prime minister refused to do so. "I believe the position set out in the Budget was the right one," he told Mr Hague. "What is more, it was the position that you also supported.

"The truth is that your policy is a policy for boom and bust and instability. And it is a policy for £16bn worth of cuts in our public services."

In return the opposition leader accused Mr Blair of talking "unleaded nonsense". The prime minister "won't listen, won't learn and won't lead", he said.

Earlier, Mr Hague used three of his six questions to press the prime minister over the government's position on British membership of the single currency. In an exchange which brought routine responses from both leaders, he charged the prime minister with "jelly wobbling" back into question time after a week in which he had repeatedly altered his policy on the euro.

"On Thursday morning you said you were against the euro, at least for the rest of the day. By that afternoon, you were in favour of it again. On Friday, you were reported as cooling on it and on Monday Downing Street asserted you were still as enthusiastic as ever about preparing for it.

"On Tuesday, we learnt you told Paddy Ashdown that Europe is one of those issues where you have to mark your line and stick to it through thick and thin."

The prime minister's response was to cite long-established government policy. "We don't say we want to join the euro, but neither do we rule it out. "We keep the option open and the dividing line at the election will be between this party that says we keep the option open and give people choice in a referendum, and your position ... which was to rule it out for the next parliament."

fields.headline: Tweenies outstrips Teletubbies in spin-off stakes
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Eh Oh! Tinky Winky, Dipsy, La La and Po have been seen off by playgroup rivals the Tweenies, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Eh Oh! Tinky Winky, Dipsy, La La and Po have been seen off by four playgroup rivals.

The BBC's latest puppet sensation, the Tweenies, has already generated a massive £110m in sales of toys and other spin-off products.

And BBC chiefs believe that the income from Tweenies property rights and merchandising will eventually outstrip that brought in by Teletubbies, which generated £23m profit from merchandising in its first year and £32m in each of the following two years.

BBC Worldwide chief executive Rupert Gavin revealed today that the Tweenies children's series had been sold in over 25 territories since the launch of the programme in September 1999.

The series, which goes out on BBC2, features four colourful puppets called Jake, Milo, Bella and Fizz and is aimed at pre-school children aged three to five who have grown out of Teletubbies.

The latest figures show the growing importance of merchandising to BBC Worldwide. Under last year's licence fee settlement, the BBC's merchandising arm was told it had to increase its cash contribution to the corporation from £82m to more than £200m before 2006.

BBC Worldwide is launching a live Tweenies show on Boxing Day, which will kick off a series of dates at the National Indoor Arena at Birmingham.

Later this month the Tweenies will release a single, "No 1". A video and DVD, "Merry Tweenie Christmas", will also be released to cash in on Christmas sales.

BBC Worldwide claims that Tweenies toys, launched together with toy maker Hasbro, will be among the top five selling children's toys this Christmas.

webTitle: Parents: From Contented Baby to Confident Child by Gina Ford

fields.headline: Red Adair in the nursery
fields.standfirst: Revered by some, loathed by many, Gina Ford is fast becoming Britain's most controversial childcare guru.  Joanna Moorhead  meets her
fields.trailText: Revered by some, loathed by many, Gina Ford is fast becoming Britain's most controversial childcare guru. Joanna Moorhead meets her...
fields.body:
They call her book "the bible", and its author "Auntie Gina". Her followers meet in small groups, usually over afternoon tea, to debate her teachings: some say they'd never have made it through without her, others that she has changed their lives. Occasionally, one of them will admit to having had a lie-in until 9am - and baby too - and they'll all giggle and admit that Auntie Gina wouldn't like that. No, she wouldn't like it one bit.

These are the disciples of Gina Ford, mothers whose lives have been transformed by her Contented Little Baby Book - the book that has put routine back into the lives of Britain's parents.

"For years routine was a dirty word in childrearing," says Ford. "But I believe passionately that there's no comparison between a baby who is demand-fed, and a baby who is in a routine from day one. Today's parents have been brainwashed into thinking it's damaging to let a baby cry for more than 10 minutes. But that's nonsense.

"The other problem today," she goes on, "is that everything is regarded as 'normal': there's no one who will tell you when things could be improved and help you to change them."

Until now, that is, with the advent of Auntie Gina. Her claim is that her followers are the happiest mothers in the country, and their babies are the happiest babies: because they are being raised the Gina way. Like Delia Smith's recipe for cheese soufflé, the Gina way never fails. Follow her advice about bedtimes and sleep times and feed times to the letter and you will not have a baby who is difficult, who keeps you awake or who cries endlessly for no reason at all.

"Gina's babies", as they are invariably called by their delighted parents, are No Trouble At All.

Auntie Gina is looking fairly contented herself today, as well she might given her runaway bestseller and a second book, From Contented Baby to Confident Child, about to join it on the shelves. There are other reasons to be cheerful: the website she's developing; the network of supporters she's setting up; and the endless TV offers (think Barbara Woodhouse and the Two Fat Ladies rolled into one).

But being in demand is nothing new for her: until her new career as a parenting guru, Ford was so success ful as a maternity nurse that she became the Red Adair of the neonate.

"Some of my clients earned less than me," she says. Not many, though: some of her customers counted their annual earnings nearer the seven than the six-figure mark, and were she to name names (she won't), it would sound like the contents list of Hello! magazine.

Ford fell into maternity nursing by chance. She used to babysit to boost her income while studying hotel management, and found she had rather a flair for looking after her charges. One of the families asked her to come and work for them, and Ford decided to give it a go. Ford has read her Penelope Leach and her Miriam Stoppard, but she is a self-taught expert who knows what she knows through watching babies. She might have left hotel management, but it has never quite left her: she watches the waiting staff like a hawk during our lunch, criticises and comments, sends back her main course, says it was never like this in her day.

Babies, one suspects, come in for similar no-nonsense treatment: Ford is a bossy know-all rather than an empathetic supporter, a dictator rather than an enabler. She claims her schedules can make a woman into a confident parent, but the exact opposite would seem to be the case: she quotes mothers who phone to ask what to substitute for leeks in her recipes. She says some of her fans have begged her to write the follow-up book because "they can't manage without it".

Does she like "her babies", as she calls them?

"What a naff question," she says, before claiming that she "goes all gooey" when she sees one. Yet Ford's philosophy is all about taming the little horrors, letting them know who's boss. You don't manage that by coming over all soppy and sentimental.

Asked whether, as a non-parent, she's qualified to offer us pearls of wisdom, she is defensive. If you had a heart attack, she asks, would you rather be treated by a doctor who's had two himself, or one who's treated hundreds of heart-attack victims?

You can see her intent: parenting gurus of recent years have invariably had their own children, and draw on their own experiences. This may be enriching, but it also limits them: Ford's proudest boast is that she's been in at the deep end with more than 300 families, and is able to draw on more experience of babies than most of her rivals on the parenting bookshelves.

"What I did in developing my routines," she says, "was to watch the easy, settled babies, and to use the natural routines they seemed to be in as a blueprint for the babies who seemed more difficult to deal with."

Every day, Ford says, she hears from dozens of mothers who love what she's done for them. Even her fans, though, concede that her routines are terribly complicated. "You certainly have to work at it," according to one former client. Ford's instructions for breastfeeding a four-week-old are draconian: up by 7am, feed to be finished by 7.45am, nap in his room at 8.45am, woken an hour later, 25 minutes at the breast at 10am, play on his mat at 10.30am, in bed by 11.45am, awake again by 2pm, feed now but must be over by 3.15pm, walk at 4pm, next feed to be over by 5pm, bath at 5.45pm, feeding by 6.15pm, and "fully swaddled and in the dark, with the door shut, no later than 7pm".

If only I'd known! My babies were breastfed anywhere and everywhere, stayed in a sling while I did the washing up, slept beside me on the sofa in the evenings before sleeping in my bed, and were blissfully unaware of what it meant to be swaddled. Ford seems genuinely amazed.

"All I can say," she says, "is that you were very lucky. Not everyone has such easy babies as you obviously did. And not everyone works at home."

In fact, I don't think my babies were particularly easy, but it is true that it's easier to dispense with routine if you're a home-based mother. Part of Ford's success is down to the fact that "go with the flow" mothering won't suffice for the large number of working mothers with small children. If you've got to be up and out by 8am for a hard day at the office you need to have slept for a few hours first.

But if the Ford approach has its advantages, it also has its illusions. Babies aren't "controllable" as she would have us believe. There is no blueprint for parenting: you write your own rules and make your own mistakes.

You also have to follow your heart, because childrearing is an emotional as well as a practical experience. But Ford is little interested in this: she believes love comes naturally, and doesn't need to be written about in books. For many new parents this is not the case: learning to love their baby is the most difficult lesson of all. It doesn't fit into any routine, but isn't this what matters most?

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst:
Building a library for your child

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child...
fields.body:
Ages 0-3

Does a Kangaroo Have a Mother Too? by Eric Carle (Collins, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

After the joys of The Very Hungry Caterpillar, I was a little disappointed when I picked up Carle's Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See? Thinking it rather dull and repetitive, it took me a while to realise that it was the repetition that was the point. In time, the book became a favourite with my children. Carle's latest is in similar style, full of the vibrant, patterned artwork that we've come to expect. The text is simplicity itself, taking the question in the title and substituting different animals from the giraffe to the dolphin.

This is a book for chanting, for sharing between mothers and children and for finding out about all the creatures in the world. Ideal also for children taking their first steps in letter and word recognition.

Husherbye by John Burningham(Jonathan Cape, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

This is Burningham in classic form with a bedtime tale that is so snug, gentle and warm, it makes you want to rush off to bed immediately. Which is presumably the point. Books as the modern equivalent of the lullaby don't come more enchanting than this.

Once again, simplicity is the keynote here, both in the everyday magic of the text and the simple drawings. Burningham actually manages to capture exactly what a fish looks like when it is heavy-eyed with sleep or how comfy the man-in-the-moon is as he settles down for the night. This is a book that, in the tale of the baby sailing a boat on the sea, the cat looking for a place for her kittens to stay and the goose who has been flying high, takes the reader on a journey from sleepiness to sleep itself. A book to bring the day to a close with a caress and a whisper.

Ages 4-7

Beware of the Storybook Wolves by Lauren Child(Hodder, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

Absolutely no apologies for reviewing another book by this writer/illustrator who has turned books for this age group upside down. Child makes words dance and topography jitterbug, and her sly sense of humour makes both children and adults giggle. This one is for anyone who has ever believed that there might be a wolf under the bed or has worried that the characters in books, particularly the nasty ones, might creep out of the pages and get you.

At its most profound, this is about the tremendous power of books. At its silliest, it is about how wolves don't put toothpaste on their shopping lists and why they think jelly is for starters. Read this and your children will never look at Red Riding Hood the same way again.

The Obvious Elephant by Bruce Robinson and Sophie Windham (Bloomsbury, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

"Imagine a town, in a country, where a simple thing like an elephant had never been seen, or even heard of." That's the tantalising start to this completely enchanting and thought-provoking tale about an elephant that turns up in a town square one day. Nobody knows what to do with it. The people consider plugging it in, using it as a new kind of railway engine or vacuum cleaner. The elephant is not best pleased. Only a little boy called Eric knows what the elephant is and nobody will listen to him.

Part of the joy of this book, written in simple prose and illustrated with magical pictures, is that it puts its young readers in a superior position to the silly adults in the story. But it is also a touching tale about friendship. This is the sort of book that both inspires and makes children think laterally.

Ages 8-11

The Oldest Girl in the World by Carol Ann Duffy (Faber, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

So much poetry for children is just about jokes that scan. Duffy's is about living your life to the full.

Between these pages are exquisite lives in miniature, a kind of distillation of experience. There are lullabies that remind us not to be scared because: "The dark is only a blanket/ for the moon to put on her bed." Or morality tales about bad princesses who end up in the arms of dull young princes. It serves them right. Best of all are such transformations as that of 96-year-old Emily who throws off her clothes and the years and goes swimming: "A poacher up to his tricks on the bank noticed her splashing away/Afterward, when they asked, she was young, was all he could say." Anyone could dive into this collection and surface with a pearl.

Polly's Running Away Book by Frances Thomas, illustrated by Sally Gardner (Bloomsbury, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

If you have any worries that your eight-year-old daughter is in danger of turning into a poppet version of Bridget Jones, you should hide this book. She will find it anyway. Sally Gardner's scrapbook-style illustrations have the chaotic charm of a child's treasure box crossed with what's underneath the average pre-teen bed - and they attract children at a 100 paces. This is one of the few books I've reviewed that has caused a queue of eager year fours to form.

It is a first-person narrative, complete with misspellings, written by Polly, whose hamster has gone missing, whose mum is having a baby, and who doesn't like broccoli. This is as tough as it gets, but Thomas's writing is great on why it is the little things that seem big when you are in primary school. In truth, I found the whole thing just a bit too contrived, giggly and girlie. But who am I?

Ages 12+

The Basic Eight by Daniel Handler (Allison and Busby, £9.95; CultureShop price £7.99)

The Basic Eight are 18-year-old Flannery and her pretentious, articulate, affluent clique of San Francisco high school friends. These are kids with Yale futures ahead of them, but circumstance, teenage hearts and adult failings conspire against them. Flannery commits murder - and the clique is classed as satanic and much studied by pop psychologists, worried parents' groups, self-styled experts and the makers of "true story" videos.

This classy, clever and cheesy first novel, which takes the form of Flannery's diary, drips irony. It is very funny and very sharp - the biggest contribution to the high school murder genre since the movie Heathers. No doubt the film version is already on its way. Worldly-wise teenagers of 14 and over will covet it.

Awful End by Philip Ardagh (Faber, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

This is a book with character. To be precise, lots of incredible characters. Such as Gibbering Jane, the chambermaid who failed a bed-making course and has since lived in the cupboard under the stairs; Mrs Cruel Streak, who runs an orphanage; mad Uncle Jack and his even madder wife, who talks to her stuffed stoat.

This scrumptious cross between Dickens and Monty Python tells the story of Eddie, who fails to heed his mother's warning not to be mistaken for a runaway orphan - lest he be taken to St Horrid's Home For Grateful Orphans, where he will suffer cruelty, hardship and misery.

You can look at this book as an examination of: 1) the absurdities of the English language; 2) the absurdities of the 19th-century novel; 3) the absurdities of the way the English treat their kids; 4) the absurdities of the absurd. A child will enjoy its daft ness at 10, will get the references at 14, and will know that it is all true at 18. Brilliant.

Missing by Catherine Macphail (Bloomsbury, £4.99)

Since her brother Derek went missing 10 months ago, 13-year-old Maxine has been feeling increasingly isolated and rejected. Her parents are so wrapped in their own grief that that she feels unloved and locked out. Their neglect sends her off the rails and into truancy. The situation isn't helped by Sweeny, the school bully who made Derek's life a misery and is now targeting Maxine.

Macphail's story is a gritty, superior page-tuner. It creates a palpable sense of terror as a body is found and identified as Derek's, while Maxine starts to get mysterious phone calls from someone claiming to be her brother. As a thriller, it doesn't quite add up, but there is no doubting that Macphail captures the experiences of a teenager trying to cope in circumstances where the adults have copped out. Maxine is a credible, down-to-earth heroine and the story will hook the most reluctant reader.

webTitle: Parents: Hallowe'en was a huge social event

fields.headline: Ghosts of a childhood past
fields.standfirst: Hallowe'en was a huge social event when  Julie Wheelwright  was growing up in Canada. It's different here - but it still has a peculiar magic
fields.trailText: Hallowe'en was a huge social event when Julie Wheelwright was growing up in Canada. It's different here - but it still has a peculiar magic.
fields.body:
Where I grew up in western Canada in the 60s, the first snow would usually have fallen by October 31. This often provoked bitter battles between mothers, concerned about exposing tender young legs and heads to biting temperatures, and children determined to show off the full glory of their costumes. At six, I was particularly bad-tempered about having to tramp along the icy streets of Calgary carrying my loot bag up my neighbours' driveways with my beautiful nylon and coat-hanger wire wings crushed beneath my duffle coat. "Fairies don't wear boots!" I yelled before leaving the house that evening.

Given that Hallowe'en came over with those 19th-century Irish immigrants fleeing the potato famines, it seems ironic that it is now understood as a North American tradition, fast gaining popularity in the UK. But my memories of bitter nights - harbinger of long, hard winters - is exactly what the ancient Celts were celebrating in Ireland. The modern ritual has its origins in the ancient Celtic fire festival and New Year, the night when fairies would traipse through the land. At this bewitching time, people would imitate fairies, going from house to house begging treats and, if they were not given, playing practical jokes upon the owner.

Throughout my childhood, Hallowe'en was a huge event, the run-up a fever-pitch of excitement second only to Christmas. There were weeks during recess when we'd grill each other with, "So, what are you going as?" and then further time spent convincing a parent to stoop over a sewing machine or make a trip uptown to the department stores. Ghosts, cowboys, goblins, skeletons, fairies and monsters were popular.

Hallowe'en was full of forbidden pleasures. Going out after dark with a bunch of other kids, getting a sackful of treats and having permission to pull a few "tricks" like wrapping trees in toilet paper or setting off firecrackers. But this misrule was balanced by churches and schools turning us all into UN volunteers. Every year, I took a Unicef collection box on Hallowe'en which we would shake at our neighbours who kept a stack of pennies ready on a tray next to the candy. While we gorged, we remembered the children of Biafra.

There was a darker side to Hallowe'en, too. It flourished in "real-life" ghost stories, and urban legends about children who died eating apples that had razor blades embedded in their flesh or who went mad from drugged candy bars. Yet these were apocryphal tales not linked to anyone we ever knew, and no neighbours refused us entry except the Jehovah's Witnesses who lived down the road. Parents would maintain a respectful distance as children charged up garden paths.

Now that I live in England with my two young daughters, I am conscious that Hallowe'en has an entirely different meaning. The biggest single influence over my daughter's excitement about Hallowe'en is her general infatuation with witches and wizardry, inspired by JK Rowling's Harry Potter series. Hallowe'en themes are with us all year through television programmes such as Sabrina and Buffy the Vampire Slayer. When we gave a Hallowe'en party last year, all 10 girls came dressed as witches, and "playing Harry Potter" is a favourite after-school game.

The idea of trick or treat, however, seems alien here. The children who call at my south London home on Hallowe'en are rare and, even in those neighbourhoods where children fill up loot bags, the process is orchestrated by parents. Other friends report that Hallowe'en on the street runs a definite second to private fancy-dress parties and certainly to Guy Fawkes night.

But when I watch my daughter getting dressed for her party, donning false fingernails and taking up her home-made wand, I realise there is an eternal magic to Hallowe'en that transcends cultural boundaries. For one night at least, the children, like ancient Celtic fairies, are in control.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: A survey has found that most girls want to be Britney Spears and most boys Michael Owen when they grow up. But who do parents think make the best role models?
fields.trailText: Who do parents think make the best role models?
fields.body:
Helen Humphreys, The Guide Association

My son said that his hero is his dad and when he thought about it a little bit more he came up with Jim Carrey. My daughter likes Tom Jones, the same hero her grandmother has, which is nice. If parents have a good relationship with their children they can work alongside them, helping to keep heroes in perspective. Children can get very disappointed if they ever meet an icon, because they're often not the person the media has built them up to be. I'd like my children to have someone with the values we hold dear as their hero, a person who respects others, is successful and hardworking.
Verdict: Steve Redgrave

Max Clifford, PR guru

My hero for Louise has got to be her mum, my wife Liz, not me. Liz is a much nicer person than I am and not as ambitious. She is one of the kindest, happiest, most natural people I have ever come across. I wouldn't really nominate an icon because I've worked with too many of them and I know what they're like. I don't think there's anything wrong with children having icons, but parents need to temper these images which often have nothing to do with what a famous person is really like. As well as Liz, I think Louise has been an excellent role model to herself.
Verdict: Wife and daughter

Pascoe Sawyers, father of three

When I was a teenager I thought my role models were people such as Muhammad Ali and Aretha Franklin. But the really big influences on my life were the people I had close relationships with - my parents, family, teachers and peers. My children, if asked, would probably choose TV, sports or pop stars. But real role models are almost always much closer to home, they are the people who help to shape your ideas and attitudes. So in spite of all my faults, I would pick myself, and their mum, Hazel, as role models for our children and hope that they would, in the long run, pick us too.
Verdict: Mum and dad

Peter Hook musician and father of three

My son Jack's icon is David Beckham and I would choose him myself as Jack's hero because I think he comes across as quite a caring father. A lot of fathers I know these days don't take being a parent seriously. He and Posh do seem to take their parenting seriously. When Beckham came on after 20 minutes at the United vs Leeds match on Saturday Jack's face really lit up. My youngest daughter's icon is the Teletubbies. But after we dressed up as them for her birthday party at a kid's activity centre and got beaten up by other kids because of it, I don't think I'd share that one with her.
Verdict: David Beckham

Mary McLeod chief executive of the National Family and Parenting Institute

This is terribly, embarrassingly obvious but I would say Nelson Mandela. As well as being my hero for them he's one of their heroes too. I think it's important to look for heroes from ordinary life too. There are so many of them out there and I think that they're the really important role models for children to have. I'm not against the business of children having icons in general. It's good to think highly of other people because it gives you something to aim for. I know that another survey was done this year about girls' heroes and a lot of them came up with their mum. I like that.
Verdict: Nelson Mandela

fields.headline: Dad's the word
fields.standfirst: Once used as a last resort in child support cases, DNA paternity testing has become big business in the US for men anxious to know whether their child is really theirs. Now it's coming here.  Polly Ghazi  reports
fields.trailText: Once used as a last resort in child support cases, DNA paternity testing has become big business in the US for men anxious to know whether their child is really theirs. Now it's coming here.
fields.body:
Caroline Caskey loves her job. She receives many gushing testimonials, usually anonymous, along the lines of "Thank you - you saved my marriage!" and "You made it possible for me to have a positive life." She is not, however, a marriage guidance counsellor or family therapist, but a successful businesswoman in a boom industry. Her company tests the DNA of parents and children in order to answer a heart-wrenching question apparently gnawing away at a growing number of men. Did they father the child they are raising?

"It's a very cathartic experience to learn that your child is really yours and your suspicions are unfounded," says Caskey, chief executive of Identigene of Houston, Texas. "It's very common for fathers who get a positive result to burst into tears over the phone."

Traditionally, DNA paternity testing has been sought by mothers trying to prove the fatherhood of men who are refusing to pay child support. The results, if positive, are used in civil court cases to force fathers to pay up. But over the past five years there has been a surge of applications from insecure American and, to a lesser extent, British men, anxious that their partners may have been less than faithful.

"About a third of fathers who come to us have their worst fears realised," says Craig Kelly of New Orleans-based ReliaGene Technologies, whose business has doubled since 1995. "Some men are happy not to have to pay child support. Many others are devastated. But which is the greater tragedy for father and child: knowing the truth or not knowing it?"

Either way, their clients' anguish is good for business. There are now at least 40 major private testing firms across the US. According to the American Association of Blood Banks, which inspects accredited testing labs, the industry is growing by 11% a year, with more than 280,000 tests conducted in 1999.

Business is growing in Britain, too. Seven private companies now offer a discreet service, while hundreds, perhaps thousands, of men have mail-ordered testing kits from US firms via their websites. "Around 6,000 paternity tests are now conducted in Britain a year," says John Burn, professor of clinical genetics at Newcastle University, who in 1995 set up NorthGene, a non-profit company that tests about a hundred families a year. "Most are done for legal purposes but more anxious fathers are also coming forward by their own choice."

Half of a newborn's DNA is inherited from each parent, so a man can be ruled out as the father if his DNA markers are not found in "his" child. If their genetic patterns overlap, there is a more than 99% probability that they are father and child.

Tests cost between £350 and £475 and can be done at home, or at a hospital or clinic, simply by taking a swab of skin cells inside the cheek. Samples do not need special packing and are couriered to the company's laboratory where they are amplified and then "read" by laser beam. The child's DNA is then compared, via computer analysis, to each parent's. Results typically take five to seven days and are posted, emailed or faxed to home addresses.

While the procedure is relatively simple, the legal and social implications may be less so. An adverse result can shatter not only a father's emotional wellbeing, but that of the child he has brought up as his own. For this reason, some US states require that paternity tests are conducted very early in a child's life. For their part, testing companies require legal proof of parentage, such as birth certificates, before accepting a family. They also pass traumatised clients on to family support and counselling services.

With genetic science progressing by leaps and bounds, the circumstances under which parental DNA testing is possible are becoming ever broader and more ethically challenging. Some US companies now conduct tests on amniotic fluid surrounding a foetus to determine parenthood. Identigene has also tested pregnant couples who used donor eggs implanted with the husband's sperm - just in case one of the wife's own eggs had been fertilised. In one recent instance, this turned out to be the case, much to the parents' joy.

"The technical barriers are falling very easily and the question of whether there should be any legal or ethical barriers is being left behind," says Professor Burn. Caroline Caskey concedes that firms like hers operate in a social minefield, but denies that they prey on people's insecurity. "We offer a real social service. For example, fathers who are not bonding well with a child they are unsure of find out that they are the biological father and it paves the way for a much better relationship. Better to know for sure and then move on."

Are there any instances when she would not recommend testing to parents? "We have had cases where a woman has been a rape victim and has become pregnant soon after. She and her husband want to know that it's their baby. I think it is probably better they remain blissfully ignorant."

The vast majority of the public, however, appears to be fair game. Identigene's effective but far-from-subtle advertising methods include a "guess the father" game on its website, which offers viewers pictures of a beaming baby and three potential dads. When I clicked on the correct face, I was told "Lucky guess!" and informed that many children don't look anything like their parents.

The implication is clear: even if your child is the spitting image of you, there is always room for that tiny worm of doubt.

'It's better to know the truth': one father's story

Stanley Turner, 30, an electricity-meter reader from Memphis, Tennessee, is separated from his wife. He turned to Identigene after fearing that his three-year-old son Joshua, who lives with him, might have been fathered by another man.

My wife and I got married a year after we had Joshua and then split up last July. Since we separated she has had numerous affairs and I became worried that Joshua might not be mine. I saw an item about DNA paternity test ing on a TV talkshow and I decided to have the test for peace of mind. Also, some of my family were saying they thought Joshua was not my son.

He lives with me, I am his legal guardian, so we were able to do a test with just Joshua and me. They took cheek swabs at a local health clinic which shipped the sample off for testing. All I had to do was wait for a fax to arrive. It was very hard waiting. If he had not been mine, my heart would have been broken. Still, I think it's much better to know the truth, for the child as well as the parents. It gives the child a sense of stability he might not otherwise have.

When the result came, it said that Joshua was mine and I was overjoyed. I don't like to think about how I would have felt with a different result. Still, I wouldn't have abandoned Joshua. His mother doesn't see him much and I'm the only father he has ever known. The test cost $500 (£350) and it was well worth it for my peace of mind.

fields.headline: Associated to supply handheld content
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Associated New Media has been signed up to supply content to a new personal digital assistant service, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Associated New Media has been signed up to supply content to a new PDA (personal digital assistant) service that launches in the UK today.

ThisisLondon.com, the website of the London Evening Standard, will supply London restaurant, pub and events data to Vindigo, a US company that provides an in-depth city guide service to handheld personal organisers.

The partnership with ANM and Vindigo's entry into the UK has been set up by the digital media and entertainment agency <kpe>, which is headed in Europe by the former managing director of ANM, Paul Zwillenberg.

To use the free service, which provides venue listings and reviews as well as detailed directions, Palm device users have to download the application from www.vindigo.com

David Joerg, president of Vindigo, said he was thrilled to be moving into Europe and planned to launch other city guides in partnership with local content providers in addition to a Wap service.

Mr Zwillenberg said: "Not only does it give media companies the means to connect with users when they are mobile, but it also gives users a first-hand look at the future of mobile devices."
