fields.headline: Autonomy makes deal with NTT
fields.standfirst:
London listing finally in reach

Net news
fields.trailText: A new chapter was added to the Autonomy fairytale yesterday less than a week before the $5.6bn (£3.8bn) firm was due to list on the London Stock Exchange; only two years ago it was dismissed as two small and too speculative to do so.
fields.body:
A new chapter was added to the Autonomy fairytale yesterday less than a week before the $5.6bn (£3.8bn) firm was due to list on the London Stock Exchange; only two years ago it was dismissed as two small and too speculative to do so.

NTT Software Corporation, part of the Japanese phone group, has become the latest multinational to announce a distribution deal with the Cambridge-based Autonomy, which sells software that sorts the vast quantities of unstructured information floating around the internet.

The announcement was just the sort of positive news investors would have expected prior to a listing in the FTSE 100 index of Britain's biggest companies. Autonomy's sales should be in for a significant lift in the region if it gains access to NTT's Japanese customer base.

Judging by the research investment banks are sending their clients the listing, on October 31, should be a resounding success. Dresdner Kleinwort Benson says Autonomy is "poised to be the standard". Dresdner and SG Cowen assess the stock as a "buy" and advise investors that it should be a "core holding" in their respective portfolios.

The enthusiasm is understandable: the "intelligent" technology Mike Lynch and his team have developed is pitched at a market for unstructured data that is forecast to grow from £1.7bn in 1999 to £8bn in 2003, according to sector research.

Financial targets have been beaten consistently: in March Autonomy turned a first pre-tax quarterly profit of £300,000 on revenues of £8.1m; gross margins were an impressive 93%. Most new contracts are coming from the American market. Autonomy is confident that its technology remains ahead of the game and by joining big players like Sun, Compaq, and GM it increases its chances of making its software a global standard.

The London listing will make Autonomy's stock available to funds restricted to buying UK shares and which are not able to buy on Easdaq or Nasdaq, the exchanges where Autonomy is at present listed. Only 6.7m shares are being made available.

Investors' tolerance of risk has increased during the boom in hi-tech shares and Autonomy, with established product, management and revenue streams, seems safer than most.

But there are still doubts about the float. Some in the City are worried about the proposed sale of shares by Mr Lynch. He is only disposing of a fraction of his stake but will still net around $69m (£47.6m) and retain an 18% holding.

Mr Lynch has been instrumental in driving Autonomy forward. But wealth is not his sole motive: he says there is plenty to do to build a truly world class company.

Autonomy shares trade at a rating of around 476 times current earnings, and results that fail to meet market expectations could shatter the share price. UK investors buying in now may also feel they have missed the boat. There may be further to go in the shares but a repeat of huge growth in the price is extremely unlikely.

Overseas expansion, particularly into non-western countries, will test management's ability and capacity to the full. The NTT deal is a strong start, but it will be necessary to strengthen sales and support in new regions.

Perhaps the biggest threat comes from new, rival technologies. The software is not yet patented, and Autonomy's own growth has shown how quickly start-ups can emerge to challenge incumbents. Some competitors have already said they are confident their technology will beat Autonomy in the long term, although no evidence has yet been produced to that effect.

Investors wondering what to do next week would be best to follow Mr Lynch's example. Invest in Autonomy by all means, but make sure you keep some money in the bank.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's transfer talk retires from the House after a 50-year sulk
fields.trailText: Rangers are the latest club to be linked with Real Madrid outcast Steve McManaman. Dick Advocaat wants to take the England winger on loan until the end of the season.
fields.body:
Rangers are the latest club to be linked with Real Madrid outcast Steve McManaman. Dick Advocaat wants to take the England winger on loan until the end of the season.

Reports suggest that Chelsea are about to make a £10m bid for Rangers midfielder Giovanni van Bronkhorst. But the Dutch international - whilst not ruling out a move - reckons such speculation is wide of the mark. "It doesn't stop. Last week I was going to Milan and I should have been at Arsenal a couple of weeks ago," he said. "I have just got to get on until it's really the case, and at the moment it isn't."

Celtic defender Alan Stubbs could move to Newcastle in a player-plus-cash deal which would see Stephen Glass move the other way.

Charlton are considering a £3m move for Liverpool right-back Rigobert Song.

Canadian international Jason Bent is on a two-week trial at Sunderland. The 23-year-old can play at left-back or in midfield.

Preston want to make Liverpool striker Erik Meijer's loan move permanent.

Former Sheffield Wednesday midfielder John Harkes wants to play for the Hillsborough club again.

Swindon will later today complete a £500,000 double deal with Danish side AGF Aarhus for 24-year-old defender John Jensen and 23-year-old midfielder Dennis Slim.

fields.headline: Emap to launch more masthead TV shows
fields.trailText: 10am: Emap is poised to launch dozens of TV programmes based on its magazines, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap is poised to launch dozens of TV programmes based on its magazines, including Smash Hits and heavy metal title Kerrang!.

The move is part of an initiative by the publishing giant to launch 'masthead' programmes that mirror its magazine portfolio.

Sources have said Emap's newly-created Emap Performance Television division will in the coming months launch masthead TV versions of all its successful music, and some non-music, magazine brands.

The company is also examining the possibility of replicating all of its successful magazine brands in a radio format.

Emap last month created three posts: head of pop for former head of BBC music programmes Trevor Dann, head of dance for Kiss and Magic managing director Mark Story and head of rock for ex-Kerrang! editor Dave Henderson.

Where Emap has a corresponding magazine and radio station, such as Mixmag and Kiss radio, it is likely to drop the weaker brand.

This policy is already being extended to video channel the Box, which over the next few months will be rebranded as the Smash Hits channel.

And Emap Performrance TV is understood to be preparing to launch a Kerrang! masthead show.

Emap Performance last month created a division called Emap Performance Television, headed by former the Box channel director Shirley Renwick.

Emap's move comes as rival IPC Media is poised to turn many of its successful magazine brands into television shows.

IPC and MTV are in talks about joint ventures based on IPC music magazine brands such as the NME, which is soon to launch a show on the Telewest-owned Bravo channel.

IPC's head of TV strategy, Nick Ryle, said: "MTV and the NME are working in similar areas and there is potential for us to work together. We have had some meetings."

But Mr Ryle added that the company had no firm plans to launch a channel or programmes with MTV. An MTV spokesman confirmed that there had been talks but said were no imminent plans to launch joint projects.

webTitle: Gielgud leaves most of his £1.5m estate to charity

fields.headline: Gielgud leaves most of his £1.5m estate to charity
fields.trailText: Sir John Gielgud, who died in May at the age of 96, made specific cash legacies to friends and charities such as Rada, the Actors' Charitable Trust and the King George V Fund for Actors and Actresses
fields.body:
The actor Sir John Gielgud has left most of his £1.5m fortune to charity, it was announced last night. The renowned stage and screen star died in May at the age of 96.

In his will he made specific cash legacies to friends and charities such as Rada, the Actors' Charitable Trust and the King George V Fund for Actors and Actresses.

He also left the Theatre Museum in London a number of personal items, including a snuffbox which once belonged to the Victorian actor Charles Kean. To the National Portrait Gallery he left a pair of portraits of actors, including his great aunt, Ellen Terry.

But the bulk of the estate is to be given to charitable causes chosen at his executors' discretion.

Solicitor Ian Bradshaw, of the firm Goodman Derrick, one of the executors of his will, said: "Although the executors had been given discretion as to the distribution of Sir John's estate, during his lifetime he made it known to them the charities he wished to benefit under the will. The executors will give these wishes proper consideration."

The executors will also dispose of his papers and archives.

Shortly after his death it emerged that Sir John had made secret payments to Stonewall, the campaign group for homosexual rights, but insisted that his support remained secret because he did not want to encourage speculation about his private life.

He made several donations to the organisation to help with campaigns to lower the age of consent for homosexuals and for the abolition of Section 28.

The Oscar-winning actor continued his support right up until his death in May, but told Sir Ian McKellen - the actor and founder-member of Stonewall - that his contributions should not be made public.

fields.headline: Cutbacks loom at Network of the World
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Network of the World, the interactive entertainment service set up by Hong Kong 'Superboy' Richard Li, is facing drastic cutbacks. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Network of the World, the interactive entertainment service set up by Hong Kong 'Superboy' Richard Li, is facing drastic cutbacks.

Parent company Pacific Century Cyberworks told analysts in Hong Kong it would sharply reduce investment in the London-based service, which employs 350 staff.

No further details were forthcoming on the cuts, which come after PCCW's share price fell to a 12-month low on Tuesday.

NOW is a joint venture between PCCW and the TV and online production outfit, Trans World International, and operates out of TWI's west London base. The service, which offers five themed web portals and an Asian satellite TV channel based around the same mix of content, launched in June.

Mr Li, 33, and PCCW were the darlings of the Hong Kong economy earlier this year with investors queueing up. His father, Li Ka-shing, known as 'Superman', is Hong Kong's richest man.

Mr Li has also clashed with Rupert Murdoch. Eight years ago he borrowed money from his father to set up Star TV, the first pan-Asian satellite service. He sold it to Murdoch for almost $1bn but the service has been losing money ever since.

fields.body:
"It's unlikely that the bookies would have approached the likes of Cronje, Shane Warne, Mark Waugh and, apparently, several Pakistanis and not done the same to West Indies players." - Anglo-Caribbean View, April 26, 2000.

That was back in the first few weeks of Cronjegate. I hold the same view now, and can't wait for publication of the interim report on match-fixing by India's Central Bureau of Investigation . According to a leak to the Indian Express (given wider circulation by Scyld Berry in Britain's Sunday Telegraph), the report names two West Indian players in connection with their shock defeat by Kenya in the 1996 World Cup match in Pune, India. The story should be treated with caution until the report is actually published. So far it's just a leak, and no one from the CBI or the WICB seems prepared to confirm whether the story is true.

They need to say yea or nay very quickly, and if it's yea, who the two players are. This story won't go away, and not just because of us journalists - the Caribbean public needs and wants to know. As I felt the England and Wales Cricket Board should have done with Chris Lewis' accusations against three unnamed players, the players named should immediately be summoned to a hearing. If the evidence presented against the alleged participants is credible, they should be suspended. If it's hard evidence, they should be banned from all forms of cricket, even coaching an under-eight side, as Cronje has been. Half measures just won't do.

So is the report accurate? It could be, given the board officials' reaction and that of the Indian Sports Minister SS Dhindsa (as reported by the Indian Express yesterday). Dhindsa said he would ask the Home Ministry to investigate how the contents of the report were leaked to the newspaper. He did not know whether it was true because "I do not even know what the report contains. I had told the CBI that they should hand over the report to us. Then I will study the report and take a legal opinion".

WICB president Pat Rousseau made similar noises in the Jamaica Observer: "It is not prudent to comment at this time because the report has not been published as yet." And he had no prior knowledge of what it may or may not have had to say about West Indies players. "I heard of it just like everybody else," Rousseau said. No one's denying the central charge. And while it's a leap of journalistic logic to take that as a yes, the odds have always pointed to the possibility that Caribbean players were, at the very least, approached.

Remember the match? Kenya's part-timers didn't just beat the West Indies, they thumped them by 73 runs, dismissing them for a laughable 93 after making 166. No disrespect to the east Africans, but their side included a few fat blokes in ill-fitting cricket clothes they clearly hadn't worn for a long time. There was an almighty furore when England lost to "the chicken farmers of Zimbabwe" soon afterwards. Kenya make Zim look like Australia - they're that ordinary. Yet the Windies managed to lose to them, in one of their most witless and embarrassing performances. They've had several low lows since - series whitewashes by Pakistan, South Africa and New Zealand, 54 all out at Lord's and 61 at Headingley last summer - but that loss to Kenya takes the gold medal. A grim-faced Richie Richardson made a curt statement to the media pack (congratulations to Kenya and we played really badly) and left the room without taking questions.

It's one thing to collapse for less than a hundred against England or Pakistan: it's quite another to do it against Kenya. It must be said that Richie Richardson had earned a reputation among players and reporters alike as a straight and decent man. The current captain Jimmy Adams, a member of that side, is also highly regarded by his fellow players. Pat Rousseau did ask Brian Lara about reports of betting on a match in South Africa - reports that emerged during this year's tour of England. Lara denied them very strongly. It has to be said in his favour that it's unlikely that such a juicy story about one of the game's most colourful characters could have remained under wraps when the Cronje story was really really big.

Interestingly, Roger Harper, now the West indies' coach, played in the Kenya game as well as Adams. The report therefore has the potential to leave a really huge stain on Caribbean cricket. Was it just their worst day at the office, or something worse? Say it ain't so, Pat Rousseau.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. His Anglo-Caribbean View appears every other Wednesday on wisden.com. webTitle: Land Rover to review European media business

fields.headline: Land Rover to review European media business
fields.trailText: 10am: Land Rover has announced a full review of its multi-million pound European media buying account, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Land Rover has announced a full review of its multi-million pound European media buying account as it continues its search for a new agency to spearhead its global creative account.

The incumbent agency, Media Plus, and the Frankfurt office of WPP Group's MindShare will both pitch for the business, which is worth £20m each year in the UK alone.

Insiders say that MindShare is the favourite because WPP ad agencies J Walter Thompson, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and Young & Rubicam are all on the Ford roster.

The move comes shortly after the car maker, which was bought by Ford from BMW in May, announced an overhaul of its global creative business.

JWT, O&M and RKCR/Y&R had all been lined up to pitch for the business but it emerged last week that the review has widened to non-WPP agencies including Grey Advertising, Wieden & Kennedy and HHCL & Partners.

fields.headline: Teenage girls' title blames freebies for closure
fields.trailText: 8am: Mollin Publishing has closed its teenage girls' title, Jump, a year after launch, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Mollin Publishing has closed its teenage girls' title, Jump, a year after launch, claiming that rivals had irreparably damaged its margins with freebies.

Managing director John Woollcombe blamed the magazine's demise on the increasingly aggressive practice of cover-mounting - giving away books and other gifts with glossy magazines. Its six staff have been made redundant.

Mr Woollcombe said: "In a sector that has become increasingly tied to cover-mounting, we no longer see the potential margins that we originally projected for the magazine.

"This is something that has changed significantly since launch. It used to be that publishers cover-mounted strategically to boost circulation. Now it's every issue, and there's a pressure to put bigger and bigger gifts on the cover."

He said that the price of the gifts was such that it was creating a barrier to profitability.

Jump, which launched last October, posted an ABC of 80,061 in the six months to 30 June.

The growing use of cover-mounts has been criticised by industry figures who claim it distorts circulation figures as consumers buy the magazine for the free gift rather than the publication.

Senior publishing executives, ranging from the deputy chief executive of BBC Worldwide, Peter Teague to Ian Locks, chairman of the PPA, have slammed the practice, but in the increasingly cut-throat drive for circulation it is seen as increasingly important. The teenage girls' sector has suffered more than other sectors.

In the past few weeks the BBC has launched star, a celebrity-oriented magazine aimed at teenagers.

Mollin will continue to publish its existing titles Men's' Fitness and Shape, with Mr Woollcombe adding that both magazines have shown "strong growth in sales".

fields.headline: Greco no-show stokes BBC/ITV rivalry
fields.trailText: 8am: ITV has accused the BBC of preventing stars from appearing on its shows, after EastEnders actor Michael Greco withdrew from the Frank Skinner Show at the last minute. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV has accused the BBC of preventing stars from appearing in its shows, after EastEnders actor Michael Greco withdrew from the Frank Skinner Show at the last minute.

Mr Greco was due to appear on last night's edition of the ITV chat show, But he pulled out of the programme's Sunday night recording at the London Studios at 5.30pm on Friday, leaving the producers scrambling to find another guest. Comedian Joe Pasquale was eventually booked to appear in his place.

ITV insiders said the incident reflected the bitter rivalry that has been stoked up between the BBC and ITV.

One source suspected the corporation did not want stars from its shows to help boost the commercial channel's audience figures during its new BBC1 ratings offensive.

The BBC told the show's production team that Mr Greco had to withdraw because of another appointment. But staff on the Frank Skinner Show production team said they contacted his agent, who said that Mr Greco had nothing booked in for Sunday evening.

A source close to the Frank Skinner Show said an EastEnders insider had admitted later that the decision to prevent Mr Greco appearing at the last minute had come from the soap's executive producer, John Yorke.

The insider said: "Michael was gagging to do it. He and Frank were on the same Question of Sport panel a few months back and got on really well."

An EastEnders spokeswoman said Mr Greco had not been able to appear because of the show's busy production schedule. She added that he "may appear in a later show" in the current Frank Skinner run.

The spokeswoman also dismissed suggestions that the BBC had a policy of not allowing its stars onto ITV programmes.

"No, not at all," she said, adding that EastEnders actors Natalie Cassidy and Jack Ryder, who play Sonia Jackson and Jamie Mitchell, were due to appear on ITV's This Morning later in the week.

fields.headline: Press heavyweights launch Brussels consultancy
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Peter Guilford, former Brussels correspondent for the Times, has teamed up with ex-BBC political correspondent Nigel Gardner to form a Brussels-based communications company. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Peter Guilford, former Brussels correspondent for the Times, has teamed up with ex-BBC political correspondent Nigel Gardner to form a Brussels-based communications company.

The pair have a wealth of European Union contacts and plan to cash in on their experience by offering "unparalleled knowledge of European media".

Mr Guilford, known to all Brussels-based journalists as deputy spokesman for EU president Romano Prodi, made his mark in the EC as a spokesman for Sir Leon Brittan.

Mr Gardner is the Labour party's communications director in the European Parliament and has worked as EC spokesman on world trade and foreign policy.

The new company, which has yet to be named, will specialise in public affairs and media relations. It opens its doors on December 1 and will be fully funded by London communications consultancy Luther Pendragon.

Charles Stewart-Smith, co-founder of Luther Pendragon, said: "For some time we have needed someone in Brussels for our international clients, but none of the existing companies was quite good enough.

"There are lots of companies doing old-school political lobbying, but they don't understand the relationship between politics and the media in the way that Peter and Nigel do."

Mr Guilford said: "We can bring to clients not just a real insight into the mind of the EU but also an unparalleled knowledge of the European media. Brussels now has the largest press corps in the world - and one with growing influence on political thinking.

"We believe no one else in Brussels offers such an integrated approach with such high-level knowledge."

Luther Pendragon was founded by Mr Stewart-Smith, a former programme editor on ITN's News at Ten, and George Pitcher, former industrial editor at the Observer. It has affiliations with Nichols Dezenhall in Washington and vom Hoff Kommunikation in Dusseldorf.

fields.headline: Newspaper Society seeks new way of measuring regional readership
fields.trailText: 8am: The Newspaper Society has created a working group to find a more effective way of measuring readership for regional newspapers, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Newspaper Society has formed a working group to find a more effective way of measuring readership for regional newspapers.

The group, which will comprise senior managing and marketing executives from the major regional newspaper groups, will try to redress the balance between the advertising industry's need for reliable readership figures and the practice of using circulation as the main yardstick.

Nicholas Rudd-Jones, group managing director of Johnstone Press and the group's chair, said: "Circulation figures are perceived as the established currency, while readership is the prime measure of audience for planner-buyers.

"The group's purpose is to redress this balance and to find a way to measure more fully and accurately the total audience that regional press publishers are delivering through print and online."

The group will give its recommendations to the Newspaper Society's council meeting next spring.

webTitle: Carlton buys HTV in £380m deal with Granada

fields.headline: Carlton buys HTV in £380m deal with Granada
fields.standfirst:
Year of consolidation ends in shared ITV network

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications yesterday completed a £181m deal with Granada Media to buy HTV, the south-west franchise, and to sell its 20% stake in south-eastern broadcaster Meridian.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications yesterday completed a £181m deal with Granada Media to buy HTV, the south-west franchise, and to sell its 20% stake in south-eastern broadcaster Meridian.

The deal, valued at £380m, marks the end of a year of consolidation among ITV companies and restores the balance of power at the network, with Granada and Carlton controlling 51% and 40% respectively.

Analysts described it as being "good for both parties" and predicted it would pave the way for a single ITV company if legislation is introduced to change competition rules.

The deal is effective immediately, although Granada will still control advertising in the last two months of the year.

Granada, which retains control of HTV's Bristol-based production business, had to sell HTV to comply with the regulators after buying the television operations of United News & Media for £1.75bn in the summer.

The arrangement will see it take full control of lucrative Meridian, while Carlton will have a large slice of ITV running from the midlands through to the south west.

Steve Morrison, the chief executive of Granada Media, said the deal would strengthen the partnership between the two, especially regarding the running of ONdigital, its joint venture pay-TV operation.

"It was very important to do this quickly as we are at a stage in the year when companies plan their budgets," he said.

"I am very pleased that we have discharged our responsibilities to the staff and viewers. We had to husband them to a safe home."

Gerry Murphy, Carlton's chief executive officer, also praised the deal and admitted the possibility of floating ONdigital, which claims to have 900,000 subscribers, would be discussed.

"This gives us a real presence in an important part of the UK," he said last night. "Flotation is an option for ONdigital but there is no timetable and we are looking at various options." These are understood to include the possibility of bringing in other partners.

Yesterday's announcement, which came earlier than expected, went down well in the City. Granada's share price climbed 32p to 417p, while Carlton was up 23p to 560p as the London markets closed.

webTitle: Veteran Hollywood writers demand change in the script

fields.headline: Veteran Hollywood writers demand change in the script
fields.standfirst: As Tinseltown's senior scriptwriters call for more work, Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles on how older people are getting a rough deal from television
fields.trailText: As Tinseltown's senior scriptwriters call for more work, Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles on how older people are getting a rough deal from television.
fields.body:
Raymond Chandler was nearly 55 when he wrote his first Hollywood screenplay. The film was Double Indemnity, which Chandler adapted from the James M Cain novel and which starred Barbara Stanwyck and Fred MacMurray, becoming a classic film noir when it appeared in 1944.

Its director, Billy Wilder, remembered the unworldly Chandler arriving at the studio and asking to see what a script looked like.

Times change. And this week, a group of Hollywood writers who claim they are discriminated against because of their age have launched a class action suit against the main networks, studios and agencies.

The group of 28 screenwriters claims that there is a systematic pattern of discrimination against writers over a certain age, regardless of how talented and experienced they are.

A survey by the Writers Guild of America, which is part of the evidence in the suit, showed that 75 per cent of writers aged 30 or under were employed during a year. Only 46 per cent of those in their 40s and 32 per cent in their 50s were.

One of the 28 plaintiffs is Arthur Eisenson, whose credits include the famous Kojak television series. Another plaintiff is Ann Marcus, whose credits include Lassie and Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.

Last year, the issue in the entertainment industry was the lack of characters from ethnic minorities appearing on prime time television shows.

Some of the networks hastily addressed the problem by grafting on extra characters and by much public hand wringing after the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People threatened boycotts of manufacturers who advertised on unresponsive networks.

Now the issue is age. The Screen Actors Guild also announced this week that they are commissioning their own study into the use of older people in prime time television. They are to take a random look at programmes and publish a survey on how older people are represented.

Meanwhile, the writers claim that, because networks are driven by a desire to reach people in their 20s and 30s, they assume that no-one much older than that will be able to write successfully for them.

This has led to writers using their creativity to recast their curricula vitae, lopping a few years off their age and dropping their credits for shows that might seem dated.

When Chandler faced tough deadlines, he demanded - and was given - six secretaries to type out his notes, working round the clock in teams of two, and a limo and driver permanently stationed outside his house to run any errand required.

All the screenwriters want is for someone to hire them to script something other than Grumpy Old Men Three.

fields.headline: Conscription days over for Italy
fields.standfirst: That butt of British derision, the Italian army is facing total upheaval thanks to legislation ending conscription. Everyone knows it was needed, but the country will mourn its military past, says Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.trailText: That butt of British derision, the Italian army is facing total upheaval thanks to legislation ending conscription. Everyone knows it was needed, but the country will mourn its military past, says Rory Carroll in Rome.
fields.body:
Declaring the end of an era, Italy has scrapped conscription to make way for a more professional army, leaving only a legacy of nostalgia, pride and cruel British jokes.

For Italians the army consigned to history yesterday was a source of unity, courage and honour, not laughter. The volunteer force that will take its place, giving women a military role for the first time, makes total sense. But its arrival was tinged with regret.

A young, fractious country born only in 1861, Italy relied on conscription to forge a sense of nationhood by jumbling together southerners and northerners. For generations of Italians who did not even speak the same language, it succeeded.

British schoolboys snigger at Benito Mussolini's incompetent forays into north Africa, and the switch to the Allies as the tide of the second world war changed, but Italians remember their army for other things.

A ragtag, outnumbered force which united the country against the odds was its progenitor. In Alpine valleys it eventually hammered the Austrians and Germans in the first world war, losing 600,000 men in the process. It has been deployed in southern Italy and Sicily to counter terrorism and the mafia.

In peacekeeping and relief operations in Lebanon, Namibia, East Timor and Kurdistan it has earned respect. It has shouldered much of Nato's burden in the Balkans. Not a slick killing machine, but one worthy of pride, reckon most Italians.

Yet the senate voted overwhelmingly to abolish conscription, a procedure started two centuries ago by Napoleon Bonaparte. Over the next seven years the 270,000-strong force will shrink to 190,000 volunteers.

Opposed only by the far-left Refounded Communists, the law is intended to boost the army's aptitude for peace-keeping. As well as short-term savings, an end to conscription means higher salaries, improved training and better equipment.

"While military personnel will be sensibly reduced, the number of troops that we will actually be able to deploy on international missions will increase," said defence minister Sergio Mattarella.

Defence spending is expected to rise 50% in the next few years. Conscription, otherwise known as naja, can be reactivated in times of war or international crisis.

Following similar moves in France and Germany, Italy is to abolish its draft from January 2003; eight of European Union's 17 members now done likewise. Commentators agreed the move was sound but could not help mourning what will be lost.

The force, after all, will change almost beyond recognition. A first generation of female officer cadets have recently signed up after an eight-year campaign by the Association of Aspiring Women Soldiers (Anados). By 2002 women will be able to volunteer for every sector of the armed forces.

Less positively, an elite alpine unit protested that the army's unifying influence would crumble due to the disproportionate number of volunteers expected from the jobless south, lured by the prospect of £635 a month. For a shop assistant on £2-an-hour, that's not bad.

Charities also expressed concern at losing the annual help of around 100,000 conscientious objectors who were allowed to serve their 10-month stint doing voluntary work; grumpy some might have been, but they were like manna from heaven.

The Refounded Communists reiterated the argument, echoed in Germany, that conscripts ensured the army remained linked to the people, thus acting as a bulwark against militarisation and coups.

Yet for males born after 1985, the cut-off date for the new law, such fears are for fuddy duddies. Where those born before may still have to serve their military service as the draft is phased out, they will be the first generation grateful to escape a 10-month sentence of boredom.

After all, sons of wealthy families often studied abroad to try to avoid the call-up, which applied to those aged 18-26, and generations of fathers, uncles and elder brothers have regaled family dinner tables with tales of waste, mismanagement, homesickness and futility.

Few were surprised last month when auditors discovered that the army had stored enough clothing and kit to last for the next 3,000 years. An inspection revealed warehouses bursting with tons of forgotten shoes, boots, underwear, hairbrushes and uniforms, including some for children or extremely small adults. Clearly a spring-clean has been long overdue.

fields.headline: Boston's gangster past bursts free
fields.standfirst: A new public works project has unearthed a long-buried '70s crime spree, as well as possible FBI corruption, says Julian Borger in Boston
fields.trailText: A new public works project has unearthed a long-buried '70s crime spree, as well as possible FBI corruption, says Julian Borger in Boston.
fields.body:
Boston is a city rushing towards its future. The "Big Dig" is hollowing out the belly of the city to allow traffic to pass beneath its growing business district. But the cold damp earth is also discharging ghosts of Boston's past, who have arisen to haunt it.

So far this year, the police have dug up the bodies of six victims of a particularly murderous Irish-American mob called the Winter Hill Gang. The latest body was found within the past few days and investigators believe there are many more.

The gang is supposed to have eliminated of 18 of its enemies and disposed of the remains somewhere under the bustling city.

Most of the bodies have been there since the 1970s, when the poor neighbourhoods of South Boston and Roxbury were ruled by the gangs and wrenched apart by racial tensions. But their significance cannot simply be consigned to the city archives.

The gang leader charged with the killings, James "Whitey" Bulger is still at large, with a price on his head of $250,000 (£171,800) and the number three position on the FBI's ten most wanted list (behind Osama bin Laden and Eric Rudolph, a fundamentalist anti-abortion activist responsible for a string of bombings).

The fact the FBI has not been able to find Whitey Bulger since he disappeared five years ago is all the more embarrassing because it turns out he was one of their own - an informant who was allowed, quite literally, to get away with murder in return for information about rival, mostly Italian, gangs.

It is quite likely Bulger was protected for another reason. His brother William is the former president of the Massachusetts state senate and is now the president of the University of Massachusetts.

The Winter Hill affair has seriously wounded the FBI in Boston and across the country. One of its senior agents, John Connolly, faced charges earlier this month of leaking information to Bulger and his lieutenant, Stephen "The Rifleman" Flemmi, which led the mobsters to two other FBI informants and a potential witness against them. All three were murdered.

"The Boston black eye is a very serious black eye," said Charles Rogovan, an expert on the FBI and organised crime from the Temple University in Philadelphia. "This cuts to the very heart of what the bureau does."

At his trial, Connolly has pleaded not guilty and refused to cooperate with investigators, and there is still no sign of the 71-year-old Bulger, rumoured to be in Ireland. All the FBI can do is call for the doubling of the reward money, and take steps to make sure such a disaster does not reoccur.

Since the Bulger case broke, the FBI has been working on a new ethics code, which will, among other things, require every new agent to take a 15-week ethical training course, including a visit to the Holocaust museum in Washington.

The visit is meant, according to the FBI's Boston chief Charles Prouty "to show them what happens when there is an absence of the rule of law." New agents will also be given a handbook listing the FBI's values including "uncompromising institutional and personal integrity".

It sounds like a tall order, but the transformation currently underway across the city may yet intervene to soften the ethical and professional dilemmas complicating the FBI's struggle with organised crime.

The old neighbourhoods and their tight-knit ethnic clans are being loosened and broken apart by gentrification. The gangs are either dissolving or moving into white collar crime. The days of Whitey Bulger have passed, even if he remains maddeningly out of Boston's grasp.

webTitle: Clinton hints at Middle East talks in Washington

fields.headline: Clinton hints at Middle East talks in Washington
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The US president, Bill Clinton, has raised the possibility of inviting the Israeli and Palestinian leaders separately to Washington for talks.
fields.body:
The US president, Bill Clinton, has raised the possibility of inviting the Israeli and Palestinian leaders separately to Washington for talks.

Mr Clinton made a talks offer in a 30 minute phone call to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, in which he urged him to implement three commitments made at the Sharm el-Sheikh summit in Egypt earlier this month, including steps to end the violence.

The commitments were to take concrete steps to reduce bloodshed, to work on a fact-finding inquiry into the failure of the peace process and to look for a way back to the negotiation table.

A White House spokesman said any attempt to break the cycle of bloodshed in the Middle East would be dependent on how the two sides lived up to commitments made earlier this month at a summit in Egypt. "At this point," the spokesman insisted, the possibility of inviting the two leaders separately to Washington is "only a possibility."

But he stressed that implementation of the first two agreements were not preconditions to hosting separate meetings with Mr Arafat and Mr Barak in Washington.

The president has been in contact with Mr Barak in recent days, according to his spokesman, but has not yet broached the idea of a meeting in Washington directly with him.

An Israeli embassy spokesman, Mark Regev, said he has "no information whatsover about Clinton's suggestion of a possible meeting".

In four weeks of fighting between Israelis and Palestinians, 127 people have died. The only brief break in the violence followed the meeting between Mr Arafat and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, at Sharm el-Sheik on October 17.

webTitle: Cheer for Amazon as losses ease

fields.headline: Cheer for Amazon as losses ease
fields.standfirst: Leading online retailer defies analysts predictions as sales leap 80%
fields.trailText: Leading online retailer defies analysts predictions as sales leap 80%
fields.body:
Amazon.com, the world's largest online retailer, provided some cheer to the depressed internet sector last night when it revealed that net losses had narrowed at the same time as sales had risen 80%.

The Seattle-based company predicted that losses would fall further next year and that the group would be cash flow positive in the last nine months of 2001.

Warren Jensen, the company's chief financial officer, said that focused on the company's financial health. "We are driving toward profitability."

Amazon also predicted that its cash position at year-end would be over $1bn (£690m).

The emphasis on cash flow and profitability comes after the company's share price has been crushed by doubts that it would ever make money.

Shares in the group have more than halved since June amid doubts that it would ever be able to repay investors in its corporate bonds. The company is continuing to burn through the money it raised from less hostile investors earlier this year.

Shares in Amazon closed at $29.56 yesterday, a fraction of their record high of $113 reached in December last year. The positive third-quarter results brought a brief rally in after-hours trading in New York, however, when the shares rose 10%.

Amazon lost $68m, or 25 cents a share, in the three months to the end of September, compared with a loss of $79m, or 26 cents per share, for the same period last year. Analysts had expected the company to lose 33 cents a share, according to estimates compiled by First Call/Thomson Financial.

Sales in the quarter were also better than expected at $638m, up 79% from a year ago. However, $20m of these revenues were at cost sales to Toysrus.com as part of an inventory reduction plan agreed when the two companies announced their joint toy-selling deal earlier this year.

Customers in Britain, France and Germany contributed to a 121% increase in Amazon's international sales in the quarter. The company has 3.9m international customers out of a total of more than 25m.

Analysts seized on the improvement in the company's gross margins from 20% to 26% as a sign that the bargain basement deals that defined early online retailing were coming to an end. The company said that fourth-quarter margins would be lower but still "up strongly", compared with last year.

Wall Street analysts welcomed the third-quarter results last night. Henry Blodget, analyst at Merrill Lynch and long-time bull of Amazon, said that signs of improving profit margins were particularly welcome in a TV interview. He added that the results should ease concerns about the company's viability going forward. "This ought to make people a little bit more comfortable that they don't have to raise money," he said.

Company executives hedged their bullish predictions about the all-important Christmas selling season as well as next year. The statement attending the results warned: "Given the emerging nature of online retail, potential changes in general economic conditions, and the various other risk factors discussed below, actual results may differ materially."

It went on to list 23 other risk factors, ranging from "the rate of growth of the internet and online commerce" to "Amazon.com's limited operating history".

In spite of these warnings, the company predicted that sales in the last three months of the year would be between $950m and $1.05bn, while pro forma operating losses would be between 5% and 8% of sales.

webTitle: Scathing BSE report blames civil servants

fields.headline: Scathing BSE report blames civil servants
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The brunt of the blame for the BSE fiasco will be placed on civil servants in the long-awaited report into the crisis which is published tomorrow - despite criticisms of some former ministers.
fields.body:
The brunt of the blame for the BSE fiasco will be placed on civil servants in the long-awaited report into the crisis which is published tomorrow - despite criticisms of some former ministers.

Institutional failures within the Whitehall culture, including an inability to trust the public with information, turf wars between departments and a tendency to try to second-guess what ministers might want to hear are all cited in the 16-volume verdict, which was compiled after more than two years of public hearings.

However, people hoping to find scapegoats from previous Tory administrations will be disappointed.

Senior Whitehall sources have suggested that the inquiry team headed by Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers had made "no searing indictments" of individuals, although officials and ministers whose behaviour is thought to have fallen outside a range of "reasonable" responses are listed.

Despite speculation to the contrary, John Gummer, an agriculture minister during the crisis, does not get slapped down for the infamous publicity stunt in which he fed a burger to his daughter Cordelia to demonstrate the safety of beef, although it is believed he faces other criticisms.

There is already acute embarrassment within the government at the report's chronicling of the way civil servants and other advisers apparently sought to put the best possible spin on the scientific evidence available, failing to change their outlook as the scientific community's concerns about the risks of BSE transferring to humans increased.

The political climate of the Thatcher and Major years, the clamour for deregulation, an apparent demand to produce success stories rather than admit problems, and the experience of the salmonella-in-eggs affair in 1988 emerge as factors in Whitehall attitudes.

The report alleges that civil servants were focused on day-to-day governance rather than contingency planning for any worst case scenario.

The health department, which has largely avoided the opprobrium heaped on agriculture officials during the 1990s, will share criticism for failing to recognise the shift in scientific opinion on the potentially disastrous consequences of the disease.

It was reluctant to support an offal ban in 1989, now seen as the most important anti-BSE safeguard, because such an action went beyond the advice of eminent scientists.

The then agriculture minister, John MacGregor, justified the offal ban on the grounds that huge numbers of cows with "hidden BSE" were entering the food chain before clinical signs were evident, on emerging evidence that some offals could potentially be infective, and because it was a "belt and braces" precautionary measure.

Douglas Hogg, the beleaguered agriculture minister at the height of the crisis, will emerge with more credit than might have been expected.

He felt new scientific information establishing a strong circumstantial link between exposure to infected meat and the death of several young people from a new incurable disease - new variant CJD - justified further tough measures to protect food, but he was over-ruled by cabinet colleagues.

They felt let down by previous scientific advice which they saw as "defective" because it had emphasised the remote risk of BSE's transmission to humans.

They saw no reason to rely on new advice and rejected any consideration of compensation for the victims, arguing that the government had followed the latest scientific advice throughout the epidemic.

The inquiry team is understood to criticise the way officials and ministers chose to "cherry pick" good news from the first inquiry report into BSE, headed by the Oxford professor Richard Southwood and published in 1989, which concluded that "it was most unlikely that BSE will have any implications for human health".

Thus for years, even as scientific uncertainty about the potential threat to the public was continuing, policy was based on the Southwood conclusion.

The report will say the government did not take adequate note of the Southwood inquiry's caveats, including a warning that if its assessment were proved wrong, the implications would be "extremely serious".

Any warning of potential risk from outside the government was also played down.

Whitehall sources say there will be greater scepticism about scientific advice in future. They promise greater government honesty over risks to public health.

But the revelations just last week that vaccines using material from British cows were banned from use only on Friday has further damaged credibility.

There is a feeling in some parts of Whitehall that the inquiry has not got to the heart of how government works, depending too much on the written record of memos, minutes and briefing papers from civil servants. No ministerial private secretaries were asked to appear before the inquiry, despite their inside knowledge.

Lord Phillips's recommendation for a centrally funded care package for the victims of the human form of BSE - 84 so far - has been accepted in principle by ministers.

There is still debate over how compensation should be awarded, either leaving a new trust to determine individual sums or a tariff of payments reflecting broad bands of family circumstances.

Likely to be criticised:

 Civil servants

Richard Packer, permanent secretary at agriculture, 1993-2000

Keith Meldrum, chief veterinary officer, 1988-97

Donald Acheson, chief medical officer, 1983-91

Kenneth Calman, chief medical officer, 1991-98

 Ministers

John MacGregor, agriculture minister, 1987-89

John Gummer, agriculture minister, 1989-93

Kenneth Clarke, health secretary, 1988-90

The report alleges that civil servants were focused on day-to-day governance rather than contingency planning for any worst case scenario. The health department, which has largely avoided the opprobrium heaped on agriculture officials during the 1990s, will share criticism for failing to recognise the shift in scientific opinion on the potentially disastrous consequences of the disease. It was reluctant to support an offal ban in 1989, now seen as the most important anti-BSE safeguard, because such an action went beyond the advice of eminent scientists. The then agriculture minister, John MacGregor, justified the offal ban on the grounds that huge numbers of cows with "hidden BSE" were entering the food chain before clinical signs were evident, on emerging evidence that some offals could potentially be infective, and because it was a "belt and braces" precautionary measure. Douglas Hogg, the beleaguered agriculture minister at the height of the crisis, will emerge with more credit than might have been expected. He felt new scientific information establishing a strong circumstantial link between exposure to infected meat and the death of several young people from a new incurable disease - new variant CJD - justified further tough measures to protect food, but he was over-ruled by cabinet colleagues. They felt let down by previous scientific advice which they saw as "defective" because it had emphasised the remote risk of BSE's transmission to humans. They saw no reason to rely on new advice and rejected any consideration of compensation for the victims, arguing that the government had followed the latest scientific advice throughout the epidemic. The inquiry team is understood to criticise the way officials and ministers chose to "cherry pick" good news from the first inquiry report into BSE, headed by the Oxford professor Richard Southwood and published in 1989, which concluded that "it was most unlikely that BSE will have any implications for human health". Thus for years, even as scientific uncertainty about the potential threat to the public was continuing, policy was based on the Southwood conclusion. The report will say the government did not take adequate note of the Southwood inquiry's caveats, including a warning that if its assessment were proved wrong, the implications would be "extremely serious". Any warning of potential risk from outside the government was also played down. Whitehall sources say there will be greater scepticism about scientific advice in future. They promise greater government honesty over risks to public health. But the revelations just last week that vaccines using material from British cows were banned from use only on Friday has further damaged credibility. There is a feeling in some parts of Whitehall that the inquiry has not got to the heart of how government works, depending too much on the written record of memos, minutes and briefing papers from civil servants. No ministerial private secretaries were asked to appear before the inquiry, despite their inside knowledge. Lord Phillips's recommendation for a centrally funded care package for the victims of the human form of BSE - 84 so far - has been accepted in principle by ministers. There is still debate over how compensation should be awarded, either leaving a new trust to determine individual sums or a tariff of payments reflecting broad bands of family circumstances. webTitle: Arts: Henry Moore exhibition in China

fields.headline: Cultural revelation
fields.standfirst: John Prescott made the headlines last week when he opened a Henry Moore exhibition in China. But what was British art doing in a Beijing park in the first place?  David Newnham reports
fields.trailText: John Prescott made the headlines last week when he opened a Henry Moore exhibition in China. But what was British art doing in a Beijing park in the first place?
fields.body:
It was the sort of story guaranteed to lift the spirits of any Daily Telegraph reader on an autumn morning. John Prescott, crossing a lake by VIP launch after opening an exhibition of Henry Moore bronzes in a Beijing park, had supposedly mouthed a string of inanities about the work of his fellow Yorkshireman. Weren't "He didn't like heads, did he?" and "Hands are very hard to get right" precisely the sort of remarks that could be expected from a man who drives two Jags?

Within hours last Tuesday, the London Evening Standard was telling the same tale under the headline "Look no hands"; by Thursday the Daily Mail had put together an entire spoof page entitled Prescott's A-Z of Art. No matter that Prescott had later explained that "a lot of the critics make the point... about hands and heads", and that many Telegraph readers might agree. History had been written and prejudices reinforced.

But not so fast. How did Prescott, in China to attend trade talks, end up opening a British Council exhibition of Moore's sculptures? Authentic or otherwise, the thoughts of Prescott prove to be the least interesting aspect of the affair.

Like much else in Beijing, Beihai Park has no real British equivalent. A willow-pattern place of water and temples, pagodas and lotus flowers, it is a spiritual recreation ground for many of the city's residents. Each morning they use it for singing, dancing and t'ai-chi. On the morning of the official unveiling, the asphalt is wet with Chinese calligraphy, ephemeral graffiti done in water from the lake for the edification of passers by. And already, the bronzes are pulling crowds, as they have done every day since a team from the Henry Moore Foundation in England set them up.

There are 12 pieces, and each has had a uniformed guard since it was found that Chinese children had a tendency to treat the works as vast, slippery climbing frames. But the guards are happy to allow touching.

Right from the outset, the exhibition has attracted people of all ages and most classes. "People in their 20s and 30s have been waiting for this for months," says Michael O'Sullivan, cultural counsellor at the British embassy in Beijing. "They have studied Moore's work, and they know its significance." But O'Sullivan is more interested in what older Beijingers make of the sculptures, and he has spent many hours canvassing their opinions. "They want to know what they are, what they represent and what they mean," he says. "I tell them that in western art a work doesn't have to mean what the artist says it means. And they quite like that."

The cultural counsellor has just been talking to a man who started off saying that it wasn't appropriate to have such contemporary sculptures in Beihai Park, where they would be juxtaposed with ancient monuments. "He was worried that some of them were too pointy. It's a feng shui thing. But he ended up asking if we would be leaving one of them here. He thought we should!"

While the Henry Moore Foundation may be less than happy to see one of its bronzes take permanent root in Beijing soil - the show will tour to Shanghai and Guangzhou next spring anyway - the suggestion is clearly music to O'Sullivan's ears, since one of the aims of the exhibition is to raise the profile of the UK in China.

"Not many people here have much awareness of Britain," he says, "and those who do have a very traditional image. They imagine that London resembles a scene from David Copperfield, or is full of men wearing bowler hats and carrying umbrellas."

Given that China will soon be the world's biggest economy, this is an alarming state of affairs, says O'Sullivan. And while the British Council is "not a flag-waving organisation", it is keen to support the huge changes that are happening in Chinese society, if only because "there would be far-reaching consequences for the rest of the world if the process of change were suddenly to fall apart".

Last year the council screened an entire series of The Bill, and at the same time it introduced Chinese lawyers to the concept of the jury by mounting several mock jury trials. This was all part of the process of nurturing change, while at the same time blowing away the image of pea-soupers and Beefeaters.

Hence the exhibition of sculptures in the city. But why pick Henry Moore, an artist who died in 1986, and can hardly be considered at the cutting edge of British art? Although they are hazy about British law enforcement, Beijingers are no strangers to other western phenomena. This vast metropolis now has 80 KFCs and more than 100 McDonald's; Madonna is number one in the Chinese charts.

But for all the savvy in matters of popular culture, the Chinese arts establishment is still isolated. Not only can local artists still find works banned for political incorrectness, the work of artists from other countries - even Asian countries - is virtually unknown in schools.

Initially, the British Council had in mind a Hockney exhibition, but the Chinese said they were more interested in Moore. It proved to be the ideal choice. The Chinese have a long tradition of appreciating natural forms, and Beijing's parks are full of eroded rocks and boulders erected as curiosities and objects of contemplation. Yet Chinese sculpture remains firmly in the beaux arts tradition, and the sculpture parks are full of naturalistic figures exhorting the viewer to put body and soul behind the latest five-year plan. Moore, on the other hand, took natural forms and used them as a starting point for works that echoed classical forms, yet said something new. The transition from the figurative to the abstract and from nature to art is clear for all to see.

If Moore's work seems tailor-made for a Chinese public looking to have its horizons expanded, then his life also has many points of contact with Chinese ideals. The son of a coal miner and a lifelong socialist, Moore was injured during the first world war. Yet he triumphed over adversity and became enormously prolific, even turning down a knighthood along the way. Add to this the fact that his major works are designed to be shown outdoors, where, perforce, they will be encountered by ordinary people, and the logic of Moore in China, as the exhibition is entitled, becomes startlingly obvious.

But if the reasons for mounting the show are compelling, the practical problems involved were to prove almost insurmountable. Stand outside the Soviet-built China Art Gallery and you might think yourself in 1950s Moscow. But step inside, and you could be in a Stanley Spencer resurrection painting. For this is where 106 of Moore's smaller works are being shown, and today, as they emerge from their crates, they are greeted by pandemonium.

"Yesterday there were 25 people in this room watching what we were doing," says the white-gloved David Mitchinson, curator at the Henry Moore Foundation. "They were asking why we were painting the columns, why we had put up false walls, why the pieces were crated in this way... They were fascinated." And why were they putting up false walls, exactly? Why were they coating the place with 300 gallons of whitish-grey paint, even taping over black skirting boards that spoiled the sense of space?

It had taken two years to negotiate the use of Beihai Park, and only as the crated sculptures were being loaded on to a ship at Felixstowe Docks had the Chinese authorities sent the final written OK. On arriving in China, the crates could not be trucked into Beijing by day because of traffic restrictions, and so a procession had made its way into the city by night, while a man perched atop the highest crate kept a lookout for low bridges.

Yet even after all this, the foundation's travelling exhibition team was insisting on remodelling the city's premier gallery. Why? Because they wanted to give Beijingers a total Western Art Experience the like of which they had never known before.

It all seems a little excessive, until you talk to the people who work the magic - people like Malcolm Woodward, a sculptor who can position a Henry Moore bronze in the corner of a Beijing park with such exquisite sensitivity that to remove it again will seem like an act of desecration. To discuss Henry Moore with Woodward - just to hear him talk about the precise colour of a plinth - is to have your eyes opened a little wider. Which is probably why John Prescott spent most of his brief voyage on the VIP boat doing just that. "He was really interested in the details," says Woodward. But who wants to read that in their morning paper?

fields.headline: Spawn of Linda Blair
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney:  Horror and humour
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney: Horror and humour
fields.body:
You may have thought that genre in-joking could not go much further than the Scream series, those drolly self-reflexive horror films about horror films. But then came Scary Movie, which parodied not only Scream itself, but every other film in which over-sexed high-schoolers were filleted by maniacs with meat cleavers.

Scary Movie's enthusiastically encyclopedic spoof was originally planned under the working title Scream If You Know What I Did Last Halloween. And oddly enough, the working title of Scream itself was - you guessed it - Scary Movie. So the circle of self-reference seems to be closed. Or not quite - last week's Variety featured an ad for a film currently in post- production, with a poster illustration awkwardly echoing both Scream and Scary Movie. The title is Shriek if You Know What I Did Last Friday the 13th. It can't be long before we get a mock chiller about a critic driven insane by reviewing too many mock chillers: Stab Me if You've Heard this One Before.

The standard critical reaction, when faced with one genre spoof too many, is to protest that you can't parody what is already a parody. Oh, but you can, and only too profitably, as Scary Movie proves. The blame is probably to be laid at the feet of Scream director Wes Craven, who himself produced the best self-conscious horror riff ever, with his film Wes Craven's New Nightmare, a belated coup de grace to his own Nightmare on Elm Street series. Perhaps he should have left it at that, instead of letting Scream spawn all these films out-parodying and out-ironising each other.

Halloween is a traditional time to moan about how much better horror used to be when it took itself seriously. Last year, in fact, things looked hopeful. The Blair Witch Project was a refreshing anomaly that opted wholeheartedly for the power of suggestion - whatever you think you saw in the shadows in that old dark house, someone you know will have imagined far worse. But Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, the sequel released this week, is afflicted with the current self-consciousness that the first film so compellingly avoided. I won't pre-empt Friday's review; suffice to say that the heart sinks the moment you realise that the film's teenage characters are all obsessive fans of the Blair Witch Project.

One film that took horror in absolute earnest was The Exorcist, soon to be released in a director's cut, and now notable less for the ludicrous oogly-boogly vileness of Linda Blair's demonic metamorphoses than for its genteel decor, 70s knitwear and curiously sluggish pacing. It seems extraordinary that the film could ever have reduced audiences to dribbling panic, but if you read contemporary accounts, what comes up again and again is a feeling that the film genuinely invoked the presence of evil - which is how some people felt about the Blair Witch Project. Dated it may be, but William Friedkin's intentions are still clear - he wants to make your flesh creep.

The Exorcist's time has come again - Linda Blair is surely the inspiring spirit behind Scary Movie's excess, in which spurting slime of every description floods the screen. It may be, though, that the new wave of teenage horror movies are not horror, properly speaking, but simply teen movies - stories of initiation, dares and dormitory bonding.

Take the element of fear away, and there's very little difference between the genre-conscious chillers and the current cycle of teen gross-out comedies, the neo-Porky's genre of American Pie, Road Trip et al. The audiences are the same; all that's different is the nature of the bodily fluids. Scary Movie is simply the point of intersection where the two genres admit their equivalence; and both genres hark back to the teenage bad manners of Linda Blair projectile-vomiting pea soup. These days, of course, she'd be doing it to the strains of Eminem, rather than Tubular Bells - surely a mercy.

webTitle: No hedging - markets bet it's Bush

fields.headline: No hedging - markets bet it's Bush
fields.standfirst:
Speculators feel Republicans' man has a 60% chance of being president

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: While surveys of public opinion about the presidential campaign may throw up widely conflicting messages from the voters, the hard-nosed futures market is pointing forcefully towards a victory for George W Bush.
fields.body:
While surveys of public opinion about the presidential campaign may throw up widely conflicting messages from the voters, the hard-nosed futures market is pointing forcefully towards a victory for George W Bush.

The University of Iowa has run a "winner-takes-all" futures market for the presidential election since 1988, and its predictions have been right every time. Speculators assess the two candidates as though they were commodities and invest in one of them.

Last week the value of the Gore contract was 51.6 cents, but at the beginning of this week it had slipped to 37.5 cents. Mr Bush, who had been trailing in the preceding weeks, was seen by Monday as suitable investment: the value of his contract jumped on Monday from 48 cents to 62 cents.

This effectively means that speculators believed that he had a better than 62% chance of victory in the November 7 election and have been putting their money behind it.

The system is seen as giving a better picture of the chances of the two candidates, since people stand to lose money if they are wrong. Those giving opinions to pollsters are notoriously fickle, and uncertain whether they will turn up to vote.

This week's valuations show a big shift from the golden days of the Gore campaign: after the Democrats' convention in Los Angeles in August, his speech and the smacking kiss he gave his wife made him worth 71 cents.

But as his campaign has stumbled, and with his failure to deliver a knock-out blow in any of the three presidential debates, his valuation has tumbled.

Speculators can also bet on the popular vote, and here they still agree that the final outcome will be very close. Mr Bush is valued here at 49.7 to Mr Gore's 48.6 cents.

The futures market apart, gamblers who fancy a flutter on the result have a problem: it is illegal in the US to bet on the outcome of a presidential race.

Anthony Curtis of the Huntington Press, a Nevada-based gambling newsletter, said: "I've heard of it being offered illegally but most bookies don't want to fool around with that sort of thing."

In traditional surveys the Green party candidate, Ralph Nader, who is causing concern to Mr Gore in key western states, is polling between 3% and 5%.

fields.headline: Glaswegian mumbles his lines
fields.standfirst: Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: The Commons met in sombre mood yesterday. MPs had just heard that Sir Edward Heath is soon to retire, having performed one last great disservice to the house he loved. He had insisted on a voting system so convoluted and unfair it produced Michael Martin as the new Speaker.
fields.body:
The Commons met in sombre mood yesterday. MPs had just heard that Sir Edward Heath is soon to retire, having performed one last great disservice to the house he loved. He had insisted on a voting system so convoluted and unfair it produced Michael Martin as the new Speaker.

Sir Ted has been there for an entire half century. He spent the latter 25 years, following the choice of Margaret Thatcher as Tory leader, in a monstrous grump, or "the incredible sulk" as it is sometimes called. He wasn't there yesterday. MPs had to cope with their choice without his wise help, guidance and foul temper.

"Orrrder, orrrder" said Mr Martin, for the first time in his new job.

I have had some chippy email from Glasgow complaining about my animadversions on his accent. Actually Mr Martin has rather a fine brogue, as rich and textured as the deep-fried Jaffa cake supper which is (and this is true) a popular meal in his home town. The problem is not going to be that we can't understand him, but that we can't hear. Some of the time he seems to be talking to himself. At other times, his sentences tail gently away.

"Message from the Queen!" said a whip. It was a rather affecting moment. In Mr Martin's neck of the woods, a message from the Queen would normally be to the effect that the old man had passed out there from an excess of whisky and 40 shilling beer. No more. "Orrder. We have now come to questions," he said, almost inaudibly.

Backbenchers rose to ask health questions, each one preceded by a sycophantic word of congratulation - even from Crispin Blunt, one of eight Tories who actually voted against him in the final division. Christopher Gill made a rambling speech and Mr Martin mumbled at him; whatever he said had the admirable effect of shutting Mr Gill up. Liam Fox asked a question and then yelled at the reply. "Ah canna have yew shooting across a' tha minister. Y'asked a question and he's answerin' it, maybe not to yer satisfaction..." His voice disappeared like the last bathwater down the plug hole.

Actually, there is no such thing as a bad Speaker. MPs are not year 10 schoolboys reducing a supply teacher to a whimpering heap. They need the Commons to function, and in the end, however much they grumble, they will give Mr Martin the support he needs. If they can make out what he's saying.

Finally, I may have solved a mystery. Is John Prescott French? As we march into the thicket of a Prescott speech, hacking at the convoluted grammar and tearing the neologisms off our trousers, our faces are brushed by sinister dangling articles. Yesterday, making a statement about the Hatfield rail crash, he spoke about "the honourable friend, Lord Macdonald", who "witnessed the first hand in the aftermath of the accident".

He didn't want to blame "the privatisation" at this time, he said, but he did talk about "the safety". Something was supposed to be done "by the June but they hadn't done it by the October".

Of course it is the French who talk like this (or the this, as Mr Prescott might say.) They have la politesse and la France where we would just say "politeness" or "France".

I see him as Jean Presquotte, a young lad raised in the port of Marseilles.

Bored, frustrated and certain that he can never make a life for himself at home, he stows away on a British ship bound for the Humber. Arriving in Hull he is dazzled by the white phone boxes, apparently made from solid ivory, the grandeur of Paragon station and by Ferensway, the Champs Elysees of the north. Determined to make good, he almost learns the language...
