webTitle: Sinn Fein will be told to fly the flag

fields.headline: Sinn Fein will be told to fly the flag
fields.standfirst:
New regulation seen as gesture of support to Trimble who faces hardline unionist calls to withdraw from power-sharing executive

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein ministers in Northern Ireland are to be forced to fly the union flag over their departments, the government announced yesterday in an attempt to shore up the position of David Trimble ahead of a crunch meeting of the Ulster Unionist council on Saturday.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein ministers in Northern Ireland are to be forced to fly the union flag over their departments, the government announced yesterday in an attempt to shore up the position of David Trimble ahead of a crunch meeting of the Ulster Unionist council on Saturday.

MPs will pass a regulation in the Commons this week which will ensure that the flag flies over the departments run by Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun on Remembrance Sunday next month and on the birthday of the Prince of Wales two days later.

Sinn Fein, which said that its ministers should not be forced to work in a British environment, angrily rejected the government announcement.

Alex Maskey, the party's chief whip, said that he would seek legal advice, adding: "Peter Mandelson has to get the message that nationalists are not second class citizens."

Government sources yesterday played down the timing of the announcement, saying that the issue needed to be resolved ahead of Remembrance Sunday. But there was little doubt that Mr Mandelson has offered an important concession to the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble ahead of Saturday's meeting of his party's ruling council.

Hardline unionists have called the meeting in an attempt to force Mr Trimble to withdraw from Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive in protest at what they claim is the slow progress on disarmament by the IRA.

There is speculation that Mr Trimble will hang on as first minister, but at the risk of damage to the peace process. It is understood that the UUP leader may appease his critics by setting a deadline for the IRA to begin the actual process of decommissioning, hardening his position. Hardline unionists have dismissed the international inspection of IRA arms as unsatisfactory.

Downing Street said that the announcement was not linked to Saturday's meeting. The prime minister's spokesman said that Mr Mandelson had used his powers because the Northern Ireland assembly had been unable to reach agreement on the flags issue.

"We recognise this won't satisfy any one side completely but we believe it's a practical solution which steers a course through a difficult problem," the spokesman said. Under the regulation, the union flag will have to fly at full mast over selected buildings on 17 days of the year. These include obscure celebrations such as the birthday of the Countess of Wessex.

webTitle: Prescott refuses to back Railtrack chief

fields.headline: Prescott refuses to back Railtrack chief
fields.standfirst:
I'll wait for inquiry says deputy PM as further worries are highlighted by leaked letter attacking 'appalling' workmanship on Leeds line

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday pointedly refused to give his backing to the chief executive of Railtrack as more worries over the maintenance of Britain's railways were revealed.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall, Keith Harper and Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday pointedly refused to give his backing to the chief executive of Railtrack as more worries over the maintenance of Britain's railways were revealed.

Speaking after delivering a Commons statement on last week's Hatfield crash, which occurred while he was in China, Mr Prescott rejected a call by Bernard Jenkin, shadow transport minister, that he publicly support Mr Corbett.

Mr Corbett's offer of resignation was spurned by Railtrack's board, but Mr Prescott said: "If the argument is whether Mr Corbett has done the job rightly or wrongly, I'll wait for an inquiry to make some judgment about that."

Mr Prescott said his junior Lord Macdonald's apparent endorsement of Mr Corbett last week referred to the relief that there would be continuity within the rail industry.

The deputy prime minister drew attention to the fact that the broken rail which contributed towards the Hatfield crash had been known about in March and had still not been mended. "That does seem to be a management failure. There was an offer of a resignation and I assume a resignation means that something had gone wrong on behalf of the management."

Mr Prescott's comments came as it was revealed that Railtrack had sent a scathing letter about a major track repair scheme to Balfour Beatty, contractors on the Hatfield line repairs, only two weeks before the derailment.

In a letter leaked to BBC North, the company describes work on approaches to Leeds station, one of the busiest on the national network, as far below required standards.

The letter from Mick Pollard of Railtrack calls workmanship "appalling" and describes how the safety inspection team from Railtrack witnessed the effects at first hand.

A strongly worded memo from Railtrack to managers refers to "crap efficiency" at Leeds and a failure by Balfour Beatty to manage the work tightly enough.

Mr Pollard said joints requiring four connecting bolts had been left with only three because of a shortage, protective covers were lifted off or broken, and cables had been left loose in ballast rather than being pinned to sleepers. This demonstrated ignorance "coupled with a lack of discipline and rigour among the supervisors".

That memo followed another leaked letter from Railtrack to the company revealed last week in which Railtrack complained that 82% of faults on the east coast main line had not been rectified. It warned Balfour Beatty that each defect could have led to a derailment.

The revelations came as Connex, which runs the south central London surburban franchise, became the first train company sacked since privatisation. The services are to be handed over to GoVia, 35% owned by the French state owned railway, SNCF. GoVia also runs Thameslink and Thames, and is involved in the Paddington tragedy.

Mike Grant, the shadow strategic rail authority's chief executive, said GoVia had promised to replace all slam door trains by 2004 and to spend £1.5bn over its 20 year franchise. It had undertaken to ensure all new trains after 2003 would be fitted with a train protection warning system.

webTitle: The story of Dr Jekyll, Mr Hyde and Fanny, the angry wife who burned the first draft

fields.headline: The story of Dr Jekyll, Mr Hyde and Fanny, the angry wife who burned the first draft
fields.trailText: One of the enduring mysteries of English literature was solved last night when it emerged that the first, impassioned draft of Robert Louis Stevenson's Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde was destroyed by the author's wife.
fields.body:
One of the enduring mysteries of English literature was solved last night when it emerged that the first, impassioned draft of Robert Louis Stevenson's Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde was destroyed by the author's wife.

Fanny Stevenson burned it after dismissing it to a friend as "a quire full of utter nonsense". She said - of what became the world's most admired and profound horror story - "He said it was his greatest work. I shall burn it after I show it to you".

Stevenson, an invalid almost deranged by tuberculosis and the effects of medicinal cocaine, had to spend the next three days feverishly rewriting and redrafting the 30,000-word story by hand.

Within weeks, the new version of his pioneering novel about split personality was in print. Despite Fanny's view, it was an instant bestseller. Sermons were preached on it in thousands of churches, including St Paul's cathedral, London. It was pirated in the US and in translation.

It rescued the Stevensons from acute debt. For the first time, the couple had enough money to live comfortably.

Some 115 years later, Fanny's deed has been disclosed in a two-page letter on pages torn from a notebook. It was written by her in 1885 to Stevenson's close friend and fellow poet WE Henley.

Henley, who was one-legged, was the model for Long John Silver in Treasure Island. He is still known for the lines: "I am the master of my fate,/I am the captain of my soul".

'Distasteful'

The letter is expected to fetch some £1,500 at auction at Phillips in London on November 17. Yesterday, Liz Merry head of Phillips's book department, said the writer's wife apparently threw the manuscript on the fire because "she considered Dr Jekyll and the duality of man rather distasteful.

"It's my belief that she thought Dr Jekyll, which was partly based on a dream, was not worthy of him. She was also uneasy because he was writing it for a "shilling shocker" series of novels. It is ironic that it turned out to be one of his most successful books."

But other sources believe Fanny acted in a spirit of literary criticism rather than artistic vandalism. One biographer says she felt the first draft did not sufficiently bring out the theme of allegory which was to make the story so compelling to psychologists like Sigmund Freud.

Despite the Hollywood films which have been based on it, Stevenson's atmospheric novel contains no sex and little violence, though these are strongly implied.

But what is clear is that Fanny, with creditors at their door, was in despair about her sick husband's ability to produce publishable work.

In an earlier letter, she wrote: "Louis is possessed of a story that he will try to work at. To stop him seems to annoy him to such a degree that I am letting him alone as the better alternative; but I fear it will only be energy wasted - as all his late work has been."

The Scots author was recovering at the time from a haemorrhage and from the death of a close friend. He said he he wrote out of hunger and the need to survive "a few years more" to support his family.

The germ of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde came to him in a cocaine-induced nightmare in their Bournemouth home. His screams aroused Fanny, who indignantly woke him. "Why did you wake me?" he said. "I was dreaming a fine bogey tale."

Dawn found him writing frantically to capture and elaborate the dream on paper. He wrote the first draft in three days at an extraordinary rate of 10,000 words a day. Stephen King, the most modern prolific horror author, is content if he can achieve 1,000 words a day.

But scholars knew before yesterday that Fanny disliked the first draft. Before her letter was discovered, the Stevenson scholar, Alanna Knight, wrote: "Angrily, Stevenson threw it on the fire. For the next three days the family walked on tiptoe glimpsing him sitting up in bed, surrounded by written and torn-up pages". Together, the first and final drafts took him a total of six days.

Fanny wrote afterwards: "That an invalid in my husband's condition performed the manual labour alone seems incredible. He was suffering from continual haemorrhages and hardly allowed to speak, his conversation carried on by means of a slate and pencil."

Stevenson himself told a critic dourly: "The wheels of Byles the Butcher [a joking reference to his creditors, taken from George Eliot's novel Middlemarch] drive exceedingly swiftly."

Of his story, with its haunted moral that "man is not truly one, but truly two", he wrote to a friend: "I send you herewith a Gothic gnome, interesting I think, and he came out of a deep mine, where he guards the fountain of tears."

Gone forever, lost treasures

Sir Richard Burton (1821-1890)

The Victorian explorer and Orientalist, was known as an expert on every scholarly subject "including pornography" - he translated the Kama Sutra and, from rare Arabic manuscripts, The Perfumed Garden.

His more explicit writings were burned by his widow, Isobel, after his death.

Philip Larkin (1922-1985)

The publicly reticent poet, in one of the greatest losses to 20th century biography, left a will asking his companion, Monica Jones, to burn all of his personal diaries after his death in 1985. However, his indiscreet letters have survived

Camille Claudel (1864-1943)

The admired sculptor was the mistress of Auguste Rodin for 15 years. Her feelings of injustice at his hands led her frequently to destroy all the work in her studio. Taken by force to an asylum in 1913, where she died

Nikolai Gogol (1809-1852)

The Russian dramatist and novelist fell victim to the "spiritual sadism" of an extreme Moscow priest, Father Matyev Konstantinovsky.

Ten days before Gogol's death in 1852, while mentally unbalanced, he burned the final volume of his masterpiece, Dead Souls, at the priest's order

Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828-1882)

The poet and painter was so distressed by the suicide of his wife Elizabeth Siddal from an overdose of laudanum in 1862 that he buried all his manuscripts with her.

Later he changed his mind and had her body exhumed to recover them. He justified this volte face by telling a friend, "Art was the only thing for which she felt very seriously"

webTitle: Low flying aircraft threaten the world's tallest building

fields.headline: Low flying aircraft threaten the world's tallest building
fields.trailText: To the rest of the world, Dallas may still be remembered chiefly as a place where a president was assassinated and a fictional oilman known only by his initials was gunned down. But if the Maharishi Global Development Fund has its way, the city which was founded as a prairie trading post more than 150 years ago may soon boast the world's tallest building.
fields.body:
To the rest of the world, Dallas may still be remembered chiefly as a place where a president was assassinated and a fictional oilman known only by his initials was gunned down. But if the Maharishi Global Development Fund has its way, the city which was founded as a prairie trading post more than 150 years ago may soon boast the world's tallest building.

There is one problem. Would the building pose a problem for pilots entering the busy airspace that serves the city and its neighbour Fort Worth?

If the proposal for a 1,659ft skyscraper to be built in The Colony suburb, providing a mix of office, commercial and residential space, goes ahead it would take over the title of world's tallest building from the twin 1,483ft Petronas Towers in Malaysia.

Its cost is estimated at up to $3bn and it would offer up to 19m sq ft of floor space.

Dallas is no shrinking Texas rose when it comes to tall buildings. The red neon Mobil Pegasus sign on top of the Magnolia Building became a famous city landmark and the Nations Bank climbed to 72 storeys. But the proposed skyscraper would dwarf even the current highest structure, the 920ft Bank of America Plaza.

"Tall buildings are synonymous with romance, ambition, technological prowess and financial success," wrote David Dillon, architecture critic of the Dallas Morning News in a recent column. "Nothing says a city has arrived more clearly than a skyscraper, particularly if it has a good restaurant on top."

But local people have complained to the press that they are still in the dark about the plans, which were announced by the Maharishi fund in May, and what they would mean for the neighbourhood.

"I'm not real comfortable with the level of information we've been given," David Stanwick told the Dallas Morning News. "We're here, now four months later, and we're still having the same questions with no additional answers and no additional information."

The Maharishi fund is investigating similar projects in Sao Paulo, Brazil, Johannesburg, South Africa, and India - which would be even taller.

For the time being the Dallas skyscraper has to await the judgment of the federal aviation administration, which has the power to disapprove of any structure higher than 200ft in the area.

The FAA has been concerned at the enormous growth in air traffic in the area and would be wary of giving the go-ahead in case a new building created too many imponderable risks.

fields.headline: Micro satellites cut space costs
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Two "downsized" satellites designed to swing more than 20,000 miles out into space twice a day could point the way to a generation of smarter and much smaller spacecraft.
fields.body:
Two "downsized" satellites designed to swing more than 20,000 miles out into space twice a day could point the way to a generation of smarter and much smaller spacecraft.

A pair of the 100kg "micro satellites", known as STRVs and packed with 25 pieces of experimental equipment, will "piggyback" along with a bigger payload aboard Europe's giant Ariane 5 when the rocket blasts off from French Guyana next month.

The STRVs - space technology research vehicles - will go into a huge 12-hour elliptical orbit moving, at their nearest, 600km from the earth, and, at their most distant, up to 39,000km away.

In a deliberate test of their ability to survive years in space, the satellites will be swinging through the Van Allen belt, a kind of radiation firewall around the earth.

The satellites follow on the heels of a similar 1994 experiment but with new hardware and communication gadgetry, according to Dera, the defence evaluation and research agency, which unveiled them yesterday. They will be among the first satellites with their own internet address, since one day satellites could push the world wide web into orbit. They will carry new kinds of carbon fibre joints never before tested in space, lithium ion batteries, and a microprocessor hardened against space radiation.

The important thing, however, is their size. Being compact and light, they can ride with bigger launch payloads, which will bring down the costs of putting hardware into space. And they open the way for an earth observation satellite that can, from space, resolve objects just 2.5m wide.

"Five or six years ago, you were talking about a one-ton satellite, something 10 times the size, with that sort of capability," said Richard Blott, Dera business projects manager. He added that it paved the way for satellites that were cheaper, quicker and easier to launch, and which enabled more people to "get into the space game".

It also meant space agencies and commercial firms being able to launch constellations of satellites, allowing better monitoring of the environment.

fields.headline: ANC backs down on Aids
fields.standfirst: Government distances itself from Mbeki over HIV
fields.trailText: South Africa yesterday attempted to end the row over President Thabo Mbeki's controversial views on the causes of Aids by launching a nationwide health campaign which implicitly repudiates the presidential opinion.
fields.body:
South Africa yesterday attempted to end the row over President Thabo Mbeki's controversial views on the causes of Aids by launching a nationwide health campaign which implicitly repudiates the presidential opinion.

The minister of health, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, told reporters in Soweto yesterday that the new guidelines for healthcare workers were intended to help implement the government's five-year plan released earlier this year.

She insisted the government operated on the premise that HIV caused Aids - earlier this year Mr Mbeki attracted withering international criticism for associating with dissident theorists who doubt whether HIV is the sole cause of the disease.

The ANC government's new campaign, launched in full-page newspaper advertisements, emphasises the benefits of safe sex and the use of condoms and faithfulness between partners.

But criticisms remained last night that despite the new campaign, the Mbeki government was still failing to issue anti-retroviral drugs to an estimated 4.2m citizens already carrying the virus.

The charge has been exploited by the opposition Democratic Alliance. With a eye to local government elections on December 5 - the first test of the Mbeki presidency since the general election - they have promised to distribute the medicines free of charge in municipalities which fall under their control.

The opposition leader, Tony Leon, is expected in Europe this week for negotiations with the pharmaceutical companies on the supply of anti-retroviral drugs at reduced prices.

The ANC hit back angrily by claiming that the opposition offer mounted to an attempt to use black people as guinea pigs in drug experiments.

webTitle: Beast of Beckenham catches golfers on hop

fields.headline: Beast of Beckenham catches golfers on hop
fields.standfirst: Mayor appeals for calm as experts check footprints of antipodean intruder that kicked dog
fields.trailText: Golf fans have grown accustomed to talented Australians parading on the green, but a six-foot kangaroo is not a usual sight at the 14th hole.
fields.body:
Golf fans have grown accustomed to talented Australians parading on the green, but a six-foot kangaroo is not a usual sight at the 14th hole.

Sightings of a mighty Skippy at large on a London golf course have encouraged players to ensure their number two wood is always close to hand.

Several people claim to have seen the stray animal near the golf course in Beckenham Place Park, south-east London. One woman claims her dog was kicked out of the undergrowth by the animal apparently defending its territory.

Another couple reported seeing the kangaroo nibbling foliage near the home of boxer Nigel Benn whose property borders the picturesque 380-acre park.

Last night the mayor of Lewisham, Dave Sullivan, appeared on television to appeal for calm. "Our advice to anyone who sees this kangaroo is not to approach it. They can be territorial and are obviously very powerful animals."

He said the council had no immediate plans to bring in the army to shoot the kangaroo, adding they were hoping to find more evidence, such as droppings or fur which could be sent for DNA testing.

"Clearly we have to balance public safety with financial prudence. But if people are attacked we will have to reconsider."

Mary Tidnam, who manages the golf club said the first sighting was three weeks ago and since then around six people claim to have seen it.

She said one golfer was taking a shot and came running back to the clubhouse saying he had seen a kangaroo. "Everyone thought he was mad or had had one too many," she said.

More sightings followed and the golf club put up a sign warning people not to go near the creature.

Yesterday footprints, supposedly belonging to the marsupial, were examined by experts at the Natural History Museum. Although their tests were inconclusive, they said the prints belonged to a large beast, much bigger than a dog.

By mid-afternoon jittery locals had dubbed the creature the Beast of Beckenham and were gathering in the golf club car-park hoping to spot the antipodean intruder.

Richard Rose, spokesman for Lewisham council said: "There have been several sightings of this kangaroo and we suspect it may have escaped from a zoo.

"I was speaking to an Australian woman this morning who said if it is a big red kangaroo, they can be quite aggressive.

"We found a large footprint near where it was seen. The Natural History Museum says it belongs to a large animal which does not appear to be native to this country. I take size 11 shoes and the footprint was much larger than my foot."

The park's management had contacted the RSPCA and London Zoo for advice and animal welfare experts from Lewisham council had scoured the area looking for evidence.

Yesterday golfers were taking no chances as they teed off at the public course. Shirley Lumsden, from Dulwich, who was playing with a friend said: "I have read that kangaroos are only dangerous in the mating season. As I have no idea what time of year that is, I'm keeping my driver nearby in case I need to use it as a weapon."

The RSPCA said the kangaroo was more likely to be an escaped wallaby, and although they are much smaller animals, they could be easily mistaken by someone unfamiliar with the different species.

Several wallaby colonies exist around Britain and one group had thrived in Derbyshire's Peak District since the 1950s, RSPCA spokeswoman Sarah Mawhinney said.

They had no plans to take any action unless the animal was injured or sick, but are advising people in Beckenham not to approach it if they see it.

Last night media interest was growing. CBS and an Australian television crew had joined the hunt.

"We are hoping it could be something of a local Loch Ness Monster," said golf club barman Michael Johnson. "It's been great publicity for the golf club."

fields.headline: Soccer scuffle 'led to player's death'
fields.trailText: A goalkeeper collapsed and died after being punched in the head by an opposing team player during a soccer match, the Northern Ireland high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A goalkeeper collapsed and died after being punched in the head by an opposing team player during a soccer match, the Northern Ireland high court heard yesterday.

Brian Reid, 25, a solicitor, was dead within minutes of the scuffle.

An artery had burst, causing a brain haemorrhage,a post mortem revealed. The chance of it happening was "one in a million", Mr Justice McCollum was told.

The life of Seamus Seaton, the other player involved, had now been ruined to a large degree, his lawyer said.

Seaton, 17, of Belfast, is accused of murdering Mr Reid, from Cookstown, Co Tyrone, after the row in the second half of the amateur game in Newtownabbey, Co Antrim, on Saturday. Mr Seaton, who plays for Glanville Stars against Mr Reid's Sporting Lisburn Road team in the Dunmurray and District League, was granted bail.

The judge told him: "It does not appear to have been an extremely or unusually violent or vicious assault."

Charles McKay, for the prosecution, said the game was being played in a "good sporting manner" when Mr Reid was challenged for catching the ball. The two players fell to the ground and the referee blew the whistle to indicate a foul. As Mr Reid got to his feet, he was punched in the head.

He considered that Mr Seaton would turn up for his trial and there was no question of interference with witnesses.

webTitle: Analysis: The Strategic Rail Authority has yet to show any evidence of a strategy

fields.headline: Signals, please
fields.standfirst:
The Strategic Rail Authority has yet to show any evidence of a strategy. Axing Connex for the Thames Trains operator is but one example

More about transport
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Step foward GoVia, the Anglo-French company, charged with the near impossible job of trying to run the most congested rail network in Britain. Yesterday its close rival, Connex, became the first victim of one of the government's two regulators, in a political move designed to show that ministers and regulators know what it is good for commuters.
fields.body:
Step foward GoVia, the Anglo-French company, charged with the near impossible job of trying to run the most congested rail network in Britain. Yesterday its close rival, Connex, became the first victim of one of the government's two regulators, in a political move designed to show that ministers and regulators know what it is good for commuters.

Sir Alastair Morton, the man responsible for building the Channel Tunnel, wielded his axe and it fell on the neck of one of Britain's worst performing rail companies. It has become a legend in its own lifetime, infamous for running short trains, packing in passengers, and allowing the public to sit in some of the dirtiest rolling stock in Britain.

Connex and GoVia have one thing in common. The French like them. Connex, which has been operating the south central franchise from London through Surrey and Sussex for the past four years, is owned by the French multi-national, Vivendi, while the French state railway, SNCF, has a 35% stake in GoVia.

It would ironic, not to say remarkable, if SNCF, a railway underpinned by considerable support from the French taxpayer, eventually found itself in charge of GoVia, at a time when the British government clearly believes that state control of the railways is out of date.

What Connex and GoVia do not have in common is that GoVia controls Thames Trains, the company at the heart of the Paddington rail crash: one of its employees, driver Hodder, went through a red light. Investigations after the event brought before Lord Cullen's inquiry into the disaster, revealed that Thames has a poor record in driver training and in scutinising new employees.

So, Sir Alastair, now chairman of the shadow Strategic Rail Authority, the government's son of British Rail, was in a cleft stick. The SSRA is supposed to be government's main representative on the platform, the trains and the booking offices. It has the power to divvy out 25 rail franchises and to withdraw them if companies under perform. Was it to be the unpopular incumbent Connex, or alternatively the company associated with Paddington?

In the case of Connex, the public had long decided that it should go, so Sir Alastair was only responding to the public mood. If he had decided to award Connex a new 20-year franchise, he might have been strung up on Platform One at East Croydon by angry commuters.

The SSRA can only blame itself for getting into this position. There were other bidders, but it boxed itself in by deciding that only Connex and GoVia should finally contest the franchise.

Yesterday's announcement was presented as an example of the industry acting in the interests of the public. But it still remains an act of faith. Very little separated the companies in terms of presentation. Both promised to invest around £1.5bn in the franchise over the next 20 years. It sounds a lot, but boils down to less than £170m a year, with a guaranteed commuter base.

The announcement also puts the SSRA under the public spotlight. This is John Prescott's great white hope for the future of the railways. It is looked on as the new vibrant organisation, giving a lead to a rapidly expanding industry written off after privatisation. More than 18 months have passed since Sir Alastair was appointed chairman, and yet the industry is still crying out for a strategy. Promised for months, it has been constantly delayed: it should finally emerge before the end of the year.

Instead of announcing a strategy, the SSRA invited train companies to come forward with their own ideas as they start their bidding in the re-franchising process. So far only two new franchises have been agreed, GoVia yesterday to replace Connex and Chiltern confirmed to operate its straightforward franchise between London and Birmingham several months ago.

Other train companies are uncomfortable and critical. One of them said yesterday: "We just don't know where we stand. Where is the blueprint for the industry? We should not be left in the dark."

When it comes, will it reduce the industry to fewer train companies, allowing the strong to expand and the minnows to be swallowed up? Almost certainly, but the timescale for change is long and the landscape which would reduce the companies to three or four leading players will take several years to achieve.

With clear doubts about the credentials of both Connex and GoVia, the SSRA could have adopted another option. It could have declared that neither was satisfactory and started the bidding process all over again.

It would have delayed matters, but the Connex franchise was not due to expire until 2003, plenty of time for the SSRA to reconsider the issue. But there are political pressures on it to deliver and it has duly obliged. In an obvious reference to GoVia, it added the caveat yesterday that safety is paramount. So the SSRA will be closely monitoring the Cullen report into the Paddington crash and any implications for Thames Trains.

Running the south central franchise, even with the re-modelled title of the New Southern Railway, will not be easy for GoVia. The name may evoke memories of kippers for breakfast on the Brighton Belle, and strike an immediate chord with passengers. It will start with some goodwill, but it will need to deliver improvements quickly. That means clean new trains and less standing. It will not be easy with such a difficult and demanding franchise.

Keith Harper is the Guardian's transport correspondent
keith.harper@theguardian.com

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Boy, 11, charged over stabbing
fields.body:
Boy, 11, charged over stabbing

An 11-year-old boy appeared at Edinburgh sheriff court yesterday charged with assault after a girl of nine was stabbed in the city on Monday. He was remanded into local authority care.

Soldiers 'lost' after map error

Rescue teams from Brecon mountain rescue, Dyfed Powys police and the RAF spent nine hours searching the Black Mountains in south Wales for eight Italian soldiers who had given out the wrong grid reference when calling for help after one of them developed hypothermia. The group was eventually found at 7.30am yesterday.

Disappointmentfor Reliant fans

The carmaker Reliant is set to disappoint 60 people keen to buy one of the last 120 Reliant Robins to be made at its factory in Burntwood, Staffordshire. The firm said the unprecedented waiting list for the car made famous in the BBC's Only Fools and Horses followed the announcement that production was to cease in December.

£2 coin salute to Marconi

A commemorative £2 coin to mark the centenary next year of inventor Guglielmo Marconi's first wireless transmission across the Atlantic was unveiled yesterday. The coin depicts radio waves in the centre and along the outer border. A spark of electricity represents the generation of the signal sent from Poldhu, Cornwall, to Newfoundland, in December 1901.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Eat Drink Man Woman/My Best Friend's Wedding/The Pawnbroker/The Owl And The Pussycat
fields.body:
Eat Drink Man Woman

(Ang Lee, 1994)

6pm, FilmFour

A succulent celebration of the spices of life - food and love - in this fragrant and witty romantic comedy cooked up by Ang Lee. It's set almost tangibly in his homeland of Taiwan and stars Sihung Lung as a widowed master chef and father of three unmarried daughters. As their romances begin to threaten his cosy world, he continues to express his love via the wok, aglow with emotional-comfort food. Watch, and drool.

My Best Friend's Wedding

(PJ Hogan, 1997)

8.10pm, FilmFour

Fun-filled modern take on the screwball comedy that saw Julia Roberts again doing big box-office. She's a cookery writer who realises, four days before her ex (Dermot Mulroney) is to marry Cameron Diaz, that she is still in love with him. Luckily her gay colleague (a very deft Rupert Everett) is on hand to pose as her beau, in order to make said ex jealous (look, it's not meant to make much sense. That's why it's screwball).

The Pawnbroker

(Sidney Lumet, 1965)

12.15am, Sky Cinema

Sol Nazerman, a middle-aged survivor of the Holocaust, owns a run-down pawnshop in Harlem. Alienated, mired in memories of the rest of his family who died in the concentration camps, he lives in his own cold world, until events conspire to bring him back to reality. Lumet's drama at times looks rather theatrical, but it is bleakly compelling. Quincy Jones's music adds to the harsh urban tone but the film belongs to Rod Steiger, and his towering performance as Nazerman.

The Owl And The Pussycat

(Herbert Ross, 1970)

1am Carlton Cinema

Bill Manhoff's witty, bawdy Broadway play is brought to the screen with aplomb by Ross. George Segal is the bookworm who reports fellow tenant Barbra Streisand when he learns she is a hooker, then feels morally obliged to put her up when she is evicted. True love overcomes love-for-sale, and the barbed comedy avoids sentimentality.

fields.headline: A combustible mix
fields.standfirst:
Kosovo threatens post-Milosevic peace Special report: Kosovo
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Kosovo is the last big Balkan problem. Despite the people's revolution in Belgrade, it may yet provide the setting for renewed conflict.
fields.body:
Kosovo is the last big Balkan problem. Despite the people's revolution in Belgrade, it may yet provide the setting for renewed conflict. While this is widely acknowledged, nobody - not the UN, not Nato, not Serbia's new rulers, not Russia, not western governments, Britain included - is agreed on what should be done to prevent it. The political disputes, tactical incompetence and military inadequacy which beset the west's Kosovo intervention last year, ruthlessly dissected in yesterday's Commons defence committee report, are damning in retrospect. But such unresolved problems also diminish confidence that the "international community" will perform any better in future. In concluding that "the war should never have needed to be fought", the report begs the question of whether the same may one day be said of a second Kosovo war: the province's avoidable but looming war of independence.

Solutions for Kosovo are as numerous as they are deeply flawed. Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica, has wasted no time in reasserting Serbia's claim. Under UN resolution 1244, Kosovo became a sort of international protectorate. Despite a likely Serb boycott, municipal elections this weekend are a step towards the sort of self-governance that the security council envisaged. But Yugoslavia never ceded, nor was it asked to cede, its territorial sovereignty. It retains the agreed right, for example, to return its troops to the scene of their ethnic crimes. Mr Kostunica's preferred solution, as with Montenegro, is to talk the province back into the fold. To this end, he has begun apologising for Milosevic era mayhem. But as an avowed Serb nationalist and critic of Nato's intervention, he is unlikely to give up on Kosovo.

Unfortunately for Mr Kostunica, the vast majority of Kosovans has long since given up on Serbia. Their solution, Belgrade's democratic dawn notwithstanding, is outright independence. On this all parties, except the few remaining Serbs and Roma, agree. They began to fight for this cause under Milosevic; and they are clearly prepared to fight for it again, against Serbia for sure, but also, prospectively, against anybody who denies them their rights. This may come to include the very UN and Nato forces who were sent to their rescue and who have since tried to disband the Kosovo Liberation Army. Despite the UN administrator Bernard Kouchner's best efforts, the creation of a law-based, multi-ethnic civil society in Kosovo remains a fond dream. Even as an OSCE report bemoaned continuing intimidation of minorities, a rocket-propelled grenade was slamming into Serb flats in Pristina on Monday evening. Given this strength of feeling, a UN commission has recommended "conditional independence" as the best solution for Kosovo. But its complicated formula falls short of Kosovan aspirations, and in any case, would be opposed by Mr Kostunica, by Russia (which he visits this week) and by jumpy neighbours.

Yet even flawed solutions are preferable to no solution at all - the west's present position. In all logic, having taken Kosovo from its owners by force, it could be expected to support its full independence. But this course, floated at the Rambouillet talks, sank with all hands and is now seen, post-Milosevic, as politically impossible. It would also be very expensive. Much emphasis is now placed on reconciliation, on time the healer, on keeping options open. Savvy diplomats describe this policy as "constructive ambiguity". This is a polite term for drift. Something may turn up, as Mr Micawber said. But if not, get ready for yet another war that need never have been fought.

fields.headline: Women answer army's shortfall
fields.trailText: Women could be the answer to the armed forces' recruitment problem, the equal opportunities commission said yesterday.
fields.body:
Women could be the answer to the armed forces' recruitment problem, the equal opportunities commission said yesterday.

The army was short of more than 6,000 trained soldiers yet it barred women from 30% of posts, said Julie Mellor, chairwoman of the EOC which gives evidence today to the Commons defence committee's inquiry into staff shortages.

"Rather than automatically excluding women from certain posts, it makes sense to judge each individual on the basis of their ability to carry out the job, using relevant tests to measure their ability", she said. "If a woman can't pass the necessary tests, she would not be accepted to do the job. But we believe that the armed services are missing out on many good recruits".

But if women were to be retained, the culture within the services needed to change so that staff were given the support they needed.

Attitudes towards women with children remained a problem, she said. Fathers, as well as mothers, needed time with their families, and it was clear that many cases of voluntary early release were related to this issue.

"Many women have also told us that they were not happy with the way their complaints of sexual harassment were dealt with," said Ms Mellor. "In many cases they were not informed about the complaints procedure or they were dissuaded from using it."

The commission pointed to research by David Segal of the US Centre for Research on Military Organisation. He concluded that there was no evidence to back up claims that women personnal had "a negative impact". He said similar arguments were used in the US to delay the integration of black and homosexual soldiers.

webTitle: Britain scores trade surplus with Europe

fields.headline: Britain scores trade surplus with Europe
fields.trailText: Britain has recorded a trade surplus with the rest of the European Union in August for the first time in nearly five years.
fields.body:
Britain has recorded a trade surplus with the rest of the European Union in August for the first time in nearly five years.

Official figures published yesterday showed that rising export volumes generated a surplus of £31m despite sterling's overvaluation against the euro, which makes British goods pricier in EU markets.

The surplus helped to reduce the overall global goods deficit to £2.27bn from July's record of £3bn but left the trade gap on a widening trend, according to the Office for National Statistics. Although exports to China and the US are rising strongly, they are being outpaced by surging imports from the US, China, South Korea and Japan.

Economists warned that with domestic demand likely to grow faster than world demand, import volumes could continue to rise strongly as the year progresses.

As a net exporter of oil, Britain's trade balance with the EU has been gaining from the surge in the price of oil, which has tripled since the start of last year.

But ONS officials said the swing into the black for the first time since November 1995 was also due to a £300m jump in exports of capital goods and a favourable £200m movement in erratic items, such as ships and precious stones.

Economists doubted that the surplus marked a turning point in Britain's trade with the rest of the EU, pointing out that it was so small that it could easily be revised away.

But they said it implied that sterling's strength is less of a handicap than manufacturers have sometimes suggested.

"The main surprise is just how well our exporters are doing in the EU in the face of the strength of sterling/euro," said Geoff Dicks, of the Royal Bank of Scotland.

However, economists say there is evidence that UK exporters are having to cut prices in sterling terms to remain competitive in the EU, resulting in thinner profit margins.

"They really must be getting close to the bone, because it's been four years now that sterling's been rising," said Danny Gabay, of JP Morgan.

The sterling price of goods sold in the EU fell only 0.7% over the year to August, not enough to compensate for sterling's increase against the euro.

ONS said Britain's trade deficit with countries outside the EU grew to £2.5bn in September from £2.3bn in August.

webTitle: Bass Brewers blames pub chains for high beer prices

fields.headline: Bass Brewers blames pub chains for high beer prices
fields.trailText: Bass Brewers yesterday blamed Britain's big pub chains for rising beer prices, as the brewer began an offensive to persuade the competition commission that its takeover by Interbrew would be good for the drinks industry.
fields.body:
Bass Brewers yesterday blamed Britain's big pub chains for rising beer prices, as the brewer began an offensive to persuade the competition commission that its takeover by Interbrew would be good for the drinks industry.

The company's chief executive, Iain Napier, said that over the past eight years wholesale beer prices had fallen 16% due to the competitive nature of the brewing industry. But pub chains have failed to pass these reductions on to drinkers - bar prices have gone up 10%.

He pinned the blame on tenanted pub groups which are "structured as financial vehicles". Many of them have borrowed heavily to buy new pubs and continually need to repay their debts. "The gap between off-trade and on-trade prices is wider than it has been at any time in the past," he said.

Mr Napier spoke out amid a growing feeling in the industry that the competition commission could severely disrupt Belgian group Interbrew's acquisition of the brewing operations of Whitbread and Bass.

The commission yesterday published a formal "issues and remedies" letter, setting out the terms of reference of its enquiry. The letter detailed a list of measures it could impose on Interbrew, varying from a complete disposal of the Bass or Whitbread businesses to the sale of certain brands or distribution networks.

More minor intervention could include an order not to discriminate in pricing between customers, or not to force pub companies to buy its entire range of products.

Mr Napier said Bass Brewer's £2.3bn takeover by Interbrew would create big savings, driving down wholesale prices even further. He insisted there was plenty of competition in the market and pointed out that margins were already low - brewers make about 4p profit on the average pint costing 204p.

"It will be in the best interests of both the consumer and the industry," he said. "My drive in life is to make beer interesting again."

Big pub chains such as Punch Taverns, which has just over 5,000 houses but has debts of £2.5bn, are opposed to Interbrew's purchases, which will give the Belgian firm a 32% market share. Punch's chairman, Hugh Osmond, described it as "a pretty dubious thing to allow to happen without some very serious conditions".

Japanese bank Nomura, which also owns about 5,000 of Britain's 60,000 pubs, has made a series of submissions to the commission which industry sources say are equally critical of Interbrew's position.

The commission will report its views to trade secretary Stephen Byers in December.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is to deliver his keenly awaited pre-Budget report on Wednesday November 8. The timing means his statement will come just five days before the fuel protesters' deadline for the resumption of the blockades if there is no cut in duties.
fields.body:
Pre-Budget report date set

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is to deliver his keenly awaited pre-Budget report on Wednesday November 8. The timing means his statement will come just five days before the fuel protesters' deadline for the resumption of the blockades if there is no cut in duties.

Mr Brown is widely expected to use the report to set out his plans for dealing with the concerns of demonstrators - particularly the hauliers and farmers who were the driving force behind the protests.

He has also said that he will announce plans for the annual increase in the basic state pension.

Following the bitter outcry over this year's rise of 75p a week, Mr Brown has made it clear that he will provide an above-inflation rise for all 11m pensioners. Yesterday's announcement was made by Mr Brown in a written Commons answer.

Jazz FM tunes in to break even

Radio broadcaster Jazz FM said on Tuesday that the company had been trading at break-even in the past six months, and that it was well placed to continue improving its performance after restructuring last year.

"The company has made good progress towards profitability this year," chairman Harry Roche said in Jazz FM's results statement. The company said it made a pre-tax loss of £489,000 in the year to June 30, compared to a £2m loss in the previous nine months.

The company also said its turnover grew to 5.1 million pounds in the year, compared to 2.8 million for nine months to June 30 1999.

Jazz FM Enterprises, which is responsible for developing non-airtime revenues, accounted for 45% of the turnover, the company said.

Actuary firm restructures

Bacon & Woodrow, the consultant and actuary firm, yesterday announced plans to restructure the firm.

Under the changes, Bacon & Woodrow's employee benefits practice will join with Hewitt Associates, a management consulting company that specialises in the human resource area, and the insurance practice will merge with Deloitte & Touche.

Bacon & Woodrow said by merging the employee benefits practice with Hewitt they would create one of the world's largest firms in this area - essentially providing all the advice and services required to run a pension fund.

The companies will begin to work closely immediately and the combined group will operate in over 80 locations worldwide.

In the UK the group is expected to have revenues of more than £100m and over 1,400 staff. Hewitt and Bacon & Woodrow also plan to create a global investment consultancy.

£10 banknote changes face

Charles Darwin is to replace Charles Dickens on £10 banknotes from next month, the Bank of England said yesterday. Merlyn Lowther, the Bank's chief cashier, said the new design would be issued on November 7.

fields.headline: Export and survive
fields.standfirst: Painful way to beat the strong pound
fields.trailText: Paper-thin margins are the secret to holding on to European markets while sterling is at its current levels, according to Hugh Morgan-Williams of Camford Audio, writes Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
Paper-thin margins are the secret to holding on to European markets while sterling is at its current levels, according to Hugh Morgan-Williams of Camford Audio, writes Charlotte Denny.

His firm makes audio and broadcasting equipment for the UK and Europe. Based in Washington, in Tyne and Wear, the firm is keeping a foothold in mainland Europe by selling some products at a loss.

But although the firm is still just making money from exports, cutting profit margins is a painful strategy. Sterling has been at high levels against the big European currencies since early 1997, and some firms are responding by moving to the European mainland. That is not an option for Camford: two-thirds of its customers are UK-based.

But sterling has also tumbled against the dollar. "A lot of components are denominated in dollars so we are doubly squeezed because we face higher input costs but can't put up prices because of competition from Europe," says Mr Morgan-Williams, pictured above. As Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George said yesterday, sterling's current value is a mystery.

But making it fall is simple, says Mr Morgan-Williams. "The government should show a more positive commitment to the euro. That would bring sterling crashing down."

fields.headline: Buoyant sterling baffles the experts
fields.standfirst: Fresh boost in trade surplus
fields.trailText: It's a mystery, said Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, yesterday when asked about sterling's remarkable strength against the euro. Equally baffling are the latest trade figures which show Britain recording a trade surplus with Europe for the first time in five years, despite the runaway pound. Export volumes were up 10% over the past three months, compared with a year ago, an impressive performance given the exchange rate.
fields.body:
It's a mystery, said Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, yesterday when asked about sterling's remarkable strength against the euro. Equally baffling are the latest trade figures which show Britain recording a trade surplus with Europe for the first time in five years, despite the runaway pound. Export volumes were up 10% over the past three months, compared with a year ago, an impressive performance given the exchange rate.

So why are the figures holding up?

Firstly, manufacturers are slashing profit margins to keep a toehold in European markets and to ward off competition at home from cheap continental imports. As a result, manufacturing profitability has fallen sharply since the start of 1999. Firms are tightening their belts and cutting costs, and jobs, in order to stay afloat. In the first quarter of 2000, rates of return fell to below 7%, around half the rate earned in 1998.

Faced with declining profitability, firms have moved upmarket in search of high quality products where they are no longer competing on price. Those stuck in low growth commodity markets - textiles, bulk chemicals and basic metals - are closing or moving overseas.

The changing composition of Britain's manufacturing sector demonstrates the search for value: the fastest growing sectors are electrical and optical equipment, biotech and drugs, all producing goods which are less price sensitive.

Britain's trade balance with Europe has been improving for nearly a year, which suggests that yesterday's figures are not just a flash in the pan. This raises the possibility that the pound may not be as overvalued as the markets are assuming. Do not expect the Treasury to celebrate Britain's improvement in competitiveness anytime soon, however. As long as the euro remains so unpopular with voters, the high pound can be used as an excuse for not joining.

Off the rails

John Prescott yesterday opened up fresh doubts again about the role of Railtrack's Gerald Corbett, whose belated love-in with some of the victims of the Paddington rail crash is remarkable.

The redoubtable deputy prime minister was away in China when Hatfield occurred. On his return, he has not been slow to hide his feelings on the remaking of Mr Corbett's reputation. They burst out yesterday when he refused to endorse the chief executive and then proceeded to voice his displeasure at Mr Corbett adopting the role of the industry's radical thinker, calling for everybody to work together. To Prescott, that is a statement of the blindingly obvious, pointing to the fact that the industry has been at loggerheads for years, Railtrack included.

Mr Corbett's position is almost certainly safe in the short term because there is nobody trained up at Railtrack to do the job. It needs someone who understands the industry and, after three years trial and error, the present incumbent has just about got to grips with it.

But the two official reports into the Paddington and Hatfield rail crashes will almost certainly expose the company's shortcomings on signalling and track renewal. Mr Corbett will eventually be forced to fall on his sword. Railtrack needs to start grooming quickly.

Déjà vu

It all sounds so powerful and deliverable: 50 of the world's banks, who together account for half the globe's currency trading (£500bn a day, no less), coming together to exploit the standardisation and speed of the internet. No longer, it seems, will corporate treasurers and money managers have to flit around on the phone.

But read on into the detail of the new Atriax venture, backed by Reuters and banks such as Citibank, and any observer of the foreign exchange markets over the past 30 years will find themselves in familiar territory.

Atriax will sport two "strong and independent" advisory boards - one with 14 bankers and another with 24 representatives of global companies and institutions. This sounds like a recipe for muddle.

Big banks have been rowing with small banks about standardisation in the world of foreign exchange, and corporate treasurers have been rowing with everyone, ever since Swift - the international network for bank money transfers - was founded 27 years ago. How Atriax fits into what remains the backbone of the foreign exchange market remains unclear.

So, too, does the ownership of this new venture. Launching the service yesterday Dan Morehead, chief executive designate, was not prepared to say, other than confirming that the original providers of £55m in working capital will get equal stakes.

Atriax will be British registered, yet Mr Morehead does "not want to discuss our capital structure". So much for transparency in the new economy.

To Prescott, that is a statement of the blindingly obvious, pointing to the fact that the industry has been at loggerheads for years, Railtrack included. Mr Corbett's position is almost certainly safe in the short term because there is nobody trained up at Railtrack to do the job. It needs someone who understands the industry and, after three years trial and error, the present incumbent has just about got to grips with it. But the two official reports into the Paddington and Hatfield rail crashes will almost certainly expose the company's shortcomings on signalling and track renewal. Mr Corbett will eventually be forced to fall on his sword. Railtrack needs to start grooming quickly. Déjà vu It all sounds so powerful and deliverable: 50 of the world's banks, who together account for half the globe's currency trading (£500bn a day, no less), coming together to exploit the standardisation and speed of the internet. No longer, it seems, will corporate treasurers and money managers have to flit around on the phone. But read on into the detail of the new Atriax venture, backed by Reuters and banks such as Citibank, and any observer of the foreign exchange markets over the past 30 years will find themselves in familiar territory. Atriax will sport two "strong and independent" advisory boards - one with 14 bankers and another with 24 representatives of global companies and institutions. This sounds like a recipe for muddle. Big banks have been rowing with small banks about standardisation in the world of foreign exchange, and corporate treasurers have been rowing with everyone, ever since Swift - the international network for bank money transfers - was founded 27 years ago. How Atriax fits into what remains the backbone of the foreign exchange market remains unclear. So, too, does the ownership of this new venture. Launching the service yesterday Dan Morehead, chief executive designate, was not prepared to say, other than confirming that the original providers of £55m in working capital will get equal stakes. Atriax will be British registered, yet Mr Morehead does "not want to discuss our capital structure". So much for transparency in the new economy.

fields.headline: Safeway denies rumoured takeover
fields.trailText: Safeway, Britain's fourth largest supermarket chain, yesterday vowed to remain independent and quashed rumours of a £4bn break-up bid.
fields.body:
Safeway, Britain's fourth largest supermarket chain, yesterday vowed to remain independent and quashed rumours of a £4bn break-up bid.

The company claimed it was unaware of any potential suitors and dismissed speculation that it was in the sights of a consortium led by John Fletcher, a former boss of Asda and Budgens.

"We have had no approaches," said Kevin Hawkins, the group's communications director. "Safeway sees its future very much as an independent," he added.

The chain, reporting second-quarter data, said the year's cost-cutting had brought in more than a million new customers. But, it added, the coming months would see a greater focus on improving and refurbishing many stores, with the introduction of services such as dry cleaning and photographic processing.

Yesterday's news met with a mixed reaction in the City with some questioning the cost of price promotions and the length of time it can sustain such growth levels. "The figures were slightly better than expected, and they have taken some market share off Asda," said one analyst.

"They are not really up against tough comparisons yet, and like for like growth is not going to be sustainable." Last night the overall verdict was favourable, with the stock rising 2.75p to close at 277.75p.

webTitle: Deutsche BA claims over rival quashed

fields.headline: Deutsche BA claims over rival quashed
fields.trailText: British Airways' German subsidiary has been ordered to withdraw claims that its rival Lufthansa was acting anti-competitively.
fields.body:
British Airways' German subsidiary has been ordered to withdraw claims that its rival Lufthansa was acting anti-competitively.

Deutsche BA, Germany's second largest domestic carrier, has been ordered by a Dusseldorf court not to repeat controversial claims made about the country's biggest airline.

Two weeks ago, under the heading "Deutsche BA fears for German domestic market competition", the carrier had set out a list of question and answers designed to highlight its concerns about Lufthansa's intention to buy a stake in Eurowings, the third biggest player in the market.

The Deutsche BA publicity claimed: "Lufthansa shows its true face - the airline is not interested in the welfare of its passengers, rather in the preservation of its power ... There must not be a return to the past when Lufthansa squeezed the German market like a lemon."

Yesterday, Lufthansa said that the issuing of a court injunction confirmed its opinion that Deutsche BA's "untrue and disparaging remarks [had]... overstepped the legal limits for advertising and competition rules".

Lufthansa said that it had particularly objected to claims that passengers would no longer have a choice and would have to accept its monopolistic prices if Eurowings were to sell.

Deutsche BA initially agreed to withdraw three claims made in its press statement, but Lufthansa successfully applied to a judge for an order banning publication of a further two.

A spokeswoman for Deutsche BA appeared unrepentant. She said: "It is true that under the German law the statement was strong. But the situation on the German market is alarming. I think we managed to get across our point ... From our point of view Lufthansa has over-reacted.

"There won't be a court case and we won't have to sit in front of a judge. We could have fought against it in court, but we feel it would have detracted from the real issue, which is free competition."

She also stood by the claim that under the proposed Eurowings deal Deutsche BA would be left as the only competitor to Lufthansa, which would control 84% of domestic flights.

There was also concern that Lufthansa controlled the lion's share of slots at many German airports including 67% at Frankfurt, she said.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Michael Ashcroft, the controversial billionaire who bailed out the Tory party after the last election, finally took his seat in the House of Lords today. The announcement of his introduction, unusually, did not appear on any of the preceding days' order papers.

Labour MP Peter Bradley said: "This ought to be a cause for celebration for Mr Ashcroft and Mr Hague at least, yet he is being smuggled in through the back door with a blanket over his head. This is the peer who dare not speak his own name."

Bad day

Britain's defence capabilities.The navy will have to use US ships to protect patrols by British Trident nuclear missile submarines, John Spellar, the armed forces minister indicated yesterday. He confirmed in a Commons statement that the navy's entire fleet of 12 nuclear-powered "hunter killer" submarines are being withdrawn from service after the discovery of flaws in the reactor cooling system in HMS Tireless which has been moored off Gibraltar since May. The fleet is used to escort Trident submarines and the navy admits its loss will effect the security of Britain's nuclear deterrent system.

Today

Commons: International development questions. PM's questions. Opposition debates on fuel protests and recruitment of teachers. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates on flooding in East Sussex, operation of the Osteopaths Act, economic development in Sunderland, Central Railway and planning blight, and free miners of the Forest of Dean. Lords: Police (Northern Ireland) bill, committee.

webTitle: John O'Farrell on the Tory frontbench

fields.headline: Frontbench stuck in the shadows
fields.standfirst:
Hague's team look like a bunch of losers from missing persons

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Sometimes I wonder if the current Tory front bench are all former SAS officers whose identities have to be kept secret for security reasons. It is hard to think of a more anonymous bunch. Does William Hague have the same problem as the rest of us when he holds meetings of the shadow cabinet?
fields.body:
Sometimes I wonder if the current Tory front bench are all former SAS officers whose identities have to be kept secret for security reasons. It is hard to think of a more anonymous bunch. Does William Hague have the same problem as the rest of us when he holds meetings of the shadow cabinet?

"Er, you, thingy, whatsyername, what do you think we should do?"

"I dunno mate, I'm just the bloke who's come to mend the photocopier."

"Oh sorry. Actually, you don't fancy being environment spokesman do you?"

Hague must take much of the blame for the anonymity of the team he has built around him. He chose new faces as a way of saying to the voters "Look, you don't have to elect anyone connected with the last Conservative government". To which the logical response must be: "Good point, I'd better vote Labour just to make really sure".

Apart from the unholy trinity of Hague, Portillo and Widdecombe, who we got to know in the Major years, the Observer's Book of British Conservatives says sightings of other shadow cabinet members are extremely unlikely. So who are the poor conscripts who found themselves suddenly promoted to generals after the massacre of May 97? They're all listed on the Conservative party website, where their faces stare out at you like the sad photos from an appeal for missing persons.

First up is Francis Maude, who is apparently now shadow foreign secretary, but the Tories might as well go to a temp agency on the continent to hire a real foreign secretary for all the impact he has made. Likewise James Arbuthnot, David Willetts, Andrew Lansley, Denis Kindel, Peter Ainsworth, Edward Garnier, Andrew Mackay - I couldn't put a face to any of them. Most of us could name more Pokemon characters than Tory frontbenchers. Shadow chief secretary to the treasury is David Heathcoat-Amory. At last, a Tory name I vaguely recognise! Oh no, I'm thinking of the other Heathcoat-Amory, aren't I? The one who was chancellor in the 50s; that was probably David's uncle or something.

T hen there's Liam Fox. He used to be a doctor, so he's been given the health portfolio. Actually he was once an army doctor, so he may well be shadow minister of defence as well. Oh no, apparently defence is Iain Duncan Smith - because he used to be the publishing director of Jane's Defence Weekly. I suppose if "Jane" had gone into politics they would have given the job to her. Then there's Bernard Jenkin at transport, who, as they say, is not even a household name in his own house.

And the remarkable thing is that these people must be the best of the bunch; the Conservative crème de la crème. The other 150 Conservative MPs have not made it to the front bench because they have failed to make as great an impact as Gary Streeter. (No, I hadn't heard of him either. He's shadow international development apparently.) If they ever became the government they would do for Britain's profile what they have done for their party's.

Today's leading Tories are the contestants in a political version of Stars in their Eyes. They are complete nobodies who brave the spotlight and have a crack at pretending to be one of the Tory superstars of yesteryear. "Tonight Matthew, I'm going to be... Margaret Thatcher!" says David Willetts, as he steps forward and trots out all the old lines about Europe and the unions. I don't know why he doesn't go the whole hog and put on a blue dress and blonde wig - at least then he might stick in the memory for more than five minutes.

There was a time when if you were a potential high-flyer, the Conservative party was a promising career ladder. But today, if you are smart and ambitious, years spent on the opposition benches does not look like a very attractive or lucrative option. The result is that today's Conservative party is filled with an evangelical rump of MPs who are not only second rate, but who actually believe all that mad rightwing stuff. Misguided and incompetent - it's a fairly terrifying combination. John Major may have imagined the answer to Britain's problems was a traffic cone hotline, but at least he remembered to put a telephone number on the signs.

One last thing I ought to mention - one of the names of the various shadow ministers I listed above is completely made up. It's actually the name of the reserve goalie for Doncaster Rovers. So now it is competition time. If you can spot the imaginary leading Conservative, write his name on a postcard and send it to me at the Guardian. The first correct answer picked at random will get £25 worth of book vouchers. Entries from the reserve goalie for Doncaster Rovers will not be accepted. I was also going to say that this competition is not open to members of the shadow cabinet. The trouble is, how would any of us know?

John O'Farrell's novel The Best a Man Can Get is published by Doubleday

webTitle: FBI hunts for killer rebels in Rwanda

fields.headline: FBI hunts for killer rebels in Rwanda
fields.trailText: A team of FBI agents has been sent to Uganda to help find the Rwandan rebels who killed eight tourists, including four Britons, on a visit to view rare gorillas last year, a US embassy spokeswoman said yesterday.
fields.body:
A team of FBI agents has been sent to Uganda to help find the Rwandan rebels who killed eight tourists, including four Britons, on a visit to view rare gorillas last year, a US embassy spokeswoman said yesterday.

The team has been in Uganda for several weeks and is working with Ugandan officials to find the killers, according to Mary Jeffers, an embassy spokeswoman.

The rebels, thought to be a faction of the ethnic Hutu militia known as Interahamwe, hacked to death four Britons, two Americans, two New Zealanders and one park ranger on March 1, 1999 in Bwindi national park, 30 miles north of Uganda's border with Rwanda.

Ms Jeffers would not give details of the agents' mission, but the weekly East African newspaper, which is published in Kenya, said on Monday that the agents have made contacts with Congolese rebels, who are thought to have information about the killers.

The park, declared safe and reopened in July, is the only natural habitat for the world's 620 mountain gorillas.

webTitle: Victory denied Ivorians protest at 'rigged' vote

fields.headline: Victory denied Ivorians protest at 'rigged' vote
fields.trailText: At least one person was killed when supporters of the Ivory Coast's civilian opposition leader, Laurent Gbagbo, took to the streets of the capital, Abidjan, yesterday after the commander of the country's ruling junta, General Robert Guei, declared himself the winner in Sunday's presidential election.
fields.body:
At least one person was killed when supporters of the Ivory Coast's civilian opposition leader, Laurent Gbagbo, took to the streets of the capital, Abidjan, yesterday after the commander of the country's ruling junta, General Robert Guei, declared himself the winner in Sunday's presidential election.

A crowd of at least 2,000 repeatedly regrouped near the presidential offices after being dispersed by soldiers and military police using machine guns and firing tear gas.

The body of one demonstrator lay in the street after a burst of gunfire. Witnesses said at least four others were injured.

The election was effectively decided when Gen Guei, who seized control of the west African country in an army coup last December, dissolved the independent commission over-seeing the election yesterday. On Monday the National Electoral Commission reported that Mr Gbagbo, of the Ivorian Popular Front (IPF), had taken a commanding lead in the contest.

Mr Gbagbo implored the country's residents to take to the streets last night after Gen Guei's victory was announced.

Daniel Bamba Sheik, director-general of the interior ministry's territorial administration department, said Gen Guei took almost 53% of the vote, against 41% for Mr Gbagbo.

He blamed the decision to disband the commission on massive fraud and the inability of its officials.

"This commission, visibly lacking in experience, instituted operational procedures for tabulating results that made the results unacceptable, causing, as was observed, mistakes and confusion," he said.

He went on to accuse several parties, including the IPF, of bussing voters from Abidjan to villages in the interior to vote twice.

Members of the electoral commission were accompanied by armed guards yesterday and were not allowed to speak to journalists.

The country's two largest political parties boycotted the ballot after their leaders were barred from running by the supreme court, leaving only Mr Gbagbo to run against the junta leader. The EC withdrew its election funding in protest.
