webTitle: Comment: Christians share the blame for the Middle East crisis

fields.headline: We share the blame
fields.standfirst:
Christians must take some responsibility for the Holy Land crisis, says the Bishop of Winchester

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Christians must take some responsibility for the Holy Land crisis, says the Bishop of Winchester
fields.body:
Then Joshua blessed him; and he gave Hebron to Caleb the son of Jephunneh for an inheritance (Joshua 14:13)

These words were the climax to a reading this week in the context of Christian worship. I found them profoundly searching. I thought they presented an acute challenge to our reading of Scripture; to our moral and political consistency in the face of events fatefully unfolding on our television screens; to our reading of the history of the last century; and a challenge to our willingness to be identified as participants, because we are Christian, in today's crisis of the Holy Land.

Behind that passage lies the significance of Hebron, first as the place of the burial of the patriarch Abraham, and then as the first capital for David's kingship before his capture of Jerusalem - a kingship which created the reality, the promise and the myth down to this day, of "the land of Israel". Of this reality, promise or myth, Hebron is therefore fundamentally symbolic. So, in the modern Israel, Hebron is a place of especially determined Jewish settlers, and a front line between them and such local people as remain. Our text is not separable from today's bitterness and violence.

To our reading of Scripture, the challenge is not just that of remembering that Jews read these texts too, but differently - because there are Christians who read them as some Jews read them, justifying from them the presence, the history, the behaviour of the modern state of Israel and of the movements out of which it was born. The challenge is to wrestle with the implications of recognising that these texts are shot through with what we have come to see as the barbarous brutality of "ethnic cleansing". As such, they have played a part in forming what we would now see as among the darker episodes in our own colonial history; and in that of Imperial Russia and Nazi Germany, against Jews among others - and in Israel's dealings with those whom Joshua and Caleb's 20th-century successors found in possession of the Land of Promise.

To our moral and our political consistency the challenge seems to me this: are we prepared to read the present crisis in the Holy Land through the lens with which we read the recent history of, say, Kosovan Albanians at the hands of Milosevic's Serbia, or of Marsh Arabs at the hands of Saddam Hussein's Iraq? With the further stimulus if we are Christians, that a significant minority of Palestinians are Christiansm- and that some see themselves as the direct descendants of the first Christian generations. Will it be just or acceptable if today's Kosovan refugees, and their children and grandchildren, are still in camps in Montenegro 50 years from now?

But think, pray like this and the challenges press in upon our understanding of 20th-century history. Does the terrible reality of the Holocaust - built upon centuries of especially European persecution and ill-treatment of the Jews, and built in part upon New Testament texts which lent themselves to anti-semitic reading - require of European and North American Christians unlimited approval of the state of Israel?

Was the land empty when the Jewish settlers arrived in the last century, or did they empty it? Whose was the land, and whose is it? Above all, whose was, and whose is, the uniquely symbolic Jerusalem - uniquely symbolic for Christians as well as for Jews and for Muslims - which with its holy places was under Muslim protection from 640 to 1914, with only short interludes of Crusader, and much less tolerant, rule?

With which set of eyes do we view the settlements rising on so many hills, and the defended roads that cut through (as Palestinians see it) Palestinian land to link them; with which set of eyes do we view what Israel sees as generous concessions for which Palestinians should be grateful, and what Palestinians see as barely a start towards a long overdue return of what was so violently snatched from them? Will we work to understand the fundamental significance to both sides of the land; and the axiomatic Israeli determination, rooted in such terrible experience, never again to be dependent for their security on anyone other than themselves?

Lastly, the challenge to see ourselves, as British descendants of those who undertook the Mandate and who made the Balfour Declaration, as Europeans in the light of the long horror of European anti-semitism, and as followers of one of the faiths for whom this is the Holy Land and Jerusalem a place of the most special significance - to see ourselves as sharing responsibility both that things are as they are, and for their resolution?

Far more is here at stake than over Kosovo last year, or over Iraq in 1991. Only a genuinely international coalition can successfully press, but by means other than weaponry, for statehood and the return of at least some land for Palestinians, and for guaranteed security for Israel - and, as the Vatican has long urged, for an international responsibility for Old Jerusalem.

Christians have long read my opening quotation as part of the long march of preparation for the Messiah Jesus, closing our eyes to elements in them that we now perceive to be ungodly, and viciously destructive.

With our eyes opened by the terrible 20th century, they can jolt us into praying with understanding for those who still look to them as title deeds to land, and for those who still suffer from their doing so. They can jolt us into confessing our share of responsibility for what is happening and into a new commitment to take a part in discovering ways towards Shalom, which is well-being and justice and not just the absence of war.

webTitle: Reuters links with banks in FX deal

fields.headline: Reuters links with banks in FX deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Reuters and three of the world's most powerful banks, Chase Manhattan, Citibank and Deutsche Bank, are funding a new attempt to breathe some electronic life into the world of foreign exchange trading.
fields.body:
Reuters and three of the world's most powerful banks, Chase Manhattan, Citibank and Deutsche Bank, are funding a new attempt to breathe some electronic life into the world of foreign exchange trading.

Each will be putting £14m into Atriax, an internet-based FX market that aims to be up and running by the middle of next year. About 50 banks have agreed to use the service, which will primarily be aimed at automating currency dealings between banks and their corporate customers.

Bank research on the FX market, together with a news service from Reuters, will be available immediately on www.atriax.com ranks as the world centre for a market where global daily turnover is believed to top £1 trillion. Much of the business between banks is already conducted online through both Reuters' FX trading systems and the competing Electronic Broking Service run by a consortium of banks. But to date, due to a lack of agreement on standards, much of the business between banks and their clients has remained telephone-based.

Companies will have to have an existing credit relationship to deal with a bank through Atriax, but the system does promise a sharp cut in the administration involved in currency deals, adding a fully automated confirmation and settlement process.

"Our aim is quickly to establish Atriax as the most efficient means to research, transact and settle foreign exchange business," Dan Morehead, Atriax's chief executive, said, adding that the new internet platform "will provide a single point of access to market news and data, aggregated research, on-line dealing and straight through processing."

webTitle: Leader: New Commons speaker goes wigless

fields.headline: Wigs in the wardrobe
fields.standfirst:
Public life will survive without them

Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: This has been a bad week for the Commons, but an even worse week for wigs. Mr Speaker Martin does not intend to wear one. And the new Lord Chief Justice seems to favour a protracted sentence of death.
fields.body:
This has been a bad week for the Commons, but an even worse week for wigs. Mr Speaker Martin does not intend to wear one. And the new Lord Chief Justice seems to favour a protracted sentence of death. They might perhaps be kept for criminal trials, he conceded in an interview in yesterday's Daily Telegraph, but even then, "wearing wigs, especially if they are spaniel-type wigs, enables us to be portrayed as out-of-touch dinosaurs - and I don't think that is helpful to public confidence."

And so, a mere 200 years after wig-wearing faded from the mainstream of public life, the classes that retained it - Speakers of the Commons, Lord Chancellors, senior lawyers - look doomed very soon to join the wigless majority. The habit of men wearing wigs, imported from France, caught on in this country in the middle years of the 17th century.

Soon all classes seemed to be doing it, though the frothiest concoctions of all were worn, of course, by the bigwigs. "At the end of the 17th century," one fashion historian writes, "a natural head of hair was the most unnatural sight imaginable." Women's wigs were quite outnumbered. Then fashion took one of its habitual lurches, so much so that in 1765 perruke-makers petitioned the king "setting forth their distress ... from the decline of the trade occasioned by the present mode of men in all stations wearing their own hair." Later, however, wigs rallied and might even be with us today, except for what we nowadays call a stealth tax: William Pitt's killer imposition, in 1795, of a tax on hair powder.

Some male wigs will survive even now, to cover baldness. But these are wigs of a lesser breed, which want people to think they are a real head of hair. What will be lost from our public life is the kind of wig which glories in its wiggishness. We have yet to learn Lord Irvine's intentions, but he too may find himself forced to join the trend. Should he refuse, Gordon Brown will know how to deal with him.

fields.headline: Oftel proposes shared local access
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Telecommunications regulator Oftel said yesterday it will allow shared access of the so-called local loop, allowing users to gain access to separate high speed data services without having to change their voice service provider.
fields.body:
Telecommunications regulator Oftel said yesterday it will allow shared access of the so-called local loop, allowing users to gain access to separate high speed data services without having to change their voice service provider.

Operators will be given the option of providing services such as fast internet access, video on demand or high-speed data transfer over the "unbundled" loop, which represents the final stretch of telephone line from local exchanges to domestic users. The unbundling of the loop is scheduled to be completed by the beginning of next year.

Consumers can therefore choose to buy higher bandwidth services from a competing operator while retaining their existing voice service with BT or Kingston Communications, Oftel said.

"Allowing two operators to provide different services over one telephone line means cus tomers can choose to keep their existing company for voice calls and buy high speed services from a competitor," director-general of telecommunications David Edmonds said. "Shared access will also make it easier for competitors to enter the market, as it allows companies to offer [digital subsriber line] services without voice telephony."

 Microsoft and Eloquent, an American-based internet media business specialist listed on the Nasdaq index, said yesterday they had signed an agreement to develop an enterprise communications solution for the management and delivery of streaming media, enabling companies to communicate faster with clients and employees.

The companies did not provide any financial details of the agreement. Eloquent's operations focus on so-called rich media business communications, which combine documents, graphics and digital audio and video content.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: On Tuesday we were introduced to hyper-ambitious would-be Labour MP Shahid Malik, the fastest carpetbagger in the west, and already further news arrives.
fields.body:
 On Tuesday we were introduced to hyper-ambitious would-be Labour MP Shahid Malik, the fastest carpetbagger in the west, and already further news arrives. Late last year, Perry Barr MP Jeff Rooker had decided to announce on New Year's day his intention to leave Westminster at the next election, and mentioned it to very few in the party. Jeff was in his constituency office on Christmas eve when the phone rang. On the other end was a young man saying that Jeff once met "my father, Mr Malik" before issuing a complete career resume, until Jeff interrupted and said he refused to discuss stepping down. Oh, replied Shahid, sadly. Jeff softened enough to offer one bit of advice - "you phoned my office on Christmas eve. And I answered it. That's what it's like being an MP" - but that seems unlikely to put him off, so we say again: find this man a seat.

 Carry On Up The Cabinet emails continue to flood in. Graham Garden writes supporting Kenneth Williams for O'Mandy, and suggesting, among others, Hattie Jacques for John Prescott (wasn't she famously competent?) and Syd James as Ken Livingstone. Graham also reminds us that November 8 is the anniversary of the first Goodies broadcast, which we trust BBC2 will mark properly. Meanwhile, Roy Stringer reports not only that this Diary game was the centre of discussion at his harvest dinner; but also that a discussion has sprung up on Compuserve's London Forum. And his daughter Louise proposes John Prescott be played by Terry Scott. Yes, Louise, that's spot on.

 Alopecian Sun editor David Yelland is so proud of inventing new sub-species the "metropolitan-elite" that he devotes two pages of witless juvenile rot to it. (Sometimes, I wonder if the incident when the subway train doors shut on his wig had any lasting neurological effect.) Hats off Hugo Young and Polly Toynbee for making the A-Z, especially Polly, described as "a raving leftie of the most dangerous kind." It seems a little harsh on history's more lethal dictators to equate them, in dangerous Marxist terms, with a leading light in the SDP. But perhaps the slaphead knows something we don't.

 Yet again, Mr Tony Blair's rhetorical sincerity is overwhelming, his moving speech on the environment elevated above all by the passage about his ferocious interest being sparked when a shadow cabinet member had a long debate about green issues with little Euan, then aged 10. Yes, yes, it really happened of course, and how good to see Mr T protecting his children's privacy, and refusing to use them for short-term political gain.

 The Speaker election created a splendid bond between high Tories and New Labour loyalists, the former finding the one-time Glaswegian shopfitter Michael Martin as awful as the latter ("the alternative is unspeakable," a shire gent muttered of him before one vote. "Let's vote for David Clark."). Its a reassuring sign of cabinet unity that Gordon Brown, Robin Cook and Bomber Short disobeyed orders and backed Mr Martin against George Young, but why is it that Mr T so distrusts Mr Martin? "Don't be so childish," an expert replies. "He's working class."

 How sad to see ITN's Teletext aiding the government by damaging the old-left candidate for Speaker. "Dunwoody: I was a suicidal anorexic," read a page 315 headline on Monday. It's true this referred not to Gwynneth but the jump jockey Richard, but sloppy work all the same.

 In San José, California, civic dignitaries welcomed a group of Filipino businessmen, by displaying a huge banner reading "Tuloy po kayo", or "Welcome Filipinos!". Well what it actually read was "Tuley po kayo" ("circumcise Filipinos!"), but it's a lovely thought anyway.

fields.headline: At this price?  Go-Ahead
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Rail passenger groups may have been cheering as French group Connex was stripped of the right to run the busy London to south coast commuter line, but spare a thought for the shareholders of Go-Ahead. Their company's joint venture with SNCF, the state-backed owner of the French rail network, has been awarded the franchise to run the line for the next 20 years.
fields.body:
Rail passenger groups may have been cheering as French group Connex was stripped of the right to run the busy London to south coast commuter line, but spare a thought for the shareholders of Go-Ahead. Their company's joint venture with SNCF, the state-backed owner of the French rail network, has been awarded the franchise to run the line for the next 20 years.

At first glance the risks in taking on the franchise look frightening. In order to win the franchise the joint venture, called Go-Via, has pledged to invest up to £1.5bn in the route over the course of the next 20 years. Analysts say the upfront investment will be around £100m.

Then there are risks. Staff morale at Connex is already said to be at rock bottom.

So it was not surprising to Go-Ahead, which is still under scrutiny for its role in the Paddington rail crash, that its shares closed 24.5p lower at 658p.

But balanced against such concerns are the potential gains. Broker HSBC Securities reckons the franchise win is positive and has upgraded its rating to "buy" and set an 850p target price.

The awarding of the franchise almost doubles the number of passengers using Go-Ahead's rail services. Go-Ahead already operates Thames Trains while Go-Via controls the Thameslink franchise which runs cross-London services.

Strong full-year results from Go-Ahead - pretax profits were a better-than-expected £44.8m - were largely attributable to the robust performance of its two rail franchises.

The fact the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority has got tough and stripped Connex of its franchise means other incumbent operators could be facing the same fate and Go-Ahead could pick-up more franchises.

Nevertheless, the risk lies in the execution. Go-Ahead's management, which recently rebuffed an 800p a share takeover offer, has much to prove. Hold on for the ride.

fields.headline: Peace and understanding
fields.trailText: Earlier this year I visited schools in the West Bank and Gaza, reading from my South African novels set during apartheid days. It is much more complex than Peter Preston suggests (Comment, October 23). Responses were sharp. "That is our experience!" Almost every question to me was philosophical or political. In South Africa, many young black people declared their parents had been too passive. They believed it was now up to them to stand up to injustice.
fields.body:
Earlier this year I visited schools in the West Bank and Gaza, reading from my South African novels set during apartheid days. It is much more complex than Peter Preston suggests (Comment, October 23). Responses were sharp. "That is our experience!" Almost every question to me was philosophical or political. In South Africa, many young black people declared their parents had been too passive. They believed it was now up to them to stand up to injustice.

It is true that the media and we are culpable. But it is because we did not pay attention to the injustices experienced by Palestinians before their children took on the role of David against Goliath. What would Anne Frank have said? We cannot expect peace unless there is an understanding of our shared humanity.

Beverley Naidoo Bournemouth, Dorset

 No doubt you will receive a deluge of mail attacking Linda Grant's article (The risk of peace, October 24). I am, however, relieved to see that, while it does not seek to condone the Israelis, it at least tries to understand how they have come to think the way they do. The situation is a lot more complicated than generally presented in the UK press and the gentile world would do well to remember that.

Rosalind de Charro Dordrecht, The Netherlands

fields.bodyText: Earlier this year I visited schools in the West Bank and Gaza, reading from my South African novels set during apartheid days. webTitle: Wrong diagnosis on medical injury claims

fields.headline: Wrong diagnosis on medical injury claims
fields.trailText: Your leader on no-fault compensation (October 23) accurately identifies the major injustice: that the abattoirs, renderers and farmers - some of whom must bear part of the blame for the BSE scandal - have received full and prompt compensation, but those who have lost loved ones from vCJD have had to fight every inch of the way and have not yet received anything.
fields.body:
Your leader on no-fault compensation (October 23) accurately identifies the major injustice: that the abattoirs, renderers and farmers - some of whom must bear part of the blame for the BSE scandal - have received full and prompt compensation, but those who have lost loved ones from vCJD have had to fight every inch of the way and have not yet received anything.

There are many innovative ways of overcoming the "casino-style civil justice system". For example, unlike other European Union countries, the burden of proving fault and the cause of injuries always rests in full with the victim in our courts, even where virtually all the information is held by the person who it is alleged caused the injury. Reversing that burden and taking other steps to punish, financially, wrongdoers who baulk at paying out compensation would lead to swifter payments to the injured with lower lawyers' bills.

The leap of faith to a no-fault compensation scheme as the answer for claims against the NHS is wholly misguided. There are no true no-fault schemes for medical negligence anywhere in the world. For example, the New Zealand scheme for people who have suffered "personal injury caused by medical misadventure" defines medical misadventure as "medical error or medical mishap". Further exclusions means that in reality a claimant has to prove medical negligence or malpractice without the protection the civil courts are designed to provide, and most victims of medical negligence go uncompensated.

The notion that medical negligence cases have escalated to "absurd levels" is similarly based on myth. In an article in the June British Medical Journal, independent health economists, insurance experts and accountants concluded that: "The stock of outstanding liabilities, valued at £2.8bn by the auditor-general, is a grossly misleading indicator of the impending cost of clinical negligence to the NHS."

The authors estimated the actual overall expenditure on medical negligence by the NHS, including legal costs, during 1998 at £84m. The increasing cost of compensation has not led to any slashing of health spending, but it has contributed substantially to the development of risk management and clinical guidance schemes designed to prevent medical accidents happening in the first place.

Russell Levy
Leigh, Day & Co
Russ@leighday.co.uk


Most clinical negligence cases are legally aided and most are unsustainable. Funding is granted on the advice of the claimant's lawyer, who has a direct interest. Successful health service defendants cannot recover legal costs, encouraging settlements regardless of merit. Cases supported by conditional-fee agreements have a high success rate. Legal aid for clinical negligence should be abolished and state funding should support conditional fees agreements where lawyers have incentives to pursue meritorious cases.

Anthony Barton
London

fields.headline: Load of bull
fields.trailText: I am sure John Sutherland (Keats and Co plough a lonely furrow, G2, October 23) would have been amused by a recent exchange in my A-Level business studies class. The students were doing a case study about a veterinary practice. One young man took it upon himself to explain to the class that cows had one multi-purpose orifice through which they both reproduced and defecated.
fields.body:
I am sure John Sutherland (Keats and Co plough a lonely furrow, G2, October 23) would have been amused by a recent exchange in my A-Level business studies class. The students were doing a case study about a veterinary practice. One young man took it upon himself to explain to the class that cows had one multi-purpose orifice through which they both reproduced and defecated.

Somewhat shocked I queried this claim at which point a rather earnest young woman pointed out that this was also the case with dogs. However, the point at which I finally collapsed into fits of laughter came when a rather quiet student piped up: "You mean bulls and cows are the same species? I never realised before." Danny Proudfoot
Northwich, Cheshire
danny@proudfootd. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Short haul of travel tips
fields.trailText: The prospect of 400 passengers all trying to negotiate their way around serving trolleys, feet sticking out into the aisles and queues for the toilet (Dangers lurking on long-haul flights, October 24) is a terrifying safety hazard in itself.
fields.body:
 The prospect of 400 passengers all trying to negotiate their way around serving trolleys, feet sticking out into the aisles and queues for the toilet (Dangers lurking on long-haul flights, October 24) is a terrifying safety hazard in itself. Perhaps sedentary isometric exercises conducted by cabin crew, like the safety demonstration, would be a sensible alternative. Air France provides leaflets to all passengers.

Mike Broadbent
Luton

 So, £5bn from the government, £10bn from passengers and freight users. Where is the contribution from Railtrack shareholders and the much-vaunted investment market?

Graham Mullan
Bristol

 A passenger complains to Connex South Central about an insensitive advertising campaign and nothing happens. Larry Elliott (October 23) mentions it and overnight the posters come down. Any chance he could mention the dodgy ticket gates at Brighton station, or the routine overcrowding on late afternoon express services?

Simon Elliott
Brighton

 Elected Greens may indeed now be a feature of the political landscape (Letters, October 24). But what is the point of having representatives who then vanish at the first sign of controversy - ie the great fuel tax revolt. As we approach the 60-day deadline, are Mr Johnson and his colleagues busy organising counter-demonstrations?

Andrew Smith
Falkirk

 Remind me not to instruct a law lecturer (Letters, October 23). Mr Dalziel did not pay any insurance premiums: his motorcycle was unlicensed, untaxed and bore false number plates. This was not an issue of life insurance, but a third-party damages claim.

Pat Charnock
London

fields.headline: High note from Leeds
fields.trailText: Can I take issue with the headlines over Andrew Clements's review of Alessio Bax's recital (October 20). The heading "Decline of Leeds Competition" together with the phrase "the allure that used to go with winning at Leeds is not what it was" are belied by Sir Simon Rattle's statement on BBC television that he would not like to have been a member of this year's jury as the standard was so high. The allure must have been there, as 17 first-prize winners and many others chose to perform at Leeds this year.
fields.body:
Can I take issue with the headlines over Andrew Clements's review of Alessio Bax's recital (October 20). The heading "Decline of Leeds Competition" together with the phrase "the allure that used to go with winning at Leeds is not what it was" are belied by Sir Simon Rattle's statement on BBC television that he would not like to have been a member of this year's jury as the standard was so high. The allure must have been there, as 17 first-prize winners and many others chose to perform at Leeds this year.

Secondly, the numerical results of the voting at Leeds are never disclosed and the members of the jury are contractually precluded from disclosing them, except in the case of a unanimous decision, which is always announced publicly and has only occurred twice in the history of the competition. This was not the case this year.

Finally, the mention of some of our outstanding finalists of the 70s does not do justice to some subsequent finalists - Kimura Parker, Lortie, Berezovsky, Pizzaro, Vogt, McCawley and Madzar are all enjoying fine international careers. I can assure you the piano competition is continuing onwards and upwards.

Fanny Waterman
Chairman and artistic director, Leeds International Pianoforte Competition

Andrew Clements implies that the decision to award Alessio Bax first prize at this year's competition was unanimous. As a member of the jury at Leeds, I am not at liberty to disclose how I, or any of my colleagues, voted. However, to set the record straight: the vote for Bax was by no means unanimous.

Misha Donat
London

fields.headline: A Speaker for the nation
fields.trailText: Following the elections for the new Speaker of the Commons, we have come to the conclusion that the public has been left out (Ex-shop steward Martin is Speaker, October 24). The Speaker, although directly responsible for the MPs and control of the Commons, also represents the interests of the people in parliament. The Speaker has a direct influence on how discussions are conducted and can change the direction the argument takes.
fields.body:
Following the elections for the new Speaker of the Commons, we have come to the conclusion that the public has been left out (Ex-shop steward Martin is Speaker, October 24). The Speaker, although directly responsible for the MPs and control of the Commons, also represents the interests of the people in parliament. The Speaker has a direct influence on how discussions are conducted and can change the direction the argument takes.

The revolution of 1649 is the most important event in English history, representing the desire for democracy in English politics. More than 100 years before the French and American revolutions, we implemented a constitutional democracy to replace a monarchical dictatorship - not so that 351 years later a governmental elite can bypass our representative parliament to enforce its own myopic prerogatives.

Surely if the Speaker is the public voice in the Commons, not the puppet for the oligarichal collective represented by the prime minister and governing party, this person should be voted for by the public.
Sarah Moulson
Maxine Luscombe
Chichester
warah65@hotmail.com

I was disappointed to read the cynical account of Michael Martin's election as Speaker (Discreet wooing pays off for Martin, October 24). I met him when he volunteered to act as Speaker to the Children's parliament. Sixty nervous 11-year-olds assembled in the Granada studio's mock chamber for a series of debates on the environment. He was superb: unpatronising, kindly, endlessly patient, full of encouragement and he talked to them freely afterwards. Perhaps he is just a real human being, not a robot. All credit to MPs for having the good sense to elect him.
Prof Ted Wragg
Exeter University

So, Michael Martin will be "the first Speaker to be an authentic representative of the industrial working class, the child of an impoverished broken home". The same quotation could have been attributed to the late and much lamented George Thomas, Speaker from 1976-83. He was from a Welsh mining family, his father deserting his mother and four brothers and sisters when George was six, leaving them in dire poverty. Does the fact that he managed to become a schoolteacher lift him out of the working class ?
Bob Thompson
Guernsey
bobttorteval@gtonline.net

As a former Commons researcher, I hope the new Speaker heeds the conversations he had with us. Reforming the electoral system is a start. Most serious of all is the abuse of natural justice and of the Commons' own rules that occurs in the surreal choices in the selection of amendments to government bills.

Having moved from Commons researcher to elected councillor, I am only too aware that the democratic procedures afforded those in local government are denied to those sent to parliament.
Cllr Gareth Epps
Oxford

As a local councillor I have strongly supported Best Value at both Staffordshire county council and Lichfield district council. I do not know if the new parliament office accommodation is Best Value (MPs marvel at view from £230m new home, October 24) but I am sure that the expensive time spent on electing the Speaker is not!
Cllr Steven Norman
Burntwood, Staff

If the election procedure was felt to be an unsatisfactory system, why did MPs wait until now to complain, after the vote has taken place, and not try to change the system, in the months prior to the election?
Monica Sweeney
Edinburgh

fields.headline: Xerox plans to cut 10,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Xerox, the beleaguered business machines company, announced a $1bn (£690m) cost-cutting plan yesterday expected to result in more than 10,000 job cuts as it posted its first quarterly loss in 16 years.
fields.body:
Xerox, the beleaguered business machines company, announced a $1bn (£690m) cost-cutting plan yesterday expected to result in more than 10,000 job cuts as it posted its first quarterly loss in 16 years.

The job cuts, which could double once outsourced businesses are included, are expected to focus on administrative operations and the elimination of overlapping businesses. More than 100 of the company's 4,000 UK jobs could go as a result of the latest plan, the company's third reorganisation in two years.

Paul Allaire, Xerox chairman and chief executive, also outlined a plan to sell off various parts of the business to reduce a debt burden of about $18bn. The sale of the company's equipment financing business, its 50% stake in Fuji Xerox and its operations in China are expected to raise between $2bn and $4bn.

The company is also looking for investment in its Silicon Valley research operations as part of a plan to reduce its research and development costs.

Following the announcement, shares in Xerox fell in Wall Street trading yesterday.

Investors and analysts expressed disappointment over the timing and scope of the reorganisation. One analyst said that "10,000 people is just not enough. They are either going to have to change the current product mix or drastically change how the products are built".

Xerox has lost ground in the past year to nimbler rivals offering digital products which return higher margins. As part of yesterday's reorganisation, the company said it intended to focus on its growing and higher margin colour copying products. However, analysts fear that this may be too little too late to address the problems of declining profits.

Yesterday, Xerox blamed its first quarterly loss since 1986 on a downturn in US sales, a lack of experienced sales people following a botched re-oranisation last year and greater competition.

The company lost $167m in the three months to the end of September, compared with a profit of $339m for the same quarter last year. About $55m was due to a bad loan provision involving the company's Mexican operations, which the US securities and exchange commission is still investigating. Sales of $4.5bn were down 4% in the year.

In a conference call with investors yesterday, Anne Mulcahy, president and chief operating officer, said she expected to return to profitability next year after selling off the various business and reducing the amount of money Xerox was spending on debt repayments.

The company said it would sell its financing business over time. Its inability to announce a deal for either this division or the other assets caused some disappointment yesterday.

Xerox is understood to be talking to GE Capital about the sale of its financing unit and to Fuji Photo Film about the sale of its half in their joint venture.

Earlier this month, the company was forced to reveal details of a $7bn credit line to ease concerns about liquidity prompted by the heavy debt burden. Yesterday, Barry Remeril, the company's finance director, said that he did not anticipate breaching the covenants on any bank loans.

Xerox has announced two reorganisations in the past two years. In 1998 it called for a 10,000 head count reduction. This plan was then followed by phase two, announced in March this year, which called for a further 5,200 job cuts.

Xerox Europe, which employs 19,000 in total, bore the brunt of first reorganisation. A spokesman for the company said yesterday that these existing cost-saving plans would be accelerated.

fields.headline: Blu team bickers over 3G auction
fields.trailText: The fall-out from the abrupt ending of Italy's third generation mobile phone licence auction, after the BT-backed Blu consortium pulled out, intensified yesterday with acrimonious exchanges between key players.
fields.body:
The fall-out from the abrupt ending of Italy's third generation mobile phone licence auction, after the BT-backed Blu consortium pulled out, intensified yesterday with acrimonious exchanges between key players.

The Italian government, which is furious that the auction raised only around half the expected total, grudgingly accepted that the bidding process was over and is demanding Blu surrender its €2.1bn (£1.3bn) auction deposit on the grounds it did not stick to the rules - a position which Blu disputes.

But the national audit committee said it would investigate the licence auction to establish if the manner in which it was conducted caused damage to the public accounts.

Autostrade - one of the key Blu shareholders, which is controlled by the Benetton family - turned on BT yesterday arguing that it should either increase its shareholding or quit the consortium.

"There needs to be some clarity between shareholders: there needs to be shareholders who are compatible and cohesive," according to Autostrade chief executive Vito Gamberale. "If we can't succeed in finding an accord, there is always separation."

Autostrade was one of the key shareholders who refused to continue bidding for a 3G licence, forcing Blu to withdraw. That left only five bidders for five licences, effectively ending the auction with only €13.7bn raised.

Last weekend BT offered to increase its 20% stake in Blu and to make a one-off payment into the consortium to allow it to carry on bidding. But while it was prepared to take its stake to around 30% that was well short of the demands of some of the other shareholders. Italian sources said they wanted BT to take a shareholding more in keeping with its influence - as the technology partner - over the day to day running of Blu.

Last night BT refused to comment on the latest twists in the drama.

fields.headline: Wolves bid loses fizz
fields.trailText: Time may be about to be called on the takeover offer for Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries.
fields.body:
Time may be about to be called on the takeover offer for Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries.

It is two months since entrepreneur Robert Breare first approached the pub and breweries group and, according to the market gossips, his interest is waning.

Yesterday the stock price of the company - which brews Bank's, Cameron and Marston's bitter - slid 35.5p, or 8.34% to 390p, on talk that Mr Breare and his private equity backers have turned their attention to the pub estate of Whitbread, up 5p to 465p.

Whitbread stunned the market last week by announcing plans to sell its 3,000-strong pub estate in order to concentrate on expanding hotel and leisure activities, such as its Marriott hotels and David Lloyd sports clubs.

Analysts estimate that the Whitbread estate could fetch £1.4bn. Admittedly, this is a tad higher than Mr Breare's tentative £470m offer for Wolves. The Whitbread business, however, is much cleaner - it has no breweries - and it has nothing like Wolves's £584m debt.

Apparently Mr Breare and his private equity chums have become frustrated with the attitude of Wolves and its adviser, NM Rothschild. Although the firm put itself up for sale earlier this month and reopened talks, Mr Breare is still finding it tough gaining access to financial data needed to launch a formal bid, it is said.

Sources close to Mr Breare admit that he has taken a look at the Whitbread estate, although they insist he is still interested in Wolves.

This has led some to conclude that Mr Breare's new posture is nothing more than a negotiating tactic to reduce the offer price for Wolves. Aside from Whitbread, Bass, 1.5p higher at 671.5p, and Scottish & Newcastle, off 1p to 446p, are also trying to offload pubs at the moment.

Whether Mr Breare has turned his back on Wolves or not, one thing is clear - the shares have further to fall.

The FTSE 100, meanwhile, ended higher for the fourth session as investors rekindled their love affair with telecommunications stocks.

Opinion was divided over the reasons: there was relief among some that the Italian mobile licence auction has ended early, while others said the sector was "bombed out" and due to bounce. Broking powerhouse Morgan Stanley, which advised its clients to buy as many European telecom stocks as they could lay their hands on, may have had an influence.

Whatever the reason, the effects were electrifying. Four of the five best performing blue chip stocks were from the sector. Colt Telecom led the charge, with a gain of 295p to £22.80, closely followed by Energis, up 64p to 554, BT, 81p stronger at 788p, and Cable & Wireless, 89p better at 950p.

Lifted by these performances, the FTSE 100 ended up 122.5 points at 6,438.4, its best closing level since September 14. Over the past four sessions the blue chip index has gained nearly 300 points.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 rose 46 points to 6,564.1 and the Techmark powered ahead 114.8 to 3,541.25.

Away from the telecoms sector, controls group Invensys, up 11p to 148p, continued to move higher on bid speculation. Traders reckon that a predator is building a stake.

Lower down the corporate ladder dealers spent much of the day trying to spot the next takeover target.

With the bids for plant hire group Hewden-Stuart, up 20.5p to 89p, and chemicals distributor Ellis & Everard, 55p higher at 203.5p, now out in the open, the speculative money moved into estate agent Countrywide Assured, 8.5p better at 116.5p, and engineer Bodycote, up 24.5p to 190p.

Stockbroker Collins Stewart made a strong debut, closing at 365p - a rise of 49p from its offer price.

Shire Pharmaceuticals fell 86p to £13.09 on the news that its promotion to the FTSE 100 has been delayed.

fields.headline: Privatisation goes one step further
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Water could be next as British service providers step up the pace of restructuring
fields.trailText: The pace of restructuring among Britain's privatised industries is accelerating. Yesterday alone we saw Granada Media, the dominant commercial television broadcaster, selling HTV, hastening the process which is set to see it and Carlton as the sole terrestrially based groups in ITV.
fields.body:
The pace of restructuring among Britain's privatised industries is accelerating. Yesterday alone we saw Granada Media, the dominant commercial television broadcaster, selling HTV, hastening the process which is set to see it and Carlton as the sole terrestrially based groups in ITV.

Simultaneously, the shadow strategic rail authority, aided and abetted by John Prescott, stripped French-owned Connex of one of its rail franchises and handed it to Go-Via, already operators of Thames Trains and Thameslink. The SSRA and Mr Prescott have made it quite plain that they want to see the 25 train operating companies in the hands of a few large groups virtually the re-emergence of the UK's railway system before nationalisation after the second world war.

A rash

In the energy market a rash of takeovers allied to liberalisation of the domestic supply market is prompting the creation of a few dominant players and water could be the next in line for a big shake-up - albeit 11 years after privatisation. Superficially, little has changed: the 10 water and sewerage groups and 15 water-only companies in England and Wales remain in place as geographical monopolies in private hands. There has been no restructuring or consolidation although (see box) five of the 10 dual-purpose groups are now in foreign hands.

Chris Mellor, chief executive of Anglian Water Group (AWG), believes the UK could be on the verge of as fundamental a change as that of denationalisation in 1989. The catalysts he cites include the last periodic review by retired industry regulator, Sir Ian Byatt, which brought the first price cuts since privatisation, passing on efficiency gains to customers.

But these gains are no longer there to be made and investors have shunned water groups, aghast at the harsh regulatory environment in which they operate and unable to see the earnings potential and economies of scale and scope they need to mark the shares up. Several recent events, however, are set to change the landscape. The first move was the takeover of Thames Water by German group RWE.

The two critical factors are the unravelling in the high court of a deal under which Western Power Distribution, new US owners of Welsh multi-utility Hyder, wanted to outsource the operation and management of Dwr Cymru, its water business, to United Utilities, and Sir Ian's replacement at Ofwat by Philip Fletcher, a more open-minded regulator.

Brian Duckworth, managing director of Severn Trent, which won the court ruling that the WPD/UU deal breached UK and EU regulations, is cautiously optimistic that the judgment, by creating a level play ing field in the form of an open tender process, could encourage outsourcing deals and, via them, industry restructuring.

"We could end up with three big players offering to do work for other companies which own the water assets," he says, though he thinks the Dwr Cymru contract could now be split into several parts. Either way Severn Trent, Thames and, Mr Mellor says, Anglian will bid for the contract.

Anglian is at the cutting edge of change. This summer it bought construction group Morrison for £260m in anticipation of an industry shake-up. Though outsourcing in the water industry is, he says, in its infancy AWG plans to use Morrison's expertise to provide services, including the laying of pipes, to industries such as gas, electricity and telecoms as well as water. "In our view this trend is inexorable," he says, adding that broad-based service providers enjoy a PE ratio up to 10 times higher than AWG's 10.

The onus for change is on Mr Fletcher. Under Sir Ian, Ofwat set a limit on mergers and takeovers that would not automatically go to the competition commission and set his stall against consolidation, arguing that the loss of one firm could only be compensated for by a hefty price-cut. "That put a block on consolidation in the industry by UK-owned companies though it gave a free rein to foreign groups," says Mr Mellor.

The competition

Mr Duckworth says the whole process is over-regulated. "The real issue is who becomes our national champion and whether we have got the capability when we are still relatively small companies vis-à-vis the French or Germans who can come here and buy utilities when our hands are tied. The economies of scale we want are frustrated by regulators."

Peter Vass, director of the centre for the study of the regulated industries at Bath University, says the encouragement of outsourcing and the creation of three or four operational managers is vital to winning the economies of scale that would enable UK groups to compete overseas. That would leave Ofwat free to regulate the companies owning the water assets, with competition in supply setting the market price. So far Mr Fletcher has been cautious about his approach, indicating he favours consolidation via outsourcing but is against the more radical - and abandoned - Kelda plan to turn Yorkshire Water into a mutual owned by its customers.

Mr Vass says: "The French model of municipally owned assets and operations provided by the private sector, just two groups effectively, is being looked at again. I think we will see a relaxation of policy and some cautious experimenting."

Mr Mellor thinks a chance was lost with the original privatisation scheme. "The current blocks are totally arbitrary and the regulators should, from the start, have allowed the market to consolidate the companies into three or four much larger units. The big prize for the customers would have been far bigger price cuts," he says in a nod to Mr Fletcher to recognise how the world has changed since 1989.

webTitle: Business: Bookham Technology share prices storm back

fields.headline: Bookham buoyed
fields.trailText: After a miserable month things are starting to look up for optical chip maker Bookham Technology.
fields.body:
After a miserable month things are starting to look up for optical chip maker Bookham Technology.

The company has been hit by rumours of quality control problems with products shipped to Nortel, and disquiet over share sales by company directors and early stage venture capital backers.

But yesterday its share price stormed back, rising 295p, or 11.80%, to £27.95 after getting the thumbs up from an influential US broker - a rare occurrence for a British tech stock.

The broker in question, Wit SoundView, was yesterday advising clients that at current levels Bookham shares were a "strong buy".

Wit reckons Bookham has the world's most promising technology platform for the integration of optical components on to a single chip. It says: "We believe Bookham has an opportunity to build a significant position if not the leading position."

webTitle: Lawyers say new evidence will rock Lockerbie trial

fields.headline: Lawyers say new evidence will rock Lockerbie trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: Crucial new evidence released to defence lawyers in the Lockerbie trial will have "the greatest conceivable effect" on the proceedings, the court in the Netherlands heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Crucial new evidence released to defence lawyers in the Lockerbie trial will have "the greatest conceivable effect" on the proceedings, the court in the Netherlands heard yesterday.

Lawyers for the two Libyans, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, accused of the biggest act of mass murder in British history, launched urgent inquiries in six countries after being handed evidence from "a foreign source" on Monday.

The fresh evidence was first released to the crown on October 4, but defence lawyers said the information was so sensitive it threatened the lives of potential witnesses and also directly impinged on the defence of the accused.

The accused deny charges of murder, conspiracy to murder, and breaching the Aviation Security Act, and have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming among others the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command.

There is intense speculation that the "foreign source" of the evidence is Syria.

William Taylor QC, for Mr Megrahi, said: "The information we have received, if true, is of the greatest conceivable effect on this trial." He asked for an adjournment to the £3m- a-month proceedings. Lord Sutherland, the judge, adjourned the trial until Tuesday.

fields.headline: Hello dolly
fields.standfirst:
Patsy Kensit launches radio Barbie.fm

Net news
fields.trailText: Barbie, the doll designed by toy company Mattel, yesterday launched her radio career. Barbie.fm, which is sponsored by Mattel, started broadcasting over the internet with the help of actress Patsy Kensit.
fields.body:
Barbie, the doll designed by toy company Mattel, yesterday launched her radio career. Barbie.fm, which is sponsored by Mattel, started broadcasting over the internet with the help of actress Patsy Kensit.

Aimed at girls aged between three and nine, it will be going out live for the next two days and will address issues such as music, animals and fashion. There will also be interviews with pop stars.

Two sisters, aged eight and six, came up with the idea by playing a pretend game of radio shows featuring their Barbie dolls. David Freeman, the girls' father, and a TV presenter and DJ, contacted Mattel with the idea.

"Barbie has done lots of things in her 41 years. She is about having a belief in yourself and doing what you want to do. This is what we wanted to promote," a Mattel spokesperson said

By lunchtime yesterday the site had attracted more than 50,000 people.

Based in the village hall at Shipton-on-Cherwell, Oxfordshire, the station will feature Kate Winslet, Andi Peters, the TV personality, and comedienne Sandi Toksvig.

Young girls are also going on air. Lily Magenis, aged 11, introduced a Britney Spears song, and Lucy Ellis, also 11, was interviewed by Miss Kensit.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Big finance meets big brother
fields.body:
Big finance meets big brother

Finance minister Gundars Berzins has had a 24-hour webcam installed in his office to show the Latvian electorate that he is not sleeping on the job.

With an eye on next year's municipal polls, the People's party election campaign chief, Jurgis Liepnieks, said it was important for people to see what politicians do every day and how many hours they work. "Usually, people only see politicians give speeches," he said.

The internet broadcasts, which started last week, do not include sound. When the minister is out, an on-screen notice says where he is.

The webcam will be rotated around other offices of ministers, a spokesman said. www.tautaspartija.lv/ministry

Dissident 'dies after torture'

The organiser behind one of the largest protests against Chinese rule in the restive Muslim north-west region of Xinjiang has died under police torture, a separatist group claimed yesterday.

Abduhelil Abdulmejit, who was jailed after widescale unrest in February 1997 in Yining city, died on October 17, the East Turkistan Information Centre based in Germany said. Prison officials say that he died of pneumonia.
AP, Beijing

Kim pledge on missile launches

North Korea indicated that it would never launch long-range missiles, United States officials said yesterday.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said she took seriously North Korean leader Kim Jong-il's remark - delivered offhand at a gymnastics show - that Pyongyang would never launch such missiles.

Mr Kim raised the matter on Monday night, when an image of a Taepodong I missile was flashed before the audience.

Afterwards, Mrs Albright said: "He [Mr Kim] quipped that this was the first satellite launch and it would be the last." Mrs Albright said.

Asked if she interpreted that as a pledge for a permanent moratorium on missile launches, Albright she said: "I take what he said as serious as to his desire to move forward to resolve various questions."

Speaking after the historic two-day meeting, a state department official explained that a North Korean missile cannot hit the US unless it travels through space. "The kind of missiles that we're really worried about, he's pledged to never launch again," the official said.

Many analysts are convinced that North Korea has the capacity to strike at the perimeter of the US, but diplomats could not confirm if Mr Kim's assurances covered all missiles that could be used against other nations.

Mrs Albright is set to make a stop in Seoul today to tell South Korean and Japanese officials about her meetings with Mr Kim.
Christopher Torchia, Pyongyang

Ebola death toll climbs to 60

The death toll in Uganda from an Ebola outbreak climbed yesterday to 60 people out of 165 suspected cases.

Ugandan officials said five new cases were admitted in the last 24 hours and that five patients had died.

World Health Organisation spokesman Valery Abramov said yesterday that several cases of Ebola reported in refugee camps had proved wrong. He added that all confirmed cases had so far been confined to the Gulu region.

Mr Abramov also said that the epidemic could last up to three months, although WHO officials on the ground believe it could be contained in just a month.
AP, Kampala

Judge ends Israeli ban on Wagner

A judge yesterday refused to stop the first-ever scheduled concert performance in Israel of a work by Adolf Hitler's favourite composer, Richard Wagner.

Despite objections from Holocaust survivors, the concert - including the 20-minute Siegfried Idyll - is set for Friday in Rishon Le Ziyyon, south of Tel Aviv.

District court judge Yehuda Zaft rejected the appeal for a temporary restraining order to stop the concert. He said that freedom of expression requires a wide variety of views to be heard and debated in public, and "the court should not interfere".

While acknowledging that Wagner was "an extreme anti-Semite who favoured a Jew-free Germany", judge Zaft ruled that the fact that a Wagner work would be played in a concert in Rishon Le Ziyyon would not directly harm the survivors who brought the appeal. Lawyers said they would appeal.

Ehud Gross, director of the Rishon Le Ziyyon Symphony Orchestra said that Wagner must not become a symbol of the Holocaust. "We must separate the man from the music," he said, though he admitted that some of Wagner's musical compositions have anti-Semitic themes.
Mark Lavie, AP, Tel Aviv

Lawyers said they would appeal. Ehud Gross, director of the Rishon Le Ziyyon Symphony Orchestra said that Wagner must not become a symbol of the Holocaust. webTitle: Straw to prevent repeat of Tyson debacle

fields.headline: Straw to prevent repeat of Tyson debacle
fields.standfirst: Special report: boxing
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night announced changes to the immigration rules designed to ban serious criminals from visiting Britain in the wake of the Mike Tyson debacle earlier this year.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night announced changes to the immigration rules designed to ban serious criminals from visiting Britain in the wake of the Mike Tyson debacle earlier this year.

Mr Straw sparked an outcry among Labour MPs in May when he allowed the American former world heavyweight champion and convicted rapist into Britain for the second time in six months despite protests from women's groups that his visits made a mockery of the government's stand against domestic violence.

Visitors who have been sentenced to 10 years or more in prison or been convicted of a crime involving violence, sexual violence or guns, will be refused entry to Britain by immigration officers under the rule changes.

The new rules will put the onus on visitors who have been to jail for any term to declare their criminal convictions when they arrive in Britain. Failure to do so will result in them being charged with "deceiving an immigration officer" and facing deportation as illegal entrants.

At the time of the Tyson affair, Mr Straw complained that the existing immigration rules were unfair and inconsistent in that they only tended to catch "celebrity villains" whose visits were discussed in the media or who were recognised by immigration staff. Only about 10 to 20 people a year have been prevented from entering Britain under the old rules even though they were theoretically much "tougher" because they were supposed to ban anyone who had served a sentence of more than 12 months.

On both visits by Tyson, who came to Britain to fight in "pay per view" boxing promotions, Mr Straw allowed him to enter the country under an "exceptional circumstances" clause.

This exemption will remain along with a loophole allowing serious convicted criminals to visit Britain where there are clear compassionate circumstances. The new rule will apply only to non-EU citizens.

The change in the immigration rules was promised at the time of the last Tyson visit in an attempt to defuse the row.

Maria Fyfe, Labour MP for Glasgow Maryhill, who led the campaign against Tyson, claimed at the time the decision to let him enter the country sent a message to women that a boxing match mattered more than the fight against domestic violence.

webTitle: Vodka and smoking lay Russians low

fields.headline: Vodka and smoking lay Russians low
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The health of Russians is getting worse, experts said yesterday. They blamed poor living conditions and too much drinking and smoking.
fields.body:
The health of Russians is getting worse, experts said yesterday. They blamed poor living conditions and too much drinking and smoking.

Interfax news agency quoted Oleg Shchepin of the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences as referring to "a national catastrophe".

He was speaking at a health ministry meeting called to discuss the decline seen in the last year. Mr Shchepin said overall life expectancy fell by one year in 1999 to 65.5 years,an average age of 59.8 for men and 72 for women. The general level of illness had risen 15%. The death rate was 14.7 people per 1,000 while the birth rate stood at 8.4 per 1,000, Mr Shchepin said. The official 1998 figures were 13.6 and 8.8 respectively.

Andrei Vorobyev, a haematologist, was quoted as saying at the meeting that two of the main reasons for the worsening figures were smoking and vodka, which resulted in more cancer cases, heart problems and death from accidents. The prime minister, Vladimir Putin, has expressed worry that the nation is dwindling.

fields.headline: Time stood still
fields.standfirst: Elisabeth Mahoney sees a Beckett season with a difference
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Mahoney sees a Beckett season with a difference...
fields.body:
As Coronation Street's Fred Elliot might put it, "There's nowt wrong with repetition. I say, there's nowt wrong with repetition". I don't think I was meant to think of the Weatherfield butcher in Beckett Time, the season of Beckett-inspired treats shown at various venues in Glasgow, but there was plenty of time for such meanderings.

This was a season that eschewed Waiting for Godot and went instead for a Brazilian puppet show and a Beckett flotation tank. A quizzical take on an already challenging oeuvre, we witnessed attempts at an evocation of Beckett's worldview, tributes to his way of seeing - the good, the bad and, worst of all, the ever so slightly dull.

Quat and Quadrat was based on a Beckett ballet. "Do you think we're meant to hit them to get them going?" one woman seethed after what seemed like a pre-balletic eternity in front of some seated, hooded figures. I've got a short attention span you know". I was too worried that she was a member of the cast to be friendly. Eventually, the hooded ones rose and walked in repetitive patterns for a very long time indeed, next to squares of gravel lit in primary colours.

Grupo Sobrevento were better, with their puppetry equivalent of Camus's The Myth of Sisyphus. Their puppets, one of whom looked like Beckett as an old man, took more time than you thought existed to do simple things, in maddening, repetitious gestures. But we were watching mainly for the puppetry moves, the physical jerks and the laughs that followed.

The one production to capture and at the same time refresh the spirit of Beckett was Something There. Declaring itself "music theatre", it set out to see if Beckett's 1974 poem of the same name could be translated into drama. The result was moving and intellectually crisp, with Marisa Zanotti as a young woman facing, fleeing and then conquering the social world.

When Beckett wrote, time was different, slower. Maybe now, his absurdist repetition makes him a man out of time, but at least one production in Beckett Time got to the radical otherness of his vision. We saw John Minihan's Colour Me Beckett, a series of the iconic black-and-white photographic images, but also Beckett in colour for the first time. He looked lovely, old, wrapped up against the cold. Beckett Time tried to show us his writing in full colour too. That it succeeded in (one) part should not be underestimated.

 Something There is at the Lemon Tree Theatre, Aberdeen, on November 3 and 4. Colour Me Beckett is also at the Lemon Tree from November 2 to December 22. Details on 01224 642230.

webTitle: Plea for vote on nuclear dumping

fields.headline: Plea for vote on nuclear dumping
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russian anti-nuclear campaigners yesterday demanded a popular vote on whether the country should be turned into what they dub "the world's nuclear waste dump". They submitted petitions to the authorities carrying more than 2.5m signatures of people opposed to government plans to store other countries' nuclear waste.
fields.body:
Russian anti-nuclear campaigners yesterday demanded a popular vote on whether the country should be turned into what they dub "the world's nuclear waste dump". They submitted petitions to the authorities carrying more than 2.5m signatures of people opposed to government plans to store other countries' nuclear waste.

The campaigners, including Greenpeace, hope to force Russia's first referendum on an environmental issue.

Storage of foreign nuclear waste is illegal in Russia. But, envisaging billions of pounds in profits, the atomic energy minister, Yevgeni Adamov, has submitted a bill to parliament which would allow not only nuclear waste processing but also storage.

The new legislation could be passed by the end of the year, making it possible for major nuclear countries to add Russia to the list of repositories for their troublesome waste.

Russian government documents obtained by Greenpeace propose that more than 20,000 tonnes of spent nuclear fuel be imported initially, and name 14 countries from Japan to Germany as possible clients.

The atomic energy ministry estimates income of £14bn, half of which would be profit, the other half used to build and maintain the storage facilities. Four possible sites are being considered, in the Urals, the far east, and the far north.

An alternative plan, believed to be supported by the US, has an American company, Non-Proliferation Trust Inc, pushing for the Russian storage of 10,000 tonnes of foreign nuclear waste.

A strong signal of the Russian nuclear lobby's determination to take in the world's waste came on Monday when Bulgaria disclosed that Mr Adamov told Sofia last week that the waste obtained from reprocessing spent fuel from the latter's Kozloduy plant would not be returned from Russia to Bulgaria for storage.

"Temporary storage" of such material "might bring considerable profit to Russia and would not be detrimental to the ecology", Mr Adamov said earlier this month.

Greenpeace activists draped the parliament building in slogans declaring "we don't want to live on a nuclear rubbish dump." By law, 2m signatures are needed to force a referendum. But it would be surprising if the government allowed one on this issue if it has decided to back the storage plan.

webTitle: Arts: Sarah Bernhardt a great stage actor

fields.headline: Desperately seeking Sarah
fields.standfirst: Sarah Bernhardt was perhaps the greatest actor the stage has ever known. Cocteau, Gielgud and Lawrence all adored her. So, asks  Stuart Jeffries, why is she still such a mystery?
fields.trailText: Sarah Bernhardt was perhaps the greatest actor the stage has ever known. Cocteau, Gielgud and Lawrence all adored her. So, asks Stuart Jeffries, why is she still such a mystery?
fields.body:
DH Lawrence saw Sarah Bernhardt in La Dame aux Camélias at the Theatre Royal, Nottingham, in 1906. She was, he wrote, "the incarnation of violent emotion, liberating the primitive passions of woman". John Gielgud, recalling a lifetime's theatre-going to Le Monde in 1991, remembered seeing her at the Coliseum in London, performing a self-written piece called Champ d'Honneur. "It was during the first world war, Sarah had already lost her leg... She appeared lying on a tree trunk from which she pulled out as if by miracle the French tricolour, before declaiming a long patriotic poem in French. I was bowled over." Such was Marcel Proust's regard for the actress that he created a character called Berma based on her for his magnum opus A la Recherche du Temps Perdu.

Sarah Bernhardt was an enigmatic, ultimately one-legged, probably bisexual, part-Jewish, self-mythologising hunting and travelling enthusiast. She was also, quite possibly, the greatest actor ever.

Her remarkably long career extended from her first performances at the Comédie-Française in 1861 to her death in 1923, took in 70 roles and 125 plays. Born in Paris in 1844 to a Dutch courtesan and a father whose identity is uncertain but who was probably French, Bernhardt knew from the start the life of an adventuress - thanks to her mother's lifestyle.

But the mother didn't care for the girl, arranged for Bernhardt to be brought up by relations and parcelled her off at the age of seven to boarding school. Later, at a convent school in Versailles, Sarah became obsessed with religion and decided to devote her life to God. Her mother, however, had other ideas: inspired by another man in her life, the Duc de Morny, half-brother of Louis Napoleon, she sent her daughter to the Conservatory for Dramatic Arts. Against her will, as a result, Bernhardt devoted her life to the theatre.

The influential Duc later managed to win her a place at the Comédie-Française, where she made her debut in 1862, pronouncing: "The curtain of my life has risen." Two years later she gave birth to a son, but chose not to marry. Instead, she took up a contract at the Thétre de l'Odéon, where she played the classics, especially Racine, and particularly his greatest play, Phèdre - a role that she was to perform regularly from 1874 to 1913. "People often ask me why I never played Corneille," she once wrote. "The reason is very simple: in my opinion, Corneille could not write for women... Let's speak of Phèdre. There is the most touching, the most pure, the most sad victim of love!"

She performed roles written for her by the greatest French playwrights of her day - Rostand, Hugo and Dumas fils. Rostand, especially, gave her some of her finest modern roles. She played Roxane in the premiere of his Cyrano de Bergerac in New York. She triumphed in his play L'Aiglon, a play that exalted French national pride.

Cunningly, as France limped into its Third Republic and licked its wounds after the Franco-Prussian war, the divine Sarah thrilled patriots by playing national heroines. L'Aiglon was only one example. She also portrayed the revolutionary activist Théroigne de Méricourt, she was La Fille de Roland. The novelist Anatole France saw her as Joan of Arc and wrote: "She is at the same time a vision of an ideal life and an exquisite archaism: she is the legend animated." But Bernhardt did more than animate a legend. She took the raw material of Joan of Arc and made that legend part of herself. She had appropriated something of the Maid of Orleans's iconic power and thereby became an icon herself. The line between life and art was increasingly and appealingly blurred.

But in 1898, at the height of the Dreyfus Affair, she let it be known that she was half Jewish. Here was another Bernhardt - one step ahead of those who would try to define her. Yes, she was Jewish, but why reveal that fact then? "There is no artist worth the name who doesn't incessantly split their personalities in two," she wrote in her memoirs, My Double Life. But only a double life? Sarah Bernhardt led many more than that.

By now an international icon, Bernhardt toured Europe, and triumphed repeatedly in the United States. In the 1890s, she also became the personification of the Belle Epoque and a living symbol of Art Nouveau - decadent, morbid, dabbling in mysticism, and quite possibly partaking of illicit pharmaceuticals. Her intimate circle included men, such as the artist Gustave Doré, the composer and pianist Reynaldo Hahn, and Alphons Mucha, who created a series of posters of her greatest roles during the 1890s. The misogynistic aesthete poet Robert de Montesquiou was lured to Bernhardt's lair by the belief that she incarnated his philosophy - that women only achieved their raison d' tre by becoming works of art.

If Bernhardt was more work of art than woman (a silly if suggestive thought), she was constantly making this artwork more intriguing. During the first world war, her right leg, which was damaged as a result of repeated falls on stage, was amputated, but she continued to work until the last year of her life, 1923. Indeed, before the new century had reached its teens, Bernhardt was a film star - the 1912 film Elizabeth, Queen of England was a hit in the US. Her film career continued off and on until her death. She died in her son's arms, and thousands of Parisians followed her funeral cortege through the city.

Many are still obsessed with Sarah Bernhardt. In France, two biographies have just been published, neither of which nails the enigma. But perhaps biographies don't help - we need to hear her voice, to see the costumes she wore in order to feel something of what Gielgud and Lawrence experienced when they saw her on stage.

Now that the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris has a sumptuous exhibition devoted to Bernhardt, we can do just that. Or can we? Not for nothing is the exhibition subtitled "the divine liar". Bernhardt lied herself into being, and in so doing made herself captivating. Jean Cocteau, for whom Bernhardt was a "sacred monster", wrote: "Madame Sarah Bernhardt presented the phenomenon of living at the extremity of her personality in her life, on the stage." The important word there is "presented", and the crucial elision here is between her life and what she did as an actor. Isn't it possible to find out what she really was? Perhaps not.

And yet all the evidence is here - photographs, paintings, dresses, play bills, the sheer weight of historical documentation. One can hear Bernhardt in the 1906 production of Racine's Phèdre, or employing vibrato that reminds one of Edith Piaf during a particularly fraught scene from L'Aiglon, performed at the Theatre Sarah Bernhardt 100 years ago.

There she is as Hamlet, and as Pélleas in Pelléas et Mélisande. We see her caricatured by Aubrey Beardsley as Salome holding John the Baptist's severed head, in the play that Oscar Wilde wrote for her. Here too, towards the end of her life, is the theatrical icon as advertising tool, powdering her face with La Diaphane Poudre de Riz, and later raising a glass of Terminus absinthe (although she took legal action against the advertisers for using her image without her knowledge).

And there, at the culmination of this exhibition, is the fully mythologised Sarah in a reproduction of Georges Clairin's post Pre-Raphaelite painting The Enchantress in Her Lair, her body a twisting swirl of ivory dress, topped by a feline head whose potent gaze not so much returns as devours ours. She consumes our interest and tells us nothing.

The organisers muse on the question: Who are Bernhardt's successors? Greta Garbo (who played Bernhardt in the 1928 biopic The Divine Woman) and Maria Callas (who identified with Bernhardt and sang many of the roles she had acted) are held up as possibles, as (unexpected this) is Glenda Jackson. The organisers forebear from suggesting that she is the Madonna of a century ago, though perhaps they shouldn't have.

Ultimately, the image of Bernhardt that burns itself into the brain is a photograph taken in 1892. She is Phèdre, arms outstretched, face exultant. Her rictus recalls Gloria Swanson's insane pose at the end of Sunset Boulevard - ready, eager even, for her close up. But in Bernhardt's case, it seems clear, even the most scrutinising close up will give nothing away.

 Sarah Bernhardt or the Divine Liar is at the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris, until January 14. Details: 00 33 153 79 59 59.

And there, at the culmination of this exhibition, is the fully mythologised Sarah in a reproduction of Georges Clairin's post Pre-Raphaelite painting The Enchantress in Her Lair, her body a twisting swirl of ivory dress, topped by a feline head whose potent gaze not so much returns as devours ours. She consumes our interest and tells us nothing. The organisers muse on the question: Who are Bernhardt's successors? Greta Garbo (who played Bernhardt in the 1928 biopic The Divine Woman) and Maria Callas (who identified with Bernhardt and sang many of the roles she had acted) are held up as possibles, as (unexpected this) is Glenda Jackson. The organisers forebear from suggesting that she is the Madonna of a century ago, though perhaps they shouldn't have. Ultimately, the image of Bernhardt that burns itself into the brain is a photograph taken in 1892. She is Phèdre, arms outstretched, face exultant. Her rictus recalls Gloria Swanson's insane pose at the end of Sunset Boulevard - ready, eager even, for her close up. But in Bernhardt's case, it seems clear, even the most scrutinising close up will give nothing away.  Sarah Bernhardt or the Divine Liar is at the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris, until January 14. fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Looking down on the lower woods from the road, they leap from the tree canopy like cold fire. You only notice them twice in the year. Once when they are white as snow with blossom in spring, and once with that bonfire glow of red leaves in autumn. They are a group of wild cherry trees. Seeing them from a distance is one thing; finding them another. Distance in the woods is notoriously deceptive, but after a circuitous search I found a couple at a field's edge which led me in to the rest. On a steeply wooded bank by a stream, I walked into the cherry grove. There were twenty to thirty trees, most about 20 metres tall. The trunks still had the purple to silver-grey bark with horizontal bands of dark lenticels; none had the craggy furrows of old trees, so these were relatively young and in their prime.

The wild cherry or Gean, Prunus avium, is a distinctive feature of the well-drained, lime-rich soils of Wenlock Edge's woods. There is also a strong poetic link between the wild cherries and Wenlock Edge, largely through AE Housman. This year is fast becoming a spectacular show of autumn colour. A wet season has brought out the anthocyanin pigments in the leaf. Standing under the wild cherries the colour is not so bright because the undersides of the leaves are ochre-gold. But the flashes of red, framed by sessile oaks and wild service trees, burning high above the ground layer of short bramble, wood spurge and male fern, all still green, belongs to something beyond flower and fertility - a poetry of the burning, meteoric leaf, crashing towards winter darkness.
