fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge...
fields.body:
Spare a thought for Amazonian sometime actress Anna Nicole Smith, injured after a serious dumbell-related accident and now being sued for damages by a film producer after backing out of a prospective movie co-starring Joey Buttafucco, the Long Island adulterer who acquired a certain notoriety after his teenage lover Amy Fisher shot his wife back in 1992 (Tawdry? Us?).

The enterprise in question, The Underground Comedy Movie, wound up being released last year anyway, despite Smith's withdrawal on the grounds of - oh dear - it potentially damaging her public image. Anything else to take into consideration? Well, the defendant just won $450 million in a courtroom tussle over her inheritance from late oil tycoon J Howard Marshall, whom she married back in 1994, when she was 26 and he 89 (he died a year later). Which might, if one were to throw a cynical slant on things, possibly have spurred producer Vince Offer into action. Offer, it should be noted, is no stranger to litigation, with his plagiarism suit against the producers of There's Something About Mary - filed after Offer thrust a script into star Ben Stiller's hand in an LA street - still pending...

Meanwhile, Drew Barrymore 's estranged mother, former Playboy model Jaid (Tawdry? Us?) has finally walked free after being arrested on an illegal firearms rap back in May. Ma Barrymore had originally been charged after being searched while fly-posting for a local rock band in downtown Manhattan - going through her purse, police promptly discovered a loaded and unlicensed .357 Magnum, a misdemeanour even if, as she later argued, said handgun was "so old and dirty it couldn't fire". After a plea bargain last Friday, the old dear was sentenced to 10 days of community service and six months' probation.

webTitle: TV: Spike Lee's latest film, Bamboozled

fields.headline: 'Put up or shut up'
fields.standfirst: He only has himself to blame. After lashing out at US television networks for failing to give strong roles to black actors, Spike Lee has been asked to make his own shows. Can he come up with the goods? By  Edward Lawrenson
fields.trailText: He only has himself to blame. After lashing out at US television networks for failing to give strong roles to black actors, Spike Lee has been asked to make his own shows. Can he come up with the goods?
fields.body:
Spike Lee's latest film Bamboozled begins with a Webster's dictionary definition of satire. As we're caught up in the Swiftian sweep of Lee's narrative - in which a television writer's proposal to stage a minstrel show, with African-American performers blacked-up instead of white ones, is jumped on by ratings-grabbing executives and turned into a big hit - this introductory device might seem redundant. But satire isn't supposed to be subtle, and Lee, a fearless, full-throttle film-maker at the best of times, has never been one to pull his punches. An unsparing attack on the current state of US television, Bamboozled gleefully sacrifices dramatic nuance for polemical bite.

And some bite it's got, too. David Kissinger, programming president of cable station Studios USA, admits that the film, specifically its criticism of the stereotypical roles foisted on black performers in TV, has hit a nerve: "I think the criticism of [the television] business is richly deserved. While Bamboozled paints a portrait that's intentionally extreme, its point is well taken." Kissinger should know. He's just signed a one-year development deal with Lee. Having excoriated television executives in Bamboozled for failing to adequately reflect African-American experience on screen, Lee is now getting into bed with them. "I'm elated that I'm getting a shot, being put in a position to do something good in a medium I've been very critical of", Lee told the Hollywood Reporter, adding that it was time for him to "put up or shut up".

Lee isn't the only one taking TV executives to task here. Accusing the networks of a "virtual whitewash in programming", the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last year threatened a boycott of the main broadcasters because, out of the 26 new prime-time shows in the autumn schedule, there wasn't a single role for an actor from an ethnic minority. The networks have made some efforts to respond to the NAACP's criticism: broadcasting giants NBC and ABC, for instance, agreed in January to increase the number of black faces on television and have committed themselves to employing more people from ethnic minorities to work behind the camera. It's a start, but US TV still has a way to go.

Part of the problem is that network executives can shrug off their responsibilities to cater for ethnic diversity by pointing to the fragmented, multi-channel nature of television today: with stations like BET (Black Entertainment Television) aimed at black audiences, why the need to mess with such successful - and exclusively white - shows as Friends and Frasier? What the TV bosses don't add is that these shows play to young, white consumers - a constituency advertisers are prepared to pay top buck for.

The relationship between advertisers and audience demographics might go some way to explaining Lee's decision in April to make a short film for Jaguar. Intended to raise the car manufacturer's profile among African-Americans, Lee's film followed the publication of a leaked memo in a report into advertising last year, in which a broadcaster admitted that companies like BMW and Volvo weren't interested in buying ad space on black channels.

The irony of all this is that black performers have never been so visible on the big screen. Three of the major hits this summer - The Klumps, Big Momma's House and Scary Movie - have starred African-Americans, and Lee himself notched up a surprise success with his last film The Original Kings Of Comedy, a concert film shot on video starring four black stand-ups. The comics in Kings are all moderately well-known from their appearances on cable stations HBO and UPN, and it's through comedy that black performers - if failing to make much of a dent in big prestige sitcoms like Friends and Frasier - have established a foothold in the schedules. Martin Lawrence, star of Big Momma's House, came to prominence through his slots on HBO's Def Comedy Jam and subsequently got his own sitcom, and the Wayans brothers, the guys behind Scary Movie, switched from movie projects to TV throughout the 90s (although one of the most telling lines from Scary Movie was a dig at the network which dropped their latest show).

But Lee has his sights set on a series of hour-long dramas - an enticing prospect for audiences who have seen something of a renaissance in serious drama of late, spearheaded by The Sopranos. "There's a whole world outside of the sitcom," Lee said, announcing his deal with Studios USA. "Executives in television, and in the feature business, think that the white masses are more accepting of black people in comedy roles than in something a little more challenging." The point is made a little more forcefully in Bamboozled by Damon Wayans' TV scribe, as his frighteningly un-PC blackface minstrel show takes off with viewers: "The network does not want to see Negroes on television unless they are buffoons."

webTitle: All illegal migrants out, says Haider

fields.headline: All illegal migrants out, says Haider
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: Austria's leading far-right politician, Jörg Haider, has stoked more controversy by calling for the "elimination" of all illegal immigrants living in Austria.
fields.body:
Austria's leading far-right politician, Jörg Haider, has stoked more controversy by calling for the "elimination" of all illegal immigrants living in Austria.

Speaking to an audience of 2,000 in Vienna's town hall at the start of campaigning for local elections next spring, Mr Haider argued for a total halt to immigration - a call he evidently hoped would help to put his Freedom party back in the limelight after it was trounced in a provincial election on October 15.

"There are far too many illegal immigrants, crimes and drug dealers - none of them have a place here in Austria. This has to be our priority, to eliminate them uncompromisingly."

Austrians should be able to choose which immigrants the country was willing to accept, said Mr Haider, 50, who is governor of the southern province of Carinthia.

He also called for a ban on all anti-government demonstrations, adding: "Since I've taken office in Carinthia, no leftwinger has dared to demonstrate there any more."

Outside the town hall rally on Friday evening, supporters from the Freedom party - whose boss Mr Haider effectively remains despite stepping down as leader in May - clashed with anti-Haider demonstrators. Two members of the Socialist youth movement were treated in hospital. The suspected attackers were arrested. Skinheads were involved in the clashes.

In the days since Mr Haider s remarks, his successor as leader of the Freedom party, Susanne Riess-Passer, has been trying to smooth things over, saying his comments were misinterpreted.

"He was not referring to the elimination of foreigners, but to the elimination of the problem," Ms Riess-Passer said on state television. "I forbid this insinuation that the Freedom party is hounding foreigners."

Until the Friday rally, Mr Haider had toned down his rabble-rousing - including the pro-Nazi comments that have gained him much publicity and led to his international isolation - since taking his party into a governing coalition in February.

Mr Haider's town hall speech was made at the start of the Freedom party's campaign for next year's Vienna council elections. The party has just suffered its worst defeat since Mr Haider became its leader in 1986: it scraped only third place in elections in the province of Styria last weekend, with just 12.4% of the vote.

Human rights observers and opposition politicians have blamed Mr Haider for Friday's skinhead attacks. The more the anti-immigrant Freedom party becomes integrated into the mainstream, its critics fear, the more socially acceptable its ideas will be.

The skinheads were reported to have shouted: "What Haider can't do, we'll carry out on his behalf", and "Inside they're talking, outside we'll get down to business."

Michael Kreissl, Vienna party secretary of the Freedom party, expressed his regret at the attacks: "When you have a million voters, you can expect that there will be criminals amongst them."

Thomas Landgraf, chairman of the Socialist youth in Vienna asked "whether people will have to lose their lives before everyone understands what system and what attitude of mind is behind such attacks"?

After being ostracised, Austria is now trying hard to improve its image abroad. Yesterday it formally established a fund of 6bn schillings (£253m) to pay people from the region who worked as slave labourers for the Nazis, and today its first memorial to Jewish victims of the Holocaust is due to be unveiled on Jews square in Vienna.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Life jacket theft arrest
fields.body:
Life jacket theft arrest

Luigi Gavotti, 39, was arrested at Gatwick for stealing his life jacket on a BA flight from Milan.

He was given a police caution and missed his connecting flight to Argentina on Monday night.

Britain's oldest man dies

Bill Lee, 108, from Hanley in Staffordshire, Britain's oldest man, has died less than two months after being officially recognised by the Guinness Book of Records.

Murder on seafront

The death of Martin Quantick, 38, whose body was found with a head injury on the seafront at Torquay, Devon, on Saturday, is being treated as murder, police said yesterday.

Young fear homelessness

Young people fear being made homeless more than losing their job or ending up alone, according to a survey published by Shelter today.

The charity has also launched a Wise Up guide informing people about housing issues, rents, tenants' rights, problem landlords and benefits.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Jimmy Young/Frontiers
fields.body:
The BBC's determination to get punters using its multiple web sites finds it deploying some of its heaviest artillery. Throughout the week Terry Wogan has been popping out of odd corners on Radio 2 to offer advice to the unwebbed. Today he gets support from Jimmy Young (12noon, Radio 2). The editor of Computer Weekly, Karl Schneider, joins Young to bring tyro listeners up to speed. Later Schneider answers questions in a chat session on the Radio 2 website.

Modern gene technology has posed a question Charles Darwin never thought to ask. Having hit on the theory of evolution, Darwin assumed it to have been a continuous process once life started in the primeval slime. In fact, as Peter Evans discusses in Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4), there seems to be a large hole somewhere. Recent genetic research suggests that many species must have existed 600 million years earlier than anything discovered in the fossil record. Where were they hiding?

webTitle: US roadshow wrestler found dead in hotel

fields.headline: US roadshow wrestler found dead in hotel
fields.trailText: A leading American wrestler has died while touring the UK with a wrestling roadshow.
fields.body:
A leading American wrestler has died while touring the UK with a wrestling roadshow.

Agatupu Rodney Anoei, who performed under the stage name Yokozuna, was found dead at a Liverpool hotel on Monday. Police said there were no suspicious circumstances.

The Hawaiian-born wrestler, 34, who weighed more than 42 stone, had twice been the World Wrestling Federation (WWF) heavyweight champion, and had been a sumo wrestling star in Japan.

The father-of -two was touring with the WrestleMania roadshow, promoted by the Birkenhead firm Big Time Wrestling Promotions.

Brian Dixon, the promoter, said he was "one of the most important stars of wrestling", adding: "He was very proud to be part of a tour in this country".

Mr Anoei was due to perform on Monday night at Stockport town hall. Police were called to his room at the Moat House hotel at 4pm after his body was found.

The show went ahead, preceded by a 10-bell salute to him. Mr Dixon said the other wrestlers were "devastated".

"Yoko was a gentle giant. People warmed to him as he was a very charismatic character. When they saw him they were overwhelmed by his size."

Mr Dixon said it was possible the wrestler had died of a heart attack, "but he was very fit". Police said they believe Mr Anoei died of natural causes.

The Las Vegas-based wrestler was twice WWF world champion, beating Bret Hart and later Hulk Hogan in 1993.

webTitle: Jobs go as George defends pound

fields.headline: Jobs go as George defends pound
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, acknowledged yesterday that the pound was "substantially overvalued" against the single currency, as sterling's surge on the foreign exchanges was blamed for the loss of 1,300 jobs at Panasonic's Cardiff plant.
fields.byline: Mark Milner in Paris and David Gow
fields.body:
The governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, acknowledged yesterday that the pound was "substantially overvalued" against the single currency, as sterling's surge on the foreign exchanges was blamed for the loss of 1,300 jobs at Panasonic's Cardiff plant.

In the latest blow to the struggling manufacturing sector, the company cited the government's indecision over the European single currency and the pound's strength against the euro, and weakness against the dollar and yen, as factors prompting its decision to cut half its workforce.

But Sir Eddie warned that the pound could be brought down against the euro only by cutting interest rates, which would destabilise the economy.

Making a robust defence of UK policy towards the euro since its launch at the beginning of last year, Sir Eddie said that to have joined when the single currency was introduced would have risked "something of an inflationary boom".

Britain would have been faced with both a weaker exchange rate and lower interest rates during a period when the economy was growing strongly, he said.

Panasonic's decision is the latest by a foreign investor, including other Japanese groups, to scale down its Welsh operations, with around 2,000 jobs lost in television-making in the past few months.

Last week Sony cut 400 jobs at its Pencoed plant near Bridgend, partly blaming the pound's strength against the euro, while Hitachi and other groups have also reduced their workforces in response to sterling and technological change.

The Welsh economy is heavily dependent on manufacturing, which accounts for 30% of GDP compared with the UK's 17%, and after years of attracting foreign manufacturers bodies such as the Welsh development agency have only just begun switching their emphasis to promoting services.

Panasonic said it would cut 700 permanent jobs from among its 1,800-strong full-time staff, with 600 part-timers who work on a seasonal basis to go as planned. The redundancies are due to take effect by Christmas.

Adair Turner, vice-chairman of the pro-EMU lobby group Britain in Europe, said: "This decision is yet another example of the damage that sterling's volatility outside the euro is bound to do to British manufacturing."

Sir Eddie, speaking at a conference in Paris alongside Jean-Claude Trichet, the governor of the Bank of France, said the weakness of the euro complicated the task of the Bank's monetary policy committee in setting UK interest rates.

The economy was growing faster than it had historically, unemployment was the lowest for 20 years and on one commonly used measure inflation was the lowest in Europe.

"Our problem in the UK is the imbalance within the overall economy between those sectors that are competing with producers in the euro zone, who are under considerable pressure, and the rest of the economy, which is doing relatively well.

"Believe me, we are very conscious of the desirability of exchange rate stability with our partners in the single market," he said, though he added that signing up for the single currency would provide only limited exchange rate certainty.

"The ... weakening of the euro since the beginning of last year has not made things easier for us. Just as the euro is undervalued in terms of medium-term 'fundamentals', so in the same terms sterling is on most calculations substantially overvalued against the euro."

Despite the pound's strength, the UK recorded its first trade surplus with the rest of the EU in August for almost five years, according to official figures published yesterday. Exports exceeded imports by £31m. However, economists said firms were slashing prices in pounds to retain customers.

webTitle: G7 propped up euro to test US strength

fields.headline: G7 propped up euro to test US strength
fields.standfirst:
Governor says UK would have suffered inflationary boom if it had joined single currency from the start

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The Group of Seven industrialised nations intervened on behalf of the euro last month to test whether the clamour for US assets, which has been boosting the dollar on the foreign exchanges, had been overdone, the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Group of Seven industrialised nations intervened on behalf of the euro last month to test whether the clamour for US assets, which has been boosting the dollar on the foreign exchanges, had been overdone, the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, said yesterday.

Since the euro was launched, the US has run up a current account deficit of $500bn (£342bn) but that was overshadowed by inward investment of$750bn, while the single currency zone had seen a net outflow of $275bn.

Investors had been attracted to the US by the improvement in rates of return engendered by the "productivity shock" in the US economy, Sir Eddie told a conference in Paris.

But he argued that that would eventually be discounted by a change in asset values - including the exchange rate. "The problem is that we simply do not know how close we are to that point - or indeed whether we have already passed it. Putting that question to the market was, for me, the real point of the recent G7 intervention."

The weakness of the euro was not a result of any obvious macro-economic failure in the eurozone.

"It is much more likely that it reflects the magnetic attraction of the US at present as a destination for long term investment."

Though Jean-Claude Trichet, the governor of the Bank of France who shared the platform with Sir Eddie yesterday, stressed that Britain would be warmly welcomed into the euro his UK counterpart was cool on the prospect of Britain signing up for the single currency in present conditions.

Sir Eddie warned that if Britain had signed up for the single currency from the start, the lower interest and exchange rates would have meant that Britain would have been likely to have experienced "something of an inflationary boom".

He acknowledged that the pound was, on most calculations, "substantially overvalued" against the euro and that this was causing serious problems for sections of the British economy which had to compete against rivals in the euro zone. But he argued that for Britain to cut interest rates sufficiently to bring down the value of sterling "would destabilise our overall domestic economy".

Though it might bring some short-term benefits, the problems would reappear. "And in the meantime the whole economy would be exposed to accelerating inflation which we would be powerless to address through national monetary policy.

"Frankly it is not clear to me that this is a risk which it would be in the interests of either the UK or the eurozone to take in today's conditions."

"For the time being," he said, it would be better for Britain and the eurozone to pursue macro-economic stability in parallel and to hope that the euro would recover "as I continue to expect that it will".

"That strikes me as a more reliable path to sustainable convergence ."

fields.headline: Herbert Friedman
fields.standfirst: X-ray expert who unlocked the secrets of the cosmos
fields.trailText: Herbert Friedman, who has died aged 84, was a pioneer in x-ray astronomy. His research team discovered the Crab Nebula in 1964. He also directed research in metallurgy, electron optics and nuclear radiation.
fields.body:
Herbert Friedman, who has died aged 84, was a pioneer in x-ray astronomy. His research team discovered the Crab Nebula in 1964. He also directed research in metallurgy, electron optics and nuclear radiation.

Most of Friedman's hugely productive career was spent with the space sciences division of the United States Naval Research Laboratory (NRL), which he joined in 1940. He remained active as an emeritus chief scientist to NRL until a few months ago.

Friedman's pioneering work in space astronomy began with captured German V2 rockets. He used them to carry instruments into the upper atmosphere, where they could record x-rays and other radiation from the sun that was invisible to ground-based observatories. On more than one occasion his rockets did not behave as planned: one caused a diplomatic incident with Mexico when it flew horizontally rather than vertically as intended.

Friedman's early work showed that variations in x-rays from the sun caused fluctuations in the earth's ionosphere that disrupted global radio communications. Other astronomers soon discovered a host of mysterious extragalactic x-ray sources. The sources were given names like Scorpius X-1 and Taurus X-1, referring to the constellations in which they were found. In a classic occultation observation - a measurement made possible when the moon or a planet obscures a distant star - Friedman made the first optical identification of an x-ray source. He showed that the Taurus X-1 x-rays were coming from the Crab Nebula, the remnants of a star that exploded 1,000 years ago.

Friedman was born in Brooklyn, New York. He planned to study art when he enrolled at Brooklyn College in 1932, but, inspired by one of his tutors, switched to physics. On graduating he took a PhD at Johns Hopkins University and in 1940 joined the Naval Research Laboratory in Washington to investigate the crystal structure of metals using x-rays.

The director of his research at NRL, EO Hulburt, encouraged Friedman to apply his expertise to space astronomy. By the early 1950s he had designed x-ray detectors for high-altitude rockets that made key discoveries in solar astronomy.

During the International Geophysical Year (July 1 1957 to December 31 1958), Friedman led two major experiments involving rockets. The first showed that solar flares emitted hard x-rays that produced short-wave radio blackouts; the second used a total eclipse to pinpoint the part of the sun's corona in which the x-rays were generated.

His research group then turned to studying x-ray sources outside the solar system, and made the Crab Nebula discovery, described by physicist Freeman Dyson as the most brilliant achievement of the sounding-rocket era. The group subsequently detected extragalactic x-ray sources, the quasar 3C-273, and the giant galaxy M-87.

Physical Review, the top physics journal, accepted Friedman's first paper on x-ray stars with reluctance. But he then played a major role in promoting the use of large spacecraft for x-ray astronomy, and was one of the key scientists responsible for the establishment of Nasa's High Energy Astronomy Observatory programme in the 1970s.

Friedman held 50 patents and co-authored more than 300 scientific papers. Among his popular books was The Astronomers' Universe, a review of advances in infrared, visible, ultraviolet, radio, x-ray and gamma ray astronomy that led to the golden age of discovery in the second half of the 20th century.

His achievements were recognised by the most prestigious awards in his field of science: the US National Medal of Science; the Royal Astronomical Society's Eddington Medal; the Bowie Medal of the American Geophysical Union; the Wolf Prize in Physics; and the 1992 Massey Award from the Royal Society of London, in association with the International Council of Scientific Unions' Committee on Space Research. His wife of 60 years, Gertrude, and two sons survive him.

 Herbert Friedman, physicist and astronomer, born 1916, died September 16 2000.

fields.headline: Eduard Goldstücker
fields.standfirst: Literary scholar and prominent figure in the Prague spring of 1968
fields.trailText: Professor Eduard Goldstücker, who has died aged 87, was one of the last surviving protagonists of the Prague spring of 1968. During that time he was the chairman of the Czech Writers' Union and deputy vice-chancellor of the faculty of philosophy at Charles University.
fields.body:
Professor Eduard Goldstücker, who has died aged 87, was one of the last surviving protagonists of the Prague spring of 1968. During that time he was the chairman of the Czech Writers' Union and deputy vice-chancellor of the faculty of philosophy at Charles University.

Goldstücker had many close friends and colleagues in Britain. The turbulent events in his homeland caused him twice to seek refuge in Britain: firstly in 1939 as a young Jewish communist, fleeing the Nazi occupation, and secondly after the Soviet-led invasion of 1968. In Britain he was professor of comparative literature at Sussex University.

Goldstücker was born in a small town in Slovakia, studied in Prague and later, during his first exile in Britain, at Oxford. He joined the Czechoslovak Communist party in the 1930s, at the time of the rise to power of fascism in Germany, and was then most active in anti- fascist organisations.

In Britain, on completing his studies, he joined the Czechoslovak government in exile. Towards the end of the war he was appointed to the Czechoslovak diplomatic service, where he spent time in Paris and London. He subsequently became the first Czechoslovak ambassador to Israel at the beginning of the 1950s.

The Stalinist regime had been established in Czechoslovakia in 1948 and by the early 1950s purges were in full progress. Goldstücker was recalled from Israel and arrested. He was one of those involved in the show trials. Having spent the war years in the west and being of Jewish origin, he was a natural target.

The prosecutor demanded that he be given the death sentence, which was later commuted to life imprisonment. Goldstücker spent his years in jail under the most inhuman conditions in the Czechoslovak uranium mines - without any protection against radiation.

During the political thaw following Stalin's death in 1953, Goldstücker was released and began teaching German studies at Charles University. He was particularly known for his work on Franz Kafka and Prague's German-speaking writers. In 1967 he organised a conference on Kafka, an event well remembered because the regime had always suppressed Kafka's works, labelling them "hostile to socialism". Goldstücker was particularly interested in Kafka and was one of the most erudite scholars of his work. He had a wide know-ledge of German literature and could recite entire passages from the works of the likes of Heine and Goethe.

As chairman of the Czech Writers' Union, and as a member of the Czech parliament, he played a leading role in the movement to reform the repressive regime and restore freedom of speech - the 1968 Prague spring. He was working for the restoration of the ideals of socialism that had brought him into the left-wing movement and to which he remained faithful.

The Soviet-led invasion in August 1968 was a terrible shock and he was forced to emigrate. Accompanied by his wife Marta he returned to Britain and the Sussex University professorship. He also lectured at various western European literary institutions - his memoirs, written during this period, have so far been published only in German.

Immediately after the collapse of communism in Czechoslovakia, Eduard and Marta returned to their native country, where their two daughters, Anna and Helena, and their families lived. He was anxious to offer his knowledge to a country being reborn. But the new establishment was not interested in taking advantage of his experience and erudition. As a "68er" - an erstwhile reform communist - he spent the last years of his life almost as a non-person.

Yet Goldstücker was greatly respected, loved and honoured by some of Germany and Austria's most prestigious academic institutions. He lectured, was a member of the Saxony Academy of Literary Science, and two years ago was awarded the Federal Republic's Lessing Prize.

Goldstücker was one of the kindest, most considerate and generous human beings. He never fully came to terms with the demise of his beloved wife Marta four years ago. His treatment by the new Czech establishment was a great disappointment to him. He would have liked nothing better than to teach the rising generation. He had a fantastic memory and was something like a walking encyclopaedia, especially where historical events were concerned. He had a wonderful Jewish sense of humour and loved his family with devotion.

His greatest wish was the elimination of injustice. He passionately opposed the distortion of the truth and the fortification of history, in particular events that only he and his contemporaries could still remember. He was an eloquent speaker and never hesitated to state his views openly, even if these views happened to be unpopular.

His greatest passion was his books. He was unable to pass a secondhand bookstore without walking in and looking for something special. The library in his flat is incredible; we used to joke that his apartment was books, and more books, surrounded by a flat. He is survived by two daughters, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

He was a great man.

 Eduard Goldstücker, writer, diplomat and scholar, born May 30 1913; died October 23 2000.

webTitle: Kostunica takes grip on Milosevic fiefdoms

fields.headline: Kostunica takes grip on Milosevic fiefdoms
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: President Vojislav Kostunica inched forward yesterday in his effort to take more power from his defeated opponent Slobodan Milosevic when the Serbian parliament appointed a transitional government to run the republic until elections are held in December.
fields.body:
President Vojislav Kostunica inched forward yesterday in his effort to take more power from his defeated opponent Slobodan Milosevic when the Serbian parliament appointed a transitional government to run the republic until elections are held in December.

Nearly three weeks after he was declared the winner of Yugoslavia's presidential election, Mr Kostunica's allies won the right to oversee the Serbian premiership and the key ministries of police, information, justice, and finance.

As Yugoslav president, Mr Kostunica's main power is in appointing the foreign and defence ministers and the army chief of staff.

He has kept on the defence minister appointed by Mr Milosevic, even though he is an indicted war criminal, on the grounds that it takes time to consolidate democracy.

The other key powers are with the Serbian government, which was controlled by Mr Milosevic's Socialist party. A Socialist, Milomir Minic, will be the new prime minister of Serbia, but he will have to act in agreement with his two deputies, one an ally of Mr Kostunica and the other a representative of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement. Three-party troikas will be in charge of the main ministries.

This unusual division of power will at least allow Mr Kostunica's allies to escape some of the blame for what looks like being a tough winter for most Serbs, with looming shortages of fuel.

But he will get credit for the huge programme of food and energy aid from the European Union and the United States which his election victory has unleashed.

Mr Kostunica is hoping that the alliance of 18 parties which won him the presidential election will get the majority of seats in the Serbian parliament in the polling booths on December 23.

"The time of this government is limited and so are its tasks," Mr Minic told parliament. "Its two main missions are to stabilise economic policy and urgently address the economic needs of the citizens."

The new president is planning to visit Moscow on Friday to thank his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, for the important role he played in the transfer of power.

The Russians were the last major state to recognise Mr Kostunica's victory. Although this was derided by many western officials as a sign that Moscow was out of touch, the timing of the Russian declaration was significant.

It came a few hours before Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister, arrived in Belgrade to see Mr Milosevic and the new president the day after crowds stormed the parliament building and the main state-owned television station. The announcement that Mr Putin accepted Mr Kostunica's victory was a bitter blow to Mr Milosevic.

Mr Milosevic was still wondering about using the army to reverse the result and restore his rule, but at their meeting Mr Ivanov warned him not to try.

In some ways the Russians' action paralleled their contribution during Nato's air strikes, when their special envoy, Viktor Chernomyrdin, joined forces with western governments in urging Mr Milosevic to accept defeat in the military duel. This too was highly significant.

Mr Ivanov also persuaded Mr Kostunica to visit the defeated president at his villa and mollify him with assurances that he would not be extradited to the Hague.

According to Yugoslav intelligence sources, Mr Kostunica promised Mr Milosevic that he would resist western pressures for extradition, however strong they became.

He also promised to maintain stability in the army, which was interpreted to mean that he would not replace the defence minister and army chief of staff.

Some Yugoslavs wonder whether Mr Kostunica needed to take such a conciliatory approach. But the fact that Mr Milosevic still retained considerable power through the Serbian government apparently convinced the new president that he had to move slowly and gradually.

The fact that he took nearly three weeks to get agreement on a new Serbian government, which is still a hybrid of pro- and anti-Milosevic forces, may also justify his caution.

This unusual division of power will at least allow Mr Kostunica's allies to escape some of the blame for what looks like being a tough winter for most Serbs, with looming shortages of fuel. But he will get credit for the huge programme of food and energy aid from the European Union and the United States which his election victory has unleashed. Mr Kostunica is hoping that the alliance of 18 parties which won him the presidential election will get the majority of seats in the Serbian parliament in the polling booths on December 23. "The time of this government is limited and so are its tasks," Mr Minic told parliament. "Its two main missions are to stabilise economic policy and urgently address the economic needs of the citizens." The new president is planning to visit Moscow on Friday to thank his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, for the important role he played in the transfer of power. The Russians were the last major state to recognise Mr Kostunica's victory. Although this was derided by many western officials as a sign that Moscow was out of touch, the timing of the Russian declaration was significant. It came a few hours before Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister, arrived in Belgrade to see Mr Milosevic and the new president the day after crowds stormed the parliament building and the main state-owned television station. The announcement that Mr Putin accepted Mr Kostunica's victory was a bitter blow to Mr Milosevic. Mr Milosevic was still wondering about using the army to reverse the result and restore his rule, but at their meeting Mr Ivanov warned him not to try. In some ways the Russians' action paralleled their contribution during Nato's air strikes, when their special envoy, Viktor Chernomyrdin, joined forces with western governments in urging Mr Milosevic to accept defeat in the military duel. This too was highly significant. Mr Ivanov also persuaded Mr Kostunica to visit the defeated president at his villa and mollify him with assurances that he would not be extradited to the Hague. According to Yugoslav intelligence sources, Mr Kostunica promised Mr Milosevic that he would resist western pressures for extradition, however strong they became. He also promised to maintain stability in the army, which was interpreted to mean that he would not replace the defence minister and army chief of staff. Some Yugoslavs wonder whether Mr Kostunica needed to take such a conciliatory approach. But the fact that Mr Milosevic still retained considerable power through the Serbian government apparently convinced the new president that he had to move slowly and gradually. The fact that he took nearly three weeks to get agreement on a new Serbian government, which is still a hybrid of pro- and anti-Milosevic forces, may also justify his caution.

webTitle: Room for the reindeer to roam

fields.headline: Room for the reindeer to roam
fields.standfirst: Norway's Sami have got their identity back, but not their land
fields.trailText: Once they used to swim to and from their traditional summer grazing grounds on the islands off the coast on northern Norway. Now they take the ferry.
fields.body:
Once they used to swim to and from their traditional summer grazing grounds on the islands off the coast on northern Norway. Now they take the ferry.

Thousands of starving reindeer, too weak to make the crossing, are being carried across in landing craft. The Norwegians say the indigenous Sami (formerly known as Lapps) are themselves to blame because they have built up their herds to levels which lead to overgrazing: more than 125,000 reindeer in an area with food for fewer than 100,000.

It is a land of stunted birch trees, long fjords, and small grassy islands, and the question of who controls it has become a major political issue. The Sami claim traditional rights. The Norwegian government, which annexed it in an attempt to extinguish the Sami's cultural identity, says it is the owner.

The battle is a long-running one, but plans to open untouched parts of Finnmark to gold mining threaten to push the Samis beyond the point of endurance. Ragnhild Nystad, their vice-president, said: "If we cannot stop multinational mining companies taking over our land then the Sami's traditional way of life will disappear. As a people, reindeer herding is central to our culture."

The Sami live in a wide belt across northern Scandinavia, much more extensive than the geographical area known as Lappland. For thousands of years their people knew no national boundaries.They were left unmolested in inhospitable country.

Their troubles began when four countries drew lines across their traditional lands and attempted to suppress their culture, language and lifestyle. Despite this, they survived. There are 4,000 still clinging to their way of life in Russia, 10,000 in Finland, 20,000 in Sweden and 50,000 in Norway. Their language has nine dialects.

By 1900 they had officially ceased to exist in all four countries. It was illegal to speak the language or sing their traditional songs. A century later they have revived as a nation and formed a joint council embracing the four states, and now they have their own parliament building.

On November 3, in acknowledgment of their new status, King Harold of Norway will open the parliament, in Karasjok, the Sami capital of Finnmark: a small town in the most thinly populated part of Europe.

Although this new status is an immense leap forward, the Sami believe it is incomplete without a resolution of the land issue, and the Norwegian government, albeit reluctantly, accepts this.

The Sami say they hold the land in common, individual families having traditional grazing and fishing rights. The herds are owned, the family mark being a cut in the reindeer's ear.

Under government ownership, the grazing land was gradually whittled away by privately owned farms. But after a human rights commission study three years ago, the Norwegian constitution was amended on April 21 1998 to recognise the Samis as an indigenous people and an ethnic minority.

The reawakening of Sami pride in their race and culture began after the second world war, and became a militant force with a now celebrated protest against a hydroelectric scheme on the Alta river in Finnmark. The scheme, which threatened traditional lands and the community at Masi, led to sit-down protests, hunger strikes, and links with environmental groups. The protests failed to stop the dam, but created a new spirit of defiance and a new nation.

Twenty years of campaigning later Norway, Sweden and Finland recognise the Sami as an ethnic minority but the issue of land rights is still unresolved.

Ms Nystad said: "We own this land, we always have. It was taken away from us illegally and we want it back. We cannot stand by and watch it whittled away as more and more is sold off for farms and holiday cabins. There will be nothing left for the reindeer."

In Oslo the minister responsible for Sami issues, Steiner Pedersen, admitted that the land issue was central to the Sami's future. At present the Sami had no power to stop gold mining, "but it is a sensitive topic and they have a lot of influence". The government was working on a plan to give the Sami parliament joint control of over planning issues with Finnmark county.

Ms Nystad believes the government is playing for time. "As a nation we have lived here for thousands of years in tune with our environment. It is not us that that have caused problems. We are still waiting for promises given to us in 1981 over the Alta dam to be honoured. We have been disappointed many times since then and we are not going to let it happen again with the gold mine. The Samis have been patient for too long."

fields.headline: Last chords
fields.standfirst: Aznavour stages farewell
fields.trailText: Charles Aznavour, the diminutive Gallic crooner who was once told he was too ugly ever to sing a love song in public, began a sell-out series of farewell concerts in Paris last night which will bring down the curtain on a career spanning 65 years, 60 films and more than 1,000 songs.
fields.body:
Charles Aznavour, the diminutive Gallic crooner who was once told he was too ugly ever to sing a love song in public, began a sell-out series of farewell concerts in Paris last night which will bring down the curtain on a career spanning 65 years, 60 films and more than 1,000 songs.

"I'm a song pharmacist," he said yesterday, attempting to explain his success. "I apply balm to the pain. It doesn't last long, but that's the pharmacist's job - for anything more serious, you need to see a real doctor."

Aznavour was admired by Sinatra, idolised by Dylan and told by one who should know - Aretha Franklin - that he was the only living European capable of singing soul.

But he makes an unlikely star. At little more than 1.5 metres (5ft), he has had to compensate for lack of stature with a big stage presence and a talent for phrasing the French chanson unmatched since that of woman who discovered him, Edith Piaf.

He is also the first French singer since Maurice Chevalier to have had a successful career in Britain, and above all the US, where, last year, visitors to Time magazine's website, Time Online, voted him Entertainer of the century.

The composer of the line "She ... may be a face I can't forget, a trace of pleasure or regret" was born Sharmouz Aznavourian in Paris in 1924, the son of an Armenian actor and a Turkish singer who were running a cafe at the time.

His Armenian roots are important to him and he still presides over a relief association he founded to help the victims of the 1988 Armenian earthquake.

Inspired by the recordings of Maurice Chevalier, he began to write songs which he sang - with no success whatsoever - in the cabarets during the German occupation.

In 1946 he met Piaf - he swears they were never lovers - who persuaded him to have his nose remodelled, taught him how to deliver his songs, and told him he could be a star.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: French connection Telecom equipment maker Alcatel of France and US software company Oracle are to set up a company that will offer interactive television to telephone operating companies.
fields.body:
 French connection Telecom equipment maker Alcatel of France and US software company Oracle are to set up a company that will offer interactive television to telephone operating companies. Thirdspace will be available over ordinary copper telephone wires, boosted by Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) technology. It will offer broadcast television and movies on demand.

 On the rise US internet provider America Online said the worldwide membership of its AOL service has passed the 25m mark. Over the past year, the service added more than 6m new members.

 Inquiry line Japan's financial watchdog the Fair Trade Commission has launched an investigation into NTT East for allegedly obstructing its competitors from establishing high-speed digital subscriber line (DSL) internet services. The lines provide links to the internet at more than 30 times the speed of conventional connections. The inquiry may take a year.

 On stream, The world's first streaming video mobile phone has been launched by Geo Interactive Media and its Korean partner, Samsung. The MPEG4 will allow users to view video content more easily on their phones.

webTitle: Leader: Despite a strong pound, trade flourishes

fields.headline: Going our way
fields.standfirst:
Despite a strong pound, trade flourishes

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Whisper it, but Britain had a trade surplus with the rest of the European Union in August, according to figures published yesterday. True, it was a small one (£31m) and could easily be revised out of existence in a few months time - but that does not alter the fact that it was not supposed to happen at all.
fields.body:
Whisper it, but Britain had a trade surplus with the rest of the European Union in August, according to figures published yesterday. True, it was a small one (£31m) and could easily be revised out of existence in a few months time - but that does not alter the fact that it was not supposed to happen at all. We keep being told that the pound has soared so high - and the euro sunk so low - that Britain's exporters are being priced out of the market. Yet, instead, they have produced only the fifth monthly surplus since this statistical series was started in 1988. More puzzlingly, it has happened a month after Britain experienced a record trade deficit with the rest of the world, including Europe.

So what is going on? Britain is benefiting from a revival of world trade (up 8.5% this year) and a strong revival of Europe's economy. Exporters may be prepared to suffer low profits just to keep market share. The UK has gained from being an oil exporter when the price of oil - denominated in strong dollars - has risen strongly. Exports of oil have risen by 28% since January. But there have also been strong performances in other sectors - particularly capital goods, which rose 18% by value. Capital goods include computers and mobile phones which sell more on quality and innovation than on price. Semi-finished goods rose by 11% over the same period, though car exports dropped 25%.

No one knows whether August will be looked back on as the start of an economic miracle in which the quality of British goods overcame the vagaries of the exchange rate; or a glitch that will be quickly reversed. A clue may be gleaned from looking at UK trade with the rest of the world (excluding the EU). Export value rose by the same amount as exports to the EU (8.5%), suggesting the buoyancy of world trade was vital. But imports from the rest of the world increased by 16%. Perhaps Britain's surplus with Europe (but deficit with the rest of the world) is because multinationals are importing from places like Asia and then exporting the assembled products to Europe. Eurosceptics will doubtless claim that the figures prove the wisdom of staying out of the euro, while Europhiles will argue that if this is what Britain can do with an overvalued currency, think what greater benefits would have happened had we joined the euro at a lower sterling rate. The argument, if not the trade surplus, will run and run.

webTitle: US ponders air strikes against Bin Laden

fields.headline: US ponders air strikes against Bin Laden
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Yemen trial
fields.trailText: The US was considering the possibility of air strikes against supporters of the Saudi militant Osama bin Laden yesterday after intercepting further threats to its forces in the Gulf, a fortnight after the boat-bomb attack on the destroyer USS Cole.
fields.body:
The US was considering the possibility of air strikes against supporters of the Saudi militant Osama bin Laden yesterday after intercepting further threats to its forces in the Gulf, a fortnight after the boat-bomb attack on the destroyer USS Cole.

Forces in Bahrain and Qatar were put on the highest state of alert on the basis of the intercepted intelligence.

A Pentagon spokesman said the information was very specific but the credibility of the threat was unknown.

Analysts have noted several similarities between the attack on the Cole, in which 17 sailors died, and the bomb attacks two years ago on the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, which cost the lives of more than 300 people. In each case the assault was meticulously prepared and involved a relatively sophisticated knowledge of explosives.

Washington believes the African bombings were carried out by Bin Laden's central organisation, al Qaeda, but defence staff said hard evidence would have to be found of his involvement in the attack on the Cole and the subsequent threats before any retaliatory strike could be considered.

webTitle: The best bovine scene: O Brother, Where Art Thou?

fields.headline: The best bovine scene: O Brother, Where Art Thou?
fields.trailText: The Deep South. On the run from a chain gang, Everett (George Clooney), Pete (John Turturro) and Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson) have managed to hitch a ride with a passing motorist - serial bank robber George "Babyface" Nelson (Michael Badalucco). Sirens wail in the distance, as George greets his passengers.
fields.body:
The Deep South. On the run from a chain gang, Everett (George Clooney), Pete (John Turturro) and Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson) have managed to hitch a ride with a passing motorist - serial bank robber George "Babyface" Nelson (Michael Badalucco). Sirens wail in the distance, as George greets his passengers.

"George Nelson. It's a pleasure."

Without warning, he opens the driver door and strides on to the car's running board, casually turning to Everett.

"Grab the tiller, will ya buddy?"

Somewhat aghast, Everett slides over and takes the wheel. With one arm holding on to the roof, George glances back at the police cars gathering speed behind, then gestures towards Delmar.

"Hand up that Thompson, Jack."

Delmar fumbles for a machine gun.

"Say, what line of work you in, George?"

Cut to George standing on the running board, laughing maniacally as he sends a hail of bullets towards the police.

"COME AND GET ME COPPERS! YOU FLAT-FOOTED, LAME-BRAINED, SOFT-ASSED SONS OF BITCHES! NO ONE CAN CATCH ME! I'M GEORGE NELSON! I'M BIGGER THAN ANY JOHN LAW THAT EVER LIVED!"

Still firing on his pursuers, he notices a herd of cows in an adjacent field.

"Cows... I hate cows worse than coppers."

He begins shooting at the herd. One cow falls to the ground as the rest stampede. Delmar looks out of the window, appalled.

"Aw, George... not the livestock."

See also: The Killing of Sister George, Babe, Heathers

Don't see also: Twister

Pointless trivia: Besides playing the homicidal maniac George Nelson here, Michael Badalucco also played the serial killer David Berkowitz in Spike Lee's Summer of Sam.

webTitle: Eyes left as Gore tries to limit Green appeal

fields.headline: Eyes left as Gore tries to limit Green appeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore's "Nader problem" spread like a rash across the map of the United States yesterday, as his chances of winning eight states came under threat from the radical Green party challenger.
fields.body:
Al Gore's "Nader problem" spread like a rash across the map of the United States yesterday, as his chances of winning eight states came under threat from the radical Green party challenger.

The vice-president, diverting resources to head off the threat from the left, mounted a head-on offensive against Ralph Nader, the Greens' leader, spending a large amount of time in small western states such as Oregon and Washington to defend his green credentials. "I will stack my environmental record against anyone, including him," Mr Gore told reporters on board Air Force Two.

The vice-president's aides and supporters in Congress, meanwhile, are pressing home their point that a vote for Mr Nader is equivalent to a vote for the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush.

Late last night the Gallup/CNN/USA Today daily tracking poll showed the vice-president inching ahead of Mr Bush by one point. While statistically insignificant, it was a psychologically important shift.

However, Mr Gore has so far failed to eliminate Mr Nader and his radical populist message as a threat. In the closest presidential race in four decades, the 66-year-old veteran consumer activist holds the balance of power in eight swing states, which together account for 70 of the 270 votes in the electoral college, the body through which the states elect the president.

With his firebrand anti-capitalist rhetoric, Mr Nader regularly draws bigger crowds than Mr Gore or Mr Bush.

He has described Mr Bush as "a giant corporation running for president, disguised as a person". But he has often had even harsher words for Mr Gore, calling him "fork-tongued", "Pinocchio-nosed", and a "certified political coward".

The Nader threat is most potent in north-western states such as Washington and Oregon, where environmental issues and liberal politics flourish. But Mr Nader has also fed off a backlash against globalisation in urban centres in Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, where old industries have shrunk in recent years.

In the depressed town of Flint, Michigan, for example, where General Motors has shed 23,000 jobs in the past five years, Mr Gore recently drew a crowd of 200 people for a rally, while Mr Clinton attracted a turn out of 500. Mr Nader drew more than 1,100 enthusiastic supporters.

In several policy areas where the Republicans and Democrats share a lot of common ground, Mr Nader offers a markedly different approach. He calls for a moratorium on the death penalty, he would cut military spending by a third, decriminalise marijuana, establish public financing for political campaigns and set up a system of universal healthcare.

A dozen former members of "Nader's Raiders" from the candidate's days as a pro-consumer gadfly in the 1960s and 1970s, called on him last week to reconsider his campaign.

"It is now clear that you might well give the White House to Bush," they said. "As a result, you would set back significantly the social progress to which you have devoted your entire, astonishing, career."

Mr Nader shrugged off his old comrades' entreaties, however, telling a crowd of supporters: "The most important power they have over us is the power to make us think they are the only choices."

Part of Mr Gore's problem is that there is no counterweight to Mr Nader on the right to take votes away from Mr Bush. Ross Perot helped elect Bill Clinton in 1992 by drawing votes away from George Bush's father, but the party split this year, and its far-right candidate, Pat Buchanan, can barely raise 1% in the opinion polls.

The Green party's ambition is to win 5% of the vote, and thus win government funding in 2004. However, its signifi cance has been magnified by the closeness of the race, which could be the tightest since John F Kennedy beat Richard Nixon by a fraction of a percentage point in 1960.

Mr Nader's emergence as a serious player owes much to America's fondness for mavericks. He follows very few rules from the traditional politicians' playbook, often walking without a glance as groups of supporters clamour for autographs. fields.bodyText: Al Gore's "Nader problem" spread like a rash across the map of the United States yesterday, as his chances of winning eight states came under threat from the radical Green party challenger. The vice-president, diverting resources to head off the threat from the left, mounted a head-on offensive against Ralph Nader, the Greens' leader, spending a large amount of time in small western states such as Oregon and Washington to defend his green credentials. "I will stack my environmental record against anyone, including him," Mr Gore told reporters on board Air Force Two. The vice-president's aides and supporters in Congress, meanwhile, are pressing home their point that a vote for Mr Nader is equivalent to a vote for the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush. Late last night the Gallup/CNN/USA Today daily tracking poll showed the vice-president inching ahead of Mr Bush by one point. While statistically insignificant, it was a psychologically important shift. However, Mr Gore has so far failed to eliminate Mr Nader and his radical populist message as a threat. In the closest presidential race in four decades, the 66-year-old veteran consumer activist holds the balance of power in eight swing states, which together account for 70 of the 270 votes in the electoral college, the body through which the states elect the president. With his firebrand anti-capitalist rhetoric, Mr Nader regularly draws bigger crowds than Mr Gore or Mr Bush. He has described Mr Bush as "a giant corporation running for president, disguised as a person". But he has often had even harsher words for Mr Gore, calling him "fork-tongued", "Pinocchio-nosed", and a "certified political coward". The Nader threat is most potent in north-western states such as Washington and Oregon, where environmental issues and liberal politics flourish. But Mr Nader has also fed off a backlash against globalisation in urban centres in Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, where old industries have shrunk in recent years. In the depressed town of Flint, Michigan, for example, where General Motors has shed 23,000 jobs in the past five years, Mr Gore recently drew a crowd of 200 people for a rally, while Mr Clinton attracted a turn out of 500. Mr Nader drew more than 1,100 enthusiastic supporters. In several policy areas where the Republicans and Democrats share a lot of common ground, Mr Nader offers a markedly different approach. He calls for a moratorium on the death penalty, he would cut military spending by a third, decriminalise marijuana, establish public financing for political campaigns and set up a system of universal healthcare. A dozen former members of "Nader's Raiders" from the candidate's days as a pro-consumer gadfly in the 1960s and 1970s, called on him last week to reconsider his campaign. "It is now clear that you might well give the White House to Bush," they said. "As a result, you would set back significantly the social progress to which you have devoted your entire, astonishing, career." Mr Nader shrugged off his old comrades' entreaties, however, telling a crowd of supporters: "The most important power they have over us is the power to make us think they are the only choices." Part of Mr Gore's problem is that there is no counterweight to Mr Nader on the right to take votes away from Mr Bush. Ross Perot helped elect Bill Clinton in 1992 by drawing votes away from George Bush's father, but the party split this year, and its far-right candidate, Pat Buchanan, can barely raise 1% in the opinion polls. The Green party's ambition is to win 5% of the vote, and thus win government funding in 2004. However, its signifi cance has been magnified by the closeness of the race, which could be the tightest since John F Kennedy beat Richard Nixon by a fraction of a percentage point in 1960. Mr Nader's emergence as a serious player owes much to America's fondness for mavericks. He follows very few rules from the traditional politicians' playbook, often walking without a glance as groups of supporters clamour for autographs. At times he appears grouchy, rarely smiles, and speaks in a choppy, staccato style which lacks the usual cadences of populist politics.

fields.headline: Cuba relents on jailed Britons
fields.standfirst: FO angered as access is denied to six arrested security workers
fields.trailText: Moves to avert a diplomatic row between Britain and Cuba were under way yesterday after the Havana authorities took steps to allow diplomats access to six British security firm workers detained on suspicion of industrial espionage.
fields.body:
Moves to avert a diplomatic row between Britain and Cuba were under way yesterday after the Havana authorities took steps to allow diplomats access to six British security firm workers detained on suspicion of industrial espionage.

The British consul in Havana, Bernard Garside, met Cuban officials last night in an attempt to gain access to the five men and one woman who were being held at an undisclosed location on the Caribbean island.

The move by Cuba followed a statement from the Foreign Office demanding "immediate access" to the Britons, who have been held for more than two weeks. Conflicting accounts of what the six were doing in the country emerged last night.

It was rumoured they had been arrested on suspicion of some form of industrial espionage involving the oil or gas industry. But there were also reports that the five men were private eyes hired to tail a millionaire businessman suspected of cheating on his wife.

Ken Lodge, from east London, John Fawcett, also from London, and Derek Pitt, from Hertfordshire, were thought to be among those detained.

Mr Garside received assurances that the six detainees were in good health and that he would be granted access within the next 48 hours, the Foreign Office said last night.

"The Cuban authorities are investigating allegations that the six had been hired in connection with a private investigation into a case of marital infidelity involving a Cuban national for which they were using methods in breach of Cuban law."

No charges had yet been brought and the Cuban authorities had undertaken to provide access to a lawyer, he added.

"We will continue to press the Cuban authorities to honour their obligations under international conventions and grant access to consular staff without delay."

Mr Garside was told on October 9 that the six had been arrested. But the Cuban government did not give official notification of their detention until October 13, and despite requests for consular access to be granted the interior ministry refused permission for British officials to visit them.

Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, said yesterday: "It is unacceptable that six British nationals are being held in Cuba without explanation and without access.

"Their relatives have the right to know what is happening to them, they themselves have the right to know why they are being held, and the British government has the right to offer them consular protection."

Stephen Jakobi, of Fair Trials Abroad, said the fact the six had been refused access to consular help could mean the Cuban authorities considered that they were a threat to national security.

"It is unprecedented for the British government not to be given access for this length of time," he said. "That persuades me it is no ordinary criminal matter." Mr Jakobi said whatever the outcome there was no way the six could get a fair trial. "In 16 days you can get anybody to declare they are the Queen of Sheba. It's stunningly bad and in breach of that very basic diplomatic treaty, the Vienna convention."

The detained Britons will have sampled conditions in Cuban jails which were condemned in a recent report by the Washington-based Human Rights Watch as "substandard and unhealthy where prisoners face physical and sexual abuse".

The report added: "Most prisoners suffer malnourishment from an insufficient prison diet and languish in overcrowded cells without appropriate medical attention."

The effect on prisoners was dramatically underscored with the release last month of the 24-year-old British woman Rachel McGee, who spent 22 months in a Cuban jail for drug trafficking. During her sentence she lost three stones, suffered worms, a kidney infection, stomach problems and bleeding gums.
